description:
A solid restaurant inside Japantown that is a good "backup spot" when other more popular places are packed. The decor is minimalist, and spacing is cozy but comfortable. Try the Okonomiyaki here, which is a unique option.

I came here for a Saturday night dinner with three other friends. Saturday evening in Japantown is incredibly crowded, and so our first two choices for food were both packed. We walked around the plaza and found this location after 3 or 4 other options were all full. We were hungry by then and really looking forward to eating, so would've been satisfied with many spots.

Interior seating is quite limited. Their kitchen "juts out" into the main table area. There is not enough seating for large parties. If you have 8 or more people in your party, this restaurant may not be for you.

The food quality here is average (but above average when you're hungry). The sushi and teriyaki is on par where everywhere else in Japantown. This restaurant was my first experience with Okonomiyaki, which reminded me of Korean pancakes. A very rich flavor. 4/5.
author: Chris W.

description:
I'm a big fan of Japanese food, so eating in Japantown whenever I'm in SF is something I usually do. There is many Japanese restaurants to choose from there, including sushi spots, ramen spots, hibachi, and restaurants that serve a variety of Japanese food, like Mifune Don.

What drew my boyfriend and I to Mifune Don was their rice bowls. I was very eager to try  their unagi rice bowl. Stepping inside, the restaurant itself is very small. There was also just a single waitress. They were not busy, so we were seated quickly. We ordered croquettes, gyoza, and rice bowls. The waitress frequently refilled our glasses of water, and our food also came out fairly quickly. 

The gyoza was cooked really well--steamed and seared, although they were small in size. The croquettes were very good; they were not overdone, but I was expecting them to have meat or vegetables in it. As for my unagi bowl, the fish melted in my mouth easily. The rice was fine, but there was so much pickled ginger. I'm not the biggest fan of pickled vegetables, but will eat them in small quantities. However, my rice bowl had more than I would have liked. That aside, I still enjoyed everything we ordered. I'd be interested in eating here again to try their udon.
author: Natalie V.

description:
My family and I have been coming here for years and really enjoyed their lunch specials. I'm not a big ramen eater but thoroughly enjoyed eating theirs because their ramen noodles were perfect and the broth was delicious. I also loved loved eating their green salad. A HUGE bowl of greens and fungus and veggies and protein for $6. 

The last time I came to eat all that delicious goodness must have been late last year or early this year. I've been back twice since then and it seems as if they have now changed their menu. No more big bowl of salad and their ramen noodles have changed...just reminds me of eating Chinese egg noodles Bc it's so thin. I don't think I'll be coming back for awhile, and that's disappointing. It was good while it lasted. ‍
author: Jocelyn W.

description: Great small restaurant with solid food in Japantown! I came here with a friend on a Thursday for lunch, and it wasn't too crowded. I got the lunch special, which consists of ramen (shoyu or miso) and either curry or a beef bowl (I got the curry). There was only one server for the entire restaurant, so service was a little slow, but understandable. The ramen was delicious, and the curry was great too. The meal was very filling, and I barely finished it so portion size is adequate. Overall, this is a great place to grab a bite to eat, especially during lunch!
author: Lisa C.

description:
We were brought to our seats quickly, but there seemed to only be one waitress for the whole restaurant so it took her a while to get to us. When we ordered, we tried ordering sushi, but she said that they had ran out of rice which seems very outrageous since rice is such a staple. We also order water and tea, but we never got our tea and had to remind her three times for water although she got water for the table next to us who also arrived later than us. 

When we got the food, I was hoping that it would make up for the lack of service, but sadly it did not. The soba noodles tasted over cooked, the curry had an off taste, as well as the egg being cold like it came straight out of the refrigerator. My auntie and mom were also not satisfied with their meals.

The only thing that is good here is their Japanese pizza which also seems like what everyone gets, I really tried giving the place a chance especially because I knew that the waitress was probably trying her best, but ultimately the place did not satisfy.
author: Linda N.

description: Low reviews are due to the very very very slow service. Only one waitress and she has no sense of urgency. Foodwise- I tried the okonomiyaki and that was a disappointment! Maybe that's a bit unfair since I just returned from Japan where I had the real thing. But here it's so small! (especially for the price) And, it was not crispy at all- nor did they serve it on the hot plate that is set in the table! The gyudon curry I tasted a bit of also seemed a bit bland. Overall- not impressed, but given the limited availability of Japanese places around, I might return to try other items.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Since my last review with Mifune Don, I've been coming by more frequently strictly for two of my favorite comfort foods, Okonomiyaki and Tanin Donburi.  And that's pretty much all I've been having for the most part. 

Don's Special Modern Yaki -- http://bit.ly/2l9H2HF
w/ pork, seafood, vegetables, and soba noodles. 
Modern Yaki is always a favorite of mine and they do a great job at Mifune Don.  Don's Special is just a hodge podge of good stuff.  Seafood, meat, veggies, and noodles all mixed in a pancake batter.  It sounds and looks bizarre, but the taste is just wondrous!

Tanin Donburi (beef & egg rice bowl) -- http://bit.ly/2l7DW73
This always hits the spot!  I usually refer to this as the Japanese equivalent to steak and eggs all over rice.  Lots of tender marinated beef mixed with eggs and onions.  Very filling and comforting!

On occasion I do order other things like their Mixed Tempura, Oyako Donburi, or even their Beef Bowl (Gyu-Donburi).  All are have been just as good.  I do hope to try other things someday like their shabu shabu or curry, but I'll always be satisfied with their Tanin Donburi and Modern Yaki.

I think what I like best about Mifune Don is that it's been a very convenient restaurant for me in that I can always depend on getting seated right away and served food quickly.  It wouldn't say it's the best restaurant that Japantown has to offer, but their food and service have always been consistent and I always end up a full and happy customer.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Solid spot for Japanese food. I've been once before a couple years ago, but I had the chance to revisit recently and found myself really enjoying the food again.

I came with a group of 3 other friends on a Friday around 6:30 was able to get seated immediately. The restaurant was never quite full the entire time we were there, so I appreciate that I can get good Japanese fare without a wait.

I was craving okonomiyaki, which is typically described as a Japanese pancake or pizza, so that's what I went with. Surprisingly there aren't a whole lot of places in San Francisco that serve okonomiyaki; it's either this place or a pop up at Izakaya Rintaro and that's about it. They also have a good selection of appetizers, noodles (udon, soba, yakisoba, and ramen), nabe, rice bowls or donburi, curry, and standard fare like chicken teriyaki.

They had a couple options for the okonomiyaki, some with soba which I thought sounded very interesting. I wanted something more traditional though, so I went with the seafood okonomiyaki ($14.80), which comes with scallops, shrimp, squid, and vegetables.

The okonomiyaki is served in what looks like a cast iron pan with a generous amount of okonomiyaki sauce, kewpie mayo, dried seaweed, and dried fish flakes sprinkled on top. I'm used to the mayo being drizzled on top in a lattice like structure, but the spiral design they used here was pretty too. Taste-wise, I thought the okonomiyaki was pretty solid. I've had it runny (i.e. undercooked) before, so I really appreciated how nice and firm it was here. There was a good amount of seafood mixed in as well, and it was all very easy to eat with a fork and knife.

I'd love to come back again and try one of their okonomiyaki dishes that uses soba!
author: Dianna H.

description:
I was hungry and wasn't my choice as I was wanting Yakitori.  Mom and sister wanted ramen and Unagi...

The place is really small.  We were the 2nd set of customers.  We were sat and then served right away.  

What we got:
- Chashu Ramen with Unagi over rice
- Unagi over rice
- Pork and egg over rice
- Miso soup
- Green Tea

The food was so-so.  My mom said the unagi wasn't what she's used to, but she ended up eating everything.  My sister enjoyed her ramen and her Unagi.  But my pork dish was meh.  I barely touched my food at all.  Even if I wasn't in the mood for it, if I were hungry, I would have eaten it...but I was hungry...AND I didn't touch my food.  I honestly didn't like it.  The only thing i liked from my meal was the miso soup, the green tea, and the service.

I'd like to give this place another try and order something else.  Hopefully, it'll be a better experience for me.
author: Cat D.

description:
Walking around the Miyako Mall in Japantown, we passed by Mifune Don.

Mom wanted to give this place a try and so here we were. There is plenty of seating and the ambiance is laid back. Our server was friendly and attentive. The prices are reasonable and they are generous with the portions. We enjoyed the dishes we ordered, the soups were very comforting. I wouldn't say this was the best udon soup we've tasted but it was still quite flavorful. We enjoyed our meal and overall, I'd recommend Mifune Don if you're in the area.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
Mifune means 3 boats. There are good quality of limited selection of Sakè (sak keh), excellent Koshihikari Echigo craft beer from northern Japan, Sho-chu- (show chew)/low alcohol Japanese vodka. 

We had a nosh after touring the Japanese Garden in Golden Gate Park. So why not Japanese food in Japan Town, San Francisco?

Kaki Furai/panko breaded fried oyster. Nice light crunch with pleasant sea taste of oysters. Nice accompaniment of finely shredded cabbage & touch of orange carrots. 

Gyo-za (ghee yoh zah) or pork "pot sticker" dumplings fried then lightly steamed were meaty w/ touch of veggies minced in. The wheat flour based wrapper was not as lightly crispy  as desired. 

Koshihikari Echigo beer was an excellent palate cleansing, smooth, mild beer pairing.  3 Yelp stars where the food & service were A-OK.
author: Gary I.

description: Yesterday I met up with a friend I met in bumble BFF for a ramen date. We ordered the Tonkatsu ramen and udon. We both have a good time over a good ramen! Will definitely go back when I'm around Japan Town!
author: Emily Ann F.

description:
I guess you can never go wrong in Japantown, no matter which restaurant to choose from. Heard of Mifune Don from my friend due to its super cute store front, as if standing in a Japanese cartoon series.

The place was rather small, and could fill up really quick during lunch times. Not really hungry myself, I decided to sample the Zaru soba - my to-go option.  Noodles were cooked at the perfect texture, and dipping sauce well made too. The only complaint was on their wasabi sauce - a bit lack of flavor.

Many lunch specials to choose from, and you can always mix and match noodles with dons. Reasonably priced.
author: Elaine H.

description:
Found this cute little stall inside the Japan center. They advertised ramen and a variety of dons. 

Our party of 7 was quickly seated as there was only one other party there. The inside was very small, but comfy. Myself and my brother ordered the katsu and unagi don. Both were good but i probably should have ordered the unagi don. The rest of the party ordered different flavors of ramen. The ramen was so so, I've had better elsewhere. 

Overall, it was decent for a quick bite to eat. I think we jumped the gun on choosing this place because once we started to walk around, there were other more appetizing places.
author: Emie S.

description: Cheap, tasty and consistent. I love their fish cake  udon. My family has been going here since I was a kid. The best way to warm up on a drizzly San Francisco day.
author: Sharon M.

description: I ordered the special, the pork ramen with a shoyu base. It offered a solid meal and the pork offered a sweet taste that complemented the salty broth. The noodles were alright in texture, but lacked kick. Also, the broth was as thick or rich as I would've liked it. Still a solid meal though.
author: Nathan C.

description: The service was slow the day I went because there was only one server. The wait time for food is pretty long depending on what you get. I got the don special okonomiyaki which was very good, but a really long wait. The portion was very large and left me really full. The lunch specials were a good deal and highly recommend since my friends liked the ramen. I would come again.
author: Monica D.

description:
Don't eat here!! I have two reasons for my one star review. This is all that happened when I was still in high school a year ago or two but I just want to highlight what I remember.

I ate here multiple times before because of its convenient location.

One time my friend and I were asked to leave just because we brought in rice balls we bought from a different place. Honestly I don't see the problem with bringing a small snack as long as we were going to order their food also. I didn't bother to explain that to them because they asked us to leave right away without asking us if we were going to order and I didn't think it was worth it since they were so rude. Just because we were high schoolers at that time it doesn't mean they can disrespect high schoolers.

Besides that, I came here on another occausion with a different friend. She ordered kimchi soup here and she had FOOD POISONING after eating it! She got dizzy and then she threw up all of the kimchi soup on the way home! We know it was the kimchi soup because she felt sick the moment she ate the kimichi soup. She reported this to the Public Health department as well.

All of the other times I ate here, the food wasn't even honestly good at all.

There are plenty of other restaurants in Japantown to eat in. Don't come to this restaurant.
author: Erica L.

description: Really good Japanese spot ticked on the corner upstairs. Veggies are super fresh and cooked just right. Nice and crispy but not overly oily. Regular Ramen was very good with good sized chunks of meat and lots of noodles.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: We always go here whenever we go to Japantown and our favorite are the Japanese curries and the okonomiyaki . We came back and we were surprised that the food is very different. The portions are smaller and overall quality of food are not as good as before.
author: Lorencito D.

description:
WARNING : IF YOU HAVE ANY ALLERGIES AVOID THIS RESTAURANT.  THEY DON'T RESPECT DIETARY NEEDS...

Would never go back.  

The food was a horrible experience. I ordered a meal and asked specially for a chicken only dish because I can not eat seafood.  When my dish arrived I started eating and about a third of the way through a tentacle appeared. When I asked the waitresses she said 'what am I supposed to do about it?', I said I can't eat that and checked before with her. So she rudely said 'you already ate it so I'm charging you'.  No apology, no admission of a mistake, just a stone cold angry glare that I had dared to complain. 

The waitress was incredibly mean.  Besides the food issue - she wouldn't even give a piece of tissue paper to a person who wasn't buying food. It was so petty her refusing to give a cheap napkin when she had 5000 of them right next to her.
author: Robbie M.

description:
Came here last weekend with friends (we have to take up 4 tables, sorry everyone) during the Cherry Blossom festival and thought we should try this Ramen spot out. The wait was long, then again, it is during a major event hosted in Japantown every year. When we were seated, we ordered out dishes. I ordered the Ramen of course.

Food: It's decent. Solid flavor and satisfies your Ramen craving.

Service: Could be better. Servers weren't exactly the nicest but I honestly can not blame them given the rowdiness of Japantown that day; however, that doesn't excuse one being rude to a friend of mines.

Overall, this is a decent spot.
author: Vincent V.

description:
Le bf and I were craving Japanese curry on a Saturday night. Because his favorite Japanese curry spot was closed, we needed to find a different place. We decided on Mifune Don. We figured that it was in Japantown and this place also served soba, which I was desperately craving. 

We ordered:
1. Cold soba noodles
2. 2 katsu rice curries

Our order seemed simple enough, but there is so much backstory to it. The day we came, there was some sort of cosplay event that had just wrapped up. Most of the restaurants had lines of people waiting to get it. Mifune didn't, so we were like "Yes, score!". Le bf originally wanted chicken katsu curry. When our nice server came to take our order, we learned that they had just sold their last portion of curry (to a girl that was sitting right next to us). She said that she would go check to see if they had anymore. She came back a few minutes later saying that they for sure didn't have anymore but somebody was going out to get more, but wasn't sure if they would be successful. We thought that was a bit weird. 5 minutes later she said that she would take our order and let us know if we would get curry. (Believe me, we were super confused at this point, lots of eyebrow raises and everything. I swear I'm telling the story exactly as how it happened). So we ordered the soba, I ordered my katsu rice with katsu on the side (I don't like my meat pre-smothered in curry), and le bf ordered his chicken katsu curry. We were then informed that he couldn't order chicken katsu curry because they didn't have any chicken left. He could only order pork katsu, shrimp, or potato croquette. He ended up picking the pork katsu.

The food tasted pretty good. Soba is very hard to mess up. I thought the dipping sauce was a bit salty, they could have diluted it more. The curry didn't actually come out hot, which was confusing because it seemed like they just made it. The rice and the fried katsu was, but the actual curry sauce wasn't. Hmmm......weird.

Overall, we know that it wasn't our server's fault that it seemed like the kitchen ran out of everything we wanted to order. Glad we both got to satisfy our Japanese curry craving. Would we come back? I don't really know. I can't say that I recommend this place, just because it was only around 6:30pm and they had ran out of multiple things. I guess the only positive thing was that the food was alright and we didn't have to wait to be seated. 

Be careful when you walk in, the floors were coated with something and it made walking slippery and dangerous. The staff were constantly reminding people to be careful when they walked.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Our second foray into Japan Town. And the line to Kui Shin Bo did not fit our tight schedule for a reprise, so we looked around and decided to try this little ramen shop. 

The lunch specials served up large portions of food. 

The California roll was well constructed featuring crab salad with creamy avocado. The Unagi don was lovely with sushi rice underneath velvety lobes of grilled eel. The sushi rice grains had a superb texture. The Gyoza was crispy on the outside with tender filling inside served with a tangy dipping sauce. 

The Niku soba was alright. The Udon was better. But the Chashu ramen stole the show. The broth on the Chashu ramen was bold and punchy without being too salty. Unfortunately, it did not have the gooey yolk egg we crave on ramen bowls. But the thick sliced of Chashu were tender and well marinated.

I spotted some emancipated chirashi don on our way out with par, thinly cut Maguro draped on rice.

Fair deal, but not a reason to go out of my way to eat here.
author: Lu-Shien T.

description: The food here is horrible, it's a bad experience. Small quantity, high price. the soba noodle is toooo salty and make me almost dead.
author: Sandy H.

description:
Authentic okonomiyaki is very hard to find these days. I was supposed to visit Gottsui in LA, but it closed right before my trip to LA and SF.

I got a chance to visit Japantown in SF for the first time. So I search for authentic okonomiyaki spot in SF. And Mifune Don seems to be the only place that offers this dish.
So glad I stopped by. The place looks like a normal small Japanese restaurant. The menu is also very simple but good amount of okonomiyaki selections.

I ordered Modanyaki. Which has pork, squid and vegetables over yakisoba. I personally love Hiroshima-style because of eggs and yakisoba.
My okonomiyaki came out piping hot and perfectly cooked. Good amount of pork and squids. Vegetables were also very flavorful because of okonomiyaki sauce and Japanese mayonnaise. Yakisoba noodles were soft and slightly charred crunchy.

Wish I get to eat authentic okonomiyaki like this more often. But it's so difficult to find places like this these days.

Oh, we also ordered gyoza, very tasty with beer. But if you come to Mifune Don. You have to order their okonomiyaki! Otherwise, you missed out big time.
author: Cafe S.

description:
I can't speak for their sushi (or other menu items), but definitely get the modanyaki okonomiyaki! There's pork, squid, vegetables, soba, and katsuoboshi. It's one of the thickest and juiciest okonomiyaki I've tasted so far. It's great comfort food and looks aesthetically pleasing.

The restaurant is rather small. I can't imagine how long the wait must be during popular days/nights. I came in on a Sunday night and it was perfect timing -- no wait at all!
author: Jenny H.

description: Food is decent - very very solid. I love this place. That beind said, this rating doesn't reflect the quality of the food - it only reflects the price to quality ratio. The food here is just so pricey. Donburi should not be more than 10 dollars, let alone 15 for tax and tip. It's just absurd. But I get it, real estate is expensive and everyone has to make a living.
author: David Y.

description:
JapanCenter--both West Mall and East Mall--are full of a lot Japanese restaurants. I'm a very picky New Yorker and as appetizing as everything looked in the West Mall, I decided to travel to the East Mall to see what's there. I had a mission to have katsudon! I came across a very humble looking restaurant on the second floor--Mifunedon--and right away I knew I came to the right place. The waitress seated me right away and was very kind when I asked her if she had my favorite -don. She said yes and I was excited.
It didn't take long for my meal to come out since their speciality is -don. I asked for water since I wasn't in the mood to have something that would overwhelm the taste of katsudon before it arrived. I asked for water and to my surprise, they had squeezed lemon into it! Some people may not like that, but for me it was a cute little surprise! Also, when the tray was set in front of me, I also saw a bowl of miso soup! I don't remember if it came with the order, and sometimes some Japanese restaurants do that, but miso soup always functions as a good way to ready your tastebuds.
Then... Came the Katsudon. Biiig bowl. Good size cutlet. I found it odd that she asked me if I wanted egg--who would have katsudon without it??? Anyway, what I liked at first was that they didn't put any pickles on top. Then I began my adventure into katsudon! So good! The sweet egg was properly cooked on the katsu. And the rice under the cutlet was hot and full of flavor with sauce and onion! I really enjoyed myself.
When you go to visit Japantown, make sure you go somewhere that takes prize in certain dishes or else you will be paying more for something you're not sure you wanted. I got what I wanted and it was great.
author: Brittany B.

description:
stopped for a bowl of ramen as late lunch.  The place was packed (honestly which SF restaurant isn't... they have so few tables to begin with...). 

First impression? Pricy. $12.90 for ChaShui Ramen is pricy even compared to other stall around it.  

Was the Ramen outstanding? No. It wasn't outstanding enough to justify the extra cost.  It wasn't bad though.  It just wasn't great. 

Service was slow.  If you haven't realized by now, I really hate waiting long for my food.  They took awhile to seat us, then waited to take our order and then waited to give us our bill.  

Overall, I'm pleased but I probably wouldn't come back if I was in the area again.
author: Jia Jian T.

description:
BF was an okonomiyaki virgin. Obviously, I have to pop that cherry. The few places I've tried before aren't going to cut it. So based on recommendation, I decided to gamble it all on Mifune don.

 This review is solely for their modanyaki (Okonomiyaki with pork, squid, vegetables layered with soba and katsuoboshi). We didn't try anything else since we came around closing time. It took awhile for it to come out (about 20mins). It comes on a hot plate, generously topped with okonomiyaki sauce and the katsuoboshi squirming from the steam.
The size was about 9 inches in diameter or bigger.

The texture was pretty darn amazing. The crunchy cabbage, crispy soba, chewy pork and squid, and the solid non-soggy dough keep teasing our mouth. The pancake can stand up againts and yet work with the sauce and seasoning. The sauce was a tad too sweet for bf, but a drizzle of the sesame chili oil on it made he moan in pleasure. This was the best okonomiyaki I had in San Francisco so far. Glad we didn't order two. One was already very fulfilling. Cherry popping mission has been accomplished!

The service was great. The kind waitress made sure we take our time eating even though it's past closing time.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Were immediately seated upon arrival. We went on a Thursday around 1:30pm.

INSIDE

This was a pretty small shop. There were about 5 booths that fit 4 people. Bar seating for 4 people. A couple other tables in the back. Seats in the booth are comfy, and tables are clean.

KARAAGE

The chicken was a little bit overcooked. The meat itself was a bit hard, although the sauce, lemon and chili oil went well with it. So because of that, I have to minus a star.

SEAFOOD OKONOMIYAKI

My girlfriend and I liked this very much. It was a sweet, seafoody, and tasted like potatoes and went really well with the chili oil they have on the table. I'll admit that I went through a lot of oil with this dish. heh.

OTHER

I really liked the matcha tea, and it doesn't cost anything! They were really nice with always refilling my cup when I wanted more :D. The waitresses are extremely polite. Thank you for your service! :)
author: Alexander T.

description: This is the place to go to for homemade Raman noodle it has mant different choices and you get so much Raman its hard to finish it but its so good that you finish it had fish Raman and the pork Raman both equally good
author: Matthew H.

description: We wanted a quick dinner so chose this one. Thought it would be quick because there wasn't much people there when we entered....However we were wrong. We ordered a table cooking and pancakes and waited for forever.....the flavor was ok.
author: Tianjia C.

description: Me and my boyfriend ordered udon and ramen. The broth was the only thing decent about it. Both noodles were hard, and not bouncy. My boyfriend wanted to send it back, but I don't think the quality of their produce could be any better. The service was great, but the food, eh.
author: Annie C.

description:
Mifune has slipped down the slope of badness. Okonomiyaki (actually Modenyaki version) now is a faint shadow of what they used to make. My honey's only reason to come here, is now very disappointing. Don't know what went wrong, maybe they changed the cook from Jose to Mario (just take a peek into the kitchen and this statement will make sense, and that is not racist, it is reality).

Could it be that Mifune is on a cost cutting plan, to reduce the ingredients (none carry a big price tag) or it could be that no one is paying attention. 

What ever the reason, Mufune's Okonomiki is now a substandard disappointing example. Not sure I can return.  

Servers remain attentive and thoughtful; however, their service can not make up for bad food.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
If you come here for the Okonomiyaki only and you will be fine. This is what they are known for and they do it pretty well. The other menu items were very average.

I would recommend avoiding the sushi. The sushi nigiri I had here was not very good, thin little slivers on huge hunks of rice. The fish to rice ratio was lower than any sushi I have ever had.
author: David T.

description: Good prices, definitely try the okonomiyaki. It's delicious and one of the few places I've seen it outside of Japan.
author: Zoe B.

description: The service here wasn't the best. My bf ordered a beer and she asked what size and ended up not bringing any beer. Lol the food is decent but the food and experience wasn't memorable. I think this place is just ok.
author: Jess P.

description:
I came here to grab a bite after walking around the mall area. I ordered the combo of ramen with gyoza for $12.95.  The food came out in 10 minutes.  I really enjoyed the ramen noodles, which were homemade. The broth was very fast.  The pork slices were thick and a bit fatty.

Overall, food was reasonably priced.  Service was great considering there was only 1 waitress for the whole restaurant.  I would come back again.
author: Rita V.

description:
Ebi curry don - 4 stars
Loved the curry! Good flavor and not too heavy. Better than the curry dishes I've had at Coco Ichibanya and Nana's Green Tea in Singapore, which surprised me.

Had some of the pork okonomiyaki and thought that was pretty good too.
author: Nicola L.

description: Came here with a friend after work because we were craving some chicken katsu and my friend recommended this place. It wasn't busy at all seeing that we were the first ones there and no one came in after us. The waitress was nice and accommodating. We ordered the chicken katsu but when the if came out we were disappointed. The portion size was small and the chicken was probably sliced in half to make it appear more full. Taste wise, it was good but not the greatest. The whole meal was probably the size of my hand which isn't that big. Definitely not worth the $12.80 I spent. I had high hopes for this place since I read their portions were big but I guess things change in a month or two.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
My boyfriend and I were craving udon and stopped by this little gem in the Japan Center! There's many Mifune Don in this mall, but the one that I'm giving five stars to is the very small one that closes early. 

SERVICE: Exceptionally great! There was only one waitress there at the time we went (around 8pm) with only an hour left till their closing time. She was so nice and friendly the whole time. 

FOOD: I'm from Seattle and I might be a little bias that U:DON in Seattle is the best, but the combination of the udon, chicken, pork, tempura was too exciting to pass! I got the Nabeyaki Udon. It was so good! But for $11.80, it was pretty worth. My boyfriend got the Sukiyaki Udon and it was very delicious! I love their broth. Lastly, we ordered the infamous okonomiyaki! This is a MUST get. We ordered the pork and egg was very satisfied. Pretty pricey though...but worth the try.

We will definitely be back for more Udon in the future. This is the place to go for Udon and Okonomiyaki.
author: Eva L.

description:
This is not my first time here. I have always love getting dinner here whenever I'm in Japantown. Japantown has many places for udon fix but this one is so far my favorite one. Below this restaurant is Daiso- so if you come earlier for dinner you may walk around downstairs to digest a little.

I usually get their udon with tempera. The udon here is authentic and cooked just right with the broth not too salty. The server here named Sara is also very sweet and she's on top of her game! She constantly check back with our table and she served the whole restaurant! Shout out to her for being the hostess and only server here. 

I will recommend this place for anyone who likes udon. Prices are also not that high which is great compare to other places in San Francisco.
author: Sammi L.

description: The service is speedy, the food delicious. A favorite of mine in the neighborhood. Japan town is so clean and quiet and just very welcoming.
author: James I.

description: Best place for ramen. The waitresses are quick, courteous and attentive. I drive a hour away just to eat here. You won't be disappointed it's delicious
author: Victoria V.

description:
As some of my friends already know, I've never been a fan of any of the Mifune restaurants that I've tried in Japantown, nor have I ever understood why there are so many.  Perhaps the tourists passing through like them well enough, nothing I've tried has been very good.  Generic, overpriced food?  Pass.

If there were a Mifune I could have gotten on board with, it would have been Mifune Don.  Compared to the original Mifune, the menu here is a bit more interesting, with okonomiyaki, sukiyaki, and AYCE shabu offered on top of the usual suspects (ramen, udon, donbouri, and sushi rolls).  However, not wanting to pay regular prices for anything, my friend and I decided to check out their lunch specials after doing some shopping at Nijiya.

Offered daily (I think), Mifune Don's lunch deals are pretty decent for the money - one of four different udon/ramen/soba dishes and a choice of eight different "sides" ($12.85 or $13.95, depending on your side).  For myself, I opted to go with the ZARU SOBA and NIKU DON ($12.85).  The presentation was nice, and the portions were fair, but neither stood out in any particular way.  The taste of the Zaru Soba was fine, though the noodles were a little gummy.  As for the Niku Don, it was similarly underwhelming; while the flavor was okay, it could have been stronger.  Plus, the beef was a little tough.

Even though I really don't think any Mifune restaurant is worthwhile, Mifune Don might be the best bet, if only because the others I've tried seem worse.  Plus, at least this one can offer table top cooking options (though there are better alternatives nearby).  Otherwise, there are too many other options to explore.  Especially if you're a tourist...

TWO AND A HALF STARS rounded down.
author: Mike L.

description: I was here with my friend and i wasn't that hungry so I said I would share. The worker said you can't share and insisted i order something. I said i wasn't hungry and she rolled her eyes at me and when i asked for water she completely ignored me. The food was decent but they are very rude
author: Alisha C.

description: First time. Tasty!! The curry is pretty legit and they are famous for their Japanese pancakes!
author: Helen W.

description:
So I've been here twice in my lifetime: once many years ago with friends and once this year with my family. I got to try the ramen, curry rice, and the okonomiyaki. I'm not going to compare this to Japan's food since it doesn't come close to being that good, but for being in J-town, it should be decent, right? Not even close. Yeah, I've experienced better Japanese food in other areas in this plaza alone. The only thing remotely OK was the okonomiyaki, but it is covered in sauce so how do you mess that up, right?
The service was the only thing really exceptional. For the price, this place isn't worth it, but it was the only place open so, we took what we could and well, it's an experience right? Now, I know where NOT to eat.
author: Jenn T.

description: This place has never let me down! Gyoza, okonomiyaki and yakiniku is ON POINT! Only reason this place is a 4 star and not a 5 is the soups. Im not a big fan of the base it seems to lack flavor. Oh and service is great. I always recommend this to my friends who come to japan town
author: Richmond G.

description:
Friend and I visited for lunch. She ordered a udon lunch set and I got a soba lunch set. Both of us ordered the chirashi with our entree. 

Service was okay, my soba was okay, wish they would have been more generous with the radish and green onions to add into the dipping sauce. The chirashi on the other hand, was not good. It came with a shrimp, a tuna, and another fish I forgot. The shrimp tasted over cooked and also like it was left for a few days. The tuna was okay, I spat out the other piece of sashimi though.
author: Ariel C.

description: My friend decided to eat here when we visited Japantown. He got this chicken egg rice dish(oyako donburi). He thought it just came with egg. He's vegetarian, so I ate all the chicken pieces. I got an oshinko roll and it was good. Problem is we waited a pretty long time for our food to come out.
author: Denise C.

description:
Dad and I were starving and thought we'd go here since it was packed. We usually figure busy is a good sign. And we were too hungry to really keep looking around. 

Disappointed.

Service was good and fairly quick.

Dad and I ordered to share:

Curry Katsu
Tempura Udon
Salmon Roll

Everything was bland. Flavorless. 

We were super disappointed and don't suggest this place at all. 

Meh.
author: Natasha S.

description: I find this to be just as equivalent to the other Mifune restaurants in Japantown, which is a 3star rating. I find the food to be mediocre in quality. However, I do find the lunch combos to be very worth it.
author: Stacey M.

description:
2/5 for food. 5/5 for service. 

I got the ...

1. Tempura udon ($9.50): comes with battered fried tempura and vegetables (pumpkin, sweet potato, and broccoli). It's just like any other udon. Not the best, not the worst.

2. Zaru soba ($7.20): served with a dipping sauce, cold soba served on lacquered tray. Again, not the best, not the worst. It's not that great. 

3. Okonomiyaki - beef & egg ($9.80): comes with beef, squid, and vegetables. It was pretty cheesy tasting and didn't exceed my expectation. It wasn't very good. I expected a lot because this place is apparently known for their okonomiyaki's. It was my first time trying this, and it ruined my first experience... 

Overall, food isn't very good. Service is good though. Our server kept refilling our waters without us having to ask. Very friendly.
author: Esther Y.

description:
We came here for lunch on Sunday around noon with a party of four. The restaurant itself is on the smaller side, and the booths we were seated in were cozy -- probably better suited for parties of two.

The food was alright, but I don't have a strong reason to come back. I got the oyakodon, chicken and egg over rice. The dish itself was decently filling since there's a good portion of rice in there, but I felt like nothing about the dish stood out to me (flavor/texture-wise). Two of my friends got the lunch special (somewhere around 12 dollars for an appetizer and a noodle dish), and both were content and satiated. Another friend of mine, who loves okonomiyaki and is familiar with authentic okonomiyaki, got the okonomiyaki but didn't mention anything notable about it.

Come here if you're just looking for a filling meal at a reasonable price.
author: Cindy Y.

description: Super nice waitress and food was very well balanced in seasoning and taste. It was my girlfriends first trying the spicy plain udon noodle soup and she loved it. We were seated with water right away and our order came fast. You wont regret coming here.
author: Tevin Kim P.

description:
We two people ordered two bowls to go. They gave us one pair of chopsticks. 

Food: not bad. Pretty good deal for the price, especially considering the area.

The oyako don was super salty.
author: Emery Y.

description:
Absolutely unacceptable in all aspect!  All their utensils, plates and all plastic containers has mildew and molds !   I didn't even receive an apology from the people in the kitchen nor the waitress (Older lady with short hair) who was working at the time.   I walked into the kitchen and the two hispanic gentlemen blamed it on the dishwasher and ignored.  Tried to contact the owner but no response.  Health department will definitely be contacted.

On a good note the younger waitress with the tied up hair provides exceptional/great service.   She is fast and on point.
author: Kristen W.

description: Came here for the first time. Really happy with all the food we ordered, (we had ramen, deep fried octopus, and okonomiyaki), service was great, and price was so reasonable! Will come back again and it's one of my favorite spots in SF now!!
author: Kyoko U.

description: Despite having the Michelin acclaim at the storefront, Mifune Don was disappointing mediocre. In terms of SF price range, the food is priced reasonably with each entree costing around $10 or less, but that is the only good thing about this small Japanese cafe-esque restaurant. My choice of oyako don (chicken and egg rice) was okay but the ramen cannot get any more average. While this plays a good backup for the more popular sushi restaurant across from the floor, Mifune Don is not a place you should go out of your way to try.
author: Jay Y.

description:
Mifune Don notes:

Tea:
Hot, green tea, not much flavor, because of the current drought--tea is given upon request

Water:
Good water. Expected for SF

San sai udon and ikura donburi:
- Soup has strong soy flavor; clean light flavor but gets to be salty after eating it straight for awhile (but thats why you get tea or water)
- Udon has a nice chew factor
- Nice vegetables--I do not know what they are (aside from DELICIOUS)--in broth
- Thin fish cake slices
- Ikura (fish eggs) have a pleasant flavor, clearly fresh
- Rice is well seasoned and sushi vinegar is not overpowering.
- Ginger on top of Ikura. I like ginger may not be for all
- Comes with cabbage

Wakame Udon:
- Soup has strong soy flavor; clean light flavor but gets to be salty after eating it straight for awhile (but thats why you get tea or water)
- Seaweed is nice and soft (no hard pieces) and there is a lot (which is good)
- Udon has good texture; still soft but not too soft (a bit firm) that it rubs off on the chopsticks
- 2 pieces of fish cake; nice thin slices with good fish flavor
author: Alyssa L.

description:
This was one of my favorite meals while visiting SF. We were the first customers seated at 11am (they get props for opening when they do; other places in Japan town didn't open until 11:30 or later for lunch). I ordered the lunch special of chashu ramen and gyoza for $12.95. Coming from the east coast where a bowl of overly decorative ramen will cost $13+ on its own, this is a great deal.

My ramen hit the spot. It wasn't anything fancy, just your typical fish cakes, chashu, and beansprouts inside, but it's all I needed. I'd had fancy spancy ramen earlier in my SF trip, and while it was also good, it didn't satisfy me the way this ramen did. My husband ordered croquette curry despite knowing he shouldn't double carb, but he didn't regret it. The curry was slightly sweeter than he was used to, but otherwise still delicious.
author: Dani P.

description: The California Sushi Roll was very nice but the Niku Soba was below expectations otherwise would have rated it higher
author: Rajiv M.

description:
This past weekend we stayed in Japantown at Hotel Kabuki to celebrate my sig other's birthday.  The hotel is conveniently located across from the J-town restaurant/shopping plaza and this cute little place was just a stone's throw away.

We went here for lunch twice in a row because their Green Tea cold soba and beef/egg donburi was really good.  The green tea cold soba was perfect for a hot summer day as it is refreshing and simple.  The beef and egg donburi was cooked perfectly and the sauce was savory and not too salty.  

We didn't have to wait too long each time (just a few minutes to be seated) and our food came out within 10 minutes.  Would love to go back and try other items!
author: Yue L.

description:
I stopped in here for a quick bite while cruising around Japantown. Tucked away in the upper level of an indoor shopping center, it was hard to find, but easy to get a table for one once I did. 

I have to eat small meals more often now that I'm eight months pregnant, so this was perfect. I had a small house salad with a ginger and miso dressing that was very good. I also had the edamame, which was perhaps not as fresh as I had hoped, but still good. I also had a California roll. Since I can't eat raw fish right now but have really been on a sushi kick, I think I've had more Cali rolls in the last few months than I had cumulative in my life before being pregnant. The roll was very good, almost melting in your mouth. 

I would totally go back here, and I think why I couldn't give it five stars is I needed the atmosphere to be just a little bit more relaxing. I think when in Japantown, I'm trying to find more of Yasujirō Ozu, and this has all the makings of a Tokyo Story feel, but just needs softer lighting and a bit less clutter and stuff on the walls. That's just me though.
author: Julie S.

description:
Discovered this place a couple years ago and the food is always spot on. The serve you enough to feed you for two days. 

I generally get the tempura donburi with some sort of app or roll. The gyoza are thin crispy and juicy and the spicy tuna roll is tasty. 
As for the main meal I love all the veggies that come with the tempura, outside they are the perfect crunch and the inside steamed perfectly.
author: Em C.

description:
Doing my check in at Waraku, discovered i had a previous poor experience there so passed on them.

Mifune Don had rave clippings decades old posted on their corkboard in front. think the clippings refer to another Mifune located elsewhere in japantown.

pfferings: okonomiyak, ramen, udon, donburi...

eats: Modonyaki (12.80)
-savory japanese pancake stuffed with pork, cabbage, seafood, etc.
-topped by a layer of fried noodles(yakisoda, it was thin) covered with brown sauce.
-slight burning on the bottom.
-first time eating this, not wowed. food fresh, meat dry.

temaki:
-8ish booths inside, 2 tables outside
-inside some senior citizens dining, outside working guys.
-friendly service
author: Victor G.

description:
I really really want to give this place a better rating because the serving lady is nice and does this very well even though she is by herself.... But the food. It was OK. Just barely.

Had the lunch special which came out to be $12.23 with ramen and dumpling combo. It was a huge lunch but... More food doesn't always equal good. 

They made my ramen less salty per my request which was nice but the noodle was rubbery and the egg was actually cold in the middle... And my ramen wasn't hot. It was lukewarm-ish? Why :( as for their dumplings... I don't know if they buy their dumplings in which case they need to buy better ones. If they make it, they need to buy better ones... 

For the food, it would be 2 stars but the serving lady was so nice and speedy...+1 for her.
author: Sarah K.

description: My daughter and I are big fan of Mifune don for many many years. She had bee Mifune  for 20 years   Recent two visits we noticed the change. Kitsune udon today, Anita age was not pre cooked with sugar and soy source.   Tsujemono  pickled cabbage had been changed taste.  We asked if the cook had changed or changed recipe to the waitress. We love the service there, very nice waitresses, but the change of kitsune udon like that is not worth to visit Japantown.  Hopefully, they bring the perfect kitsune udon and tsukemono back!
author: Aki M.

description:
The table cooking is really good! 

I don't see much yelp photos of the dish, and I also didn't see it on the menu the last time I visited, so I assume this must be a new addition.

They give you a stone pot filled with meat, cabbage, Enokitake mushrooms, tofu, and a bunch of other ingredients, all soaked in a sweet savory deeply flavorful broth. The stone pot is then heated up in front of you in the center of the table. As you see the broth bubble and the raw beef slices being cooked, they give you a bowl of rice to go along with the awesome pot of food in front of you.

The inside is small, but very clean and well decorated, which makes it feel very cozy.  The service is great--they are really friendly, and watches every table to make sure cups of tea/water are always full. They also had great lunch special combos that let's you order multiple things (e.g. udon and curry rice) in one set, so you can try different things in one meal.

Will definitely go back again!
author: Henry L.

description:
4 stars because good service. I request to change the chicken to beef. She said yes and still gave me same price. 

The food is so so. But at least this restaurant of Mifun is better than the other two the Japan town.
author: Daisy C.

description: This place is a go to every time my family and I visit sf. The service here is very nice and the workers are all very friendly. I would recommend trying the Nabeyaki Udon, it's tastes amazing!
author: Janet T.

description: Flavorless pasty udon noodles. They should be embarrassed. To give this restaurant a longer review seems pointless but let me try. The broth was so mediocre I stopped eating after a few spoonfuls. Now I can't get the taste out of my mouth. The Tempora was serviceable. But the only good thing I can say about this place is that the service was prompt.
author: David A R.

description:
Mifune Don is located within Japan town amongst the other variety of Japanese restaurants. To be honest, my boyfriend and I chose to dine here because we were so indecisive about where we wanted to eat and it was the closest one to us when we gave up on deciding. We were seated right away, right in front of the kitchen. I did not like this at all because it became so hot. My goodness, I think this is why my experience was not as good as it would have been. 

The customer service was rather slow. I had to flag down a waitress the whole time we were there. I ordered the katsu curry, which I surprisingly enjoyed since I never had japanese curry before. The rice smothered in the curry really hit the spot and the katsu pork was basic. Nothing special. It came with a side of salad as well; however, I would have enjoyed my meal more if I was not so irritated by the heat and the waitresses. 

There is nothing more to say about this restaurant. It was not a bad experience, but it was not a good experience either. It was meh.
author: Veda T.

description: The food is good but the gyosa comes all stuck together and the ramen could use more sesame oil
author: Nathan G.

description:
Shopping around Japantown and want to find a quick and easy place that's not too crowded? Mifune Don is a good option. 

SETTING
-Small little restaurant, that doesn't have too many tables but probably enough for a handful of parties.
-Located inside Japantown, near the Ichiban store

FOOD
-They have a great lunch special if you're like me and like to have a combination of foods. You can mix and match items for about $12-$14 dollars. I got a bowl of Udon + Chirashi.
-Chirashi (lunch special) is pretty small, with a few pieces of sashimi and seaweed. Don't expect anything fancy. 
-Udon noodles (also part of the lunch special). Yummy noodles and a tasty broth. Win. 
-Mixed Okonomiyak was pretty good and I recommend getting it! They don't serve this everywhere so it's definitely worth trying it here. After they cook it and bring it to you, they still turn on table stove heater to keep it hot and crisp! Bonus points. (Nobody likes cold soggy okonomiyaki!) 

PROS
-Get seated right away + good food, what more can you ask for?
-Plating is very nice and their okonomiyaki is quality.
author: Grace J.

description: Good in a pinch I guess, had the buckwheat noodles. Place was jam packed but not sure what that means. Place used to be a lot better than it is now. maybe ramp up food quality a bit.
author: Henry K.

description: Horrible service. That's not it. Found hair and bug in the noodles. Never refill ur drink. The waitresses have poker face, never smile or saying thank you . Worst experience ever! Will never come back.
author: Sandra S.

description:
I've always wanted to dine somewhere alone and I picked today to do so. I'm glad I did. Because this was the perfect place; cozy, relatively quite and had a nice atmosphere to it (the music they were playing is very calming and I loved it.)
I rarely leave comments but this place deserves a good comment. The waitress suggested the spicy tuna and it turned out really really good. She was friendly and kept filling my tea cup. 
If you're reading this: thank you for today! I needed this.
author: Anna A.

description: The food was really good and reasonly priced. It was the first restaurant I tried at Japantown. Considering there is only one waitress, the service was really good. She did not get any orders wrong even when the whole restaurant was filled. Not only is the serving staff amazing, but the kitchen was really quick too. My friend and I did not have to wait long for our food to come out.
author: Tanya W.

description: Their noodles are amazing! I went to eat here the first time I went to Japantown and I've been going here to eat every single time I visit San Francisco. Their curry is also good and the sushi too! The people working here are really polite too!
author: Aylin G.

description:
Great find within the Japan Center.

Mifune Don offers many staple Japanese dishes. What stood out was the okonomiyaki as it's likely one of the better ones I've had in the states.
author: Tunaidi A.

description:
There aren't many places in SF where you can get a good okonomiyaki plus their soba and donburi are good too, at least by San Francisco standards. You don't get to cook your own okonomiyaki like you do in Japan, but given the sorry state of Japanese food in SF, just being able to _get_ a decent one is a win in my book. 

My go-to weekend lunch order here is a modanyaki okonomyaki and zaru soba. Delicious, plenty of food for two people and not too expensive.

This is a small place, nothing fancy or super nice, but cozy and friendly. Note this place is upstairs in the east section of the Japantown mall (toward the hotel) if you're having trouble finding it.
author: Ely L.

description:
I came here with some friends and they put us in the seating right outside the restaurant (still indoors). The tables and chairs were a bit janky - they were basically outdoor lawn chairs made of plastic.

The menu is pretty standard Japanese fare. They do have okonomiyaki here!

I opted for a kitsune udon here. The dish was a bit disappointing. The broth was a bit flat, could have used more flavor. The noodles felt slightly undercooked. Something felt off. I've definitely had better udon elsewhere.

Green tea is free!
author: Danielle C.

description: This place has not changed very much. The food is still very good. The okonomiyaki (お好み燒き) is still good. I also like their Cha Shu Pork Ramen.
author: Hiroshi K.

description: Terrible service....the gyoza's were decent and tasted fresh but the udon soups really have nothing special to them. My boyfriend and I had TERRIBLE stomachaches after it was honestly miserable. We hadn't eaten yesterday so it had to of been the food. There's better places in Japan town to eat go around the corner and find better food.
author: Geena G.

description: Modonyaki okonomiyaki!! I'm on the search for the best okonomiyaki in San Francisco, and this was my first stop.  The dish didn't disappoint.  It's not exactly like the one I had in Hiroshima, but it was close.  Though it looks small, it's actually quite filling and should be shared with another person.  I haven't tried anything else, but I'd definitely would go back and order this again.
author: Vira P.

description:
Pretty standard Japanese joint. The ramen noodles was a good consistency but the broth could have been more rich. The gyoza was not pan fried enough and wasn't very crunchy but the pancake was pretty well done.

My sister got the sukiyaki which comes in a shabu shabu style which was pretty good as well. It looks like that there isn't enough broth for the amount of ingredients in the pot but don't worry...once it starts boiling you'll notice that there is.
author: Jason W.

description: Very much enjoyed this Japanese restaurant. Rather busy; bit of a long wait (which tends to be a positive bellwether), and one of my orders came out wrong, but the waitress was quick about making things right!  This was one of the best Japanese restaurants I've been to in the past several years. Authentic renditions of noodle dishes, tonkatsu, and curry rice. Loved the green tea, too!  Will be back!
author: Rick L.

description: Horrible service. Waited to be seated for a while when the restaurant was half empty and servers were doing nothing important (talking, clean a table while plenty of table are ready to serve) Server didn't provide water. Menu was half (looks like ppl around us all have a lunch special menu but we didn't get it.) server was not nice at all. Table was dirty. The table next to us left after talked "we have waited so long"! The nabayaki udon and curry rice was good - not special but regular quality. Noodle was good.
author: Anya C.

description: This restaurant has been around for many years-and for good reason. Very good noodles, donburi, etc. at very reasonable prices. Pleasant service. Nice, but pretty basic atmosphere.
author: Jethro B.

description:
Total disappointment!  The quality of food is what I'll expect in a small town, not Japantown. One of the worse Japanese food restaurant I've been to because it's doesn't taste like Japanese food.  To be precise, can hardly find any imitation crab meat in California roll, soba noodle looks and tastes like instant ramen, and tamago is cut the thinnest I've ever seen:(  In addition, they charged us 15% tips for five people and still asked for tips in the bill, really?!! 
Will never come again!!!
author: Annie L.

description: I ordered hot soba with tempura, beef and egg udon, and beef and vegetables okonomiyaki. It was quick service, clean food, reasonably priced, atmosphere was cozy. It's nice for small group dining because tables are very small.
author: Lynn W.

description: I got the tomago egg udon which was just okay, and the chicken karaage which was horrible. The tea and service was great.
author: Jacqui C.

description: Since my favorite restaurant in the area was closed on the day that we were in Japantown, we decided to give this place a try since it had the shortest wait (which was still a long time). Although it was very busy that day, our food was brought to us a little while after we ordered. The portion sizes for the meals were pretty good also. Our food and our service was great, so I have no real complaints. I'd like to try this place out when it isn't busy.
author: Paulamertha A.

description:
I didn't go for the shabu or okonomiyaki, so my experience is probably not representative of most. I was looking for a small snack and stopped by for some rolls and gyoza. They were ok, but nothing to write home about (both positive or negative). It was close to closing time and service was a tad slow. 

I'll be back at some point and try something they are better known for so I can give a better review of the food.
author: James S.

description: Mifune Don does it right. I'm very particular about my soba and udon noodles and there's are the best I can find. The soups are soothing and perfectly flavored. The Tenzaru soba dipping sauce is better then anywhere else's, and their tempura I find to be just right, on the lighter side, not overly fried like many other restaurants. Everyone who works there is very kind and it's just a fun and cozy place to go on a rainy day or weekend for excellent comfort food.
author: Lina H.

description:
So far so good. Good place to stop when you're tired and hungry.  Friendly waitress... And this place is clean.  Like it.  I let you know if the food is good.   To Be Continued...

Ok... Rock Star status.  Great place!
author: Kristina W.

description:
I've been wanting to try Mifune Don Restaurant in Japantown's East Mall.  Lunch specials served until 5pm Daily!  Sweet!

FREE hot green tea

Choice a noodle dish & then add another dish for $10.95 or $12.25.  Huge amount of food for cheap.

I got Zaru Soba- just cold soba w/ dipping sauce & some green onions, tiny container of cut lettuce, wasabi.  For my 2nd dish I got Curry Rice - just curry sauce, white rice, & some red pickles.  I dumped the cold soba into the curry sauce to make it tasty & added some of the dipping sauce to it.  I liked it.

Total $10.95 + tax .93 = $11.88 before tip.  Charged it.

Bathrooms: Out in the mall area, not in the restaurant.

My pic:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KiQuvELzKiHx5qg3RWaoxg?select=FXUAlqXjKD-mg__4rIxKXA
author: Ann L.

description:
Fabulous  Japanese  Cuisine.  Love their  donburi. Ramen dishes and table cooking  menu are superb.
The waitresses  are knowledgeable, professionals and great workers.
Very popular restaurant  among Japantown loyal customers  !
author: Adrian S.

description: Great deal for lunch. Ramen or Udon and a choice of Chirashi, Unagi Don, or Salmon Roe Don for $13. The food came out fast a flavorful. The restaurant is not very big but is clean and has some tables in the mall area. Mifune is located upstairs in the not so heavy traffic area of the Peace Plaza. Plus they validate parking.
author: George F.

description:
Pros:
- toppings (my bowl came with a lot of meat!)
- friendly waitstaff
- quick service

Cons:
- broth (I prefer mine to be more more creamy and fatty)
- noodles were decent (also a "pro" I guess...)

Bottom line: Decent bowl of ramen in Japantown. This is a good place if you're craving a quick dose of ramen.
author: Jiann M.

description: It's a little hard to find, but well worth the effort. If you're looking for Japanese comfort food liked okonomiyaki, look no further.
author: V. L.

description: Ordered the lunch special there, which was great! Udon was awesome, the best one that I have ever tried. Unagi don was so so but still good. Worth every penny. Highly recommend!
author: Kiki K.

description:
Stay away from their green tea simmered rice! What a rip off! It was just rice soaked in green tea.. I thought it was rice cooked with green tea instead of water so the green tea would soak into the taste. But nope, it was just green tea drowning rice.. There was barely any green tea flavor too..

Other dishes I tried were the zaru cha soba and a squid roll.  The soba was okay, again not enough green tea flavor. The texture was almost similar to spaghetti. The squid roll had a crab meat or crab salad at the bottom. I'm not that big of a fan of raw seafood so the texture of the raw squid was a little weird for me. I'll just stick to my salmon and tuna from now on..
author: Virginia Y.

description:
Came here because I've never had okonomiyaki and heard from fellow yelpers that this was the place to go. I'm not so sure if this place has the best okonomiyaki or it is just always like that, but it was cool... though not as tasty as I'd imagine... so can't particularly say much about that... (we had the mixed okonomiyaki fyi)

The rest of the food: 4/5 - We had the lunch special and chose the chirasu ramen and the unagi don. The ramen was nothing special... average... the meat to noodle ratio could be better imo. But their unagi don... man their unagi was surprisingly delicious! It looks like 2 small pieces on top of heaps of rice in a bowl, but it was more than enough when you actually start on the dish :)

Cost: 4/5 - no complaints here. 

Service: 3.5/5 - one waitress to serve the lot which is fine because it is such a small place. She wasn't the happiest person to be serving us, but she was attentive and got our food to our table as quickly as it came out.

Ambience: 4/5 - place is tinyyyy, but you do get your own table and privacy compared to other small japanese places where they cram you in where you can. It's not too noisy, but you can hear the radio playing from the kitchen haha.
author: Monika-Bianca T.

description: OK for lunch, They offer luck specials for $13.95 (combination) of 2 items. I ordered the chicken teriyaki and gyoza, wife ordered the California roll and Ramen miso soup. Both orders were OK, they did not serve with rice though, But the Asahi beer was ice cold, just the way I love it. Japantown Peace Plaza has several Japanese restaurant to chose from. Service is OK but I don't think the waitresses are Japanese, more like Chinese ladies, nice enough though.
author: Dirk D.

description:
I went during the cherry blossom festival, and it was busy. It generally is better busy. The bowls of ramen are huge. I love their tonkatsu. Their sushi options is limited. Overall quality is better good. 

The only thing from giving them a fourth star from me is that they cleaning of the tables could be better. I found ramen on my seat.
author: Nick N.

description:
I visited Japantown for the first time yesterday, and ended up here for lunch. There was a line but we were seated fairly quickly because there was only two of us. The problem was, after we've seated, the waitresses have all but forgotten about us. Two waitresses came to the nearby table to give other patrons their checks and taking their trays, but no one even glanced in our direction. Also no one brought us tea, and after 20 min I had to go find a waitress to come to our table. When I found one, she glared at me as if she was greatly bothered. 
The food was also mediocre. My Nabeyaki Udon was extremely salty even though it looked tasty. My friend's ramen was a bit better but not exceptional.
Quite a disappointing lunch because I was looking forward to trying Japantown's noodles, but at least the ramen is okay.
author: Dahlia S.

description:
My friends and I can very hungry after not having had anything for 7 hours and came in hoping for some rich, authentic Japanese food (preferably great ramen), but surely this place did not deliver.

One of them ordered some rice bowl (donbuki?) with beef and some special sauce. Great combination of flavors, but I wouldn't be able to consume an entire bowl.

My other friend ordered the ramen. She had no comment on it, for it neither good nor was it bad. She said it tasted a bit bland and the ramen noodle were a bit lumpy and moist (as though they had been sitting out for a long time).

And sure enough my udon noodles were too. I like my noodle in noodlesoups a bit on the harder side, but I can definetly take noodle in the middle. Theirs were too moist, were not fresh at all, and felt like they were on the brink of falling apart. It was disgusting. The soup flavor was worse than bland. It tasted like a bunch of days-old soups mixed together. The udon I make it with those fast and easy packets at home taste 30x better than this bowl tasted.
Even the fake crab meat slices did not taste fresh!


Horrible, horrible place. The only great thing was our waiter. She was so sweet and kind, but other than that- this place is repulsive.
No wonder we were their only customers at 5:30 on what should normally be a busy Friday night.
author: Sharon C.

description: I come here every few weeks just for the okonomiyaki! It's the most authentic I have had in SF- served super hot in a cast iron skillet with the fish flakes moving and a little spatula to scoop the yumminess onto your plate! Service is always great and super fast. Not sure about the rest of the menu because okonomiyaki is all I get there.
author: Elaine Tiffany P.

description:
I just discovered this place on my last trip to SF. And it was so good that I had to come back for another round even though I had very limited time to eat at all my favorite places. 

The service here is really great, especially for a hole in the wall restaurant. They immediately bring you out hot tea and cool water and they're very willing to help you with the menu. I also slightly altered what I ordered both times and they were totally cool with that both times.

The first time I went my friends and I sat for a relatively long period of time and we were never hassled by the servers. Both of them had ramen (one seafood, the other pork I believe). I tried both and the broth was phenomenal! (That's actually what I had to come back for the second time). It was the most flavorful, power punching, delicious ramen broth I've ever had. Also, none of us got MSG headaches or other side effects after eating there so I think they might actually be making that stuff without it! Which is mind-blowing if you think about it and what's normally served at these kinds of places. 

So the first time I went I got the okonomiyaki and it was fabulous! I asked for no mayo (cause I hate the stuff) and it came out right the first time. It was hot and tasty and I loved how the bonito flakes on the top almost seemed to 'dance' because of the heat. It was so tasty I had to  fight my friend off of my meal with the tiny spatula they give you.

The second time I went I got their special ramen (shrimp and pork I believe) and it was also amazingly tasty. The bowls and portions are huge and they do not skimp on the meat. I had three or four huge slabs of pork and at least six large shrimp in that bowl. The shrimp were perfectly cooked too which is amazing since they were sitting in hot broth. They must really know how to time their cooking!

I think part of the reason why I like this place is because it doesn't pretend to be anything it's not. It serves good food, where the focus is the food and not anything else. The presentations might not always look gorgeous like they might in other restaurants, but the flavor is there. And it feels like real comfort food.

So go check it out!
author: Cori N.

description:
Came here and ordered a chashu ramen while my girlfriend got an okonomiyaki. The chashu ramen has authentic noodles but the soup is bland and the "chashu" is not chashu it's just pork. You can easily find better places than this to get good ramen in SF.

The okonomiyaki on the other hand was wonderful. It tasted very authentic and even bests many of the places I went to in Tokyo. They even add noodles and bonito flakes on top. That it did not come with a side of red ginger is perhaps my only complaint. The pan also looks small, but it is deceptively filling.

Come here for the okonomiyaki, not the ramen.
author: Shin I.

description: Tempura is delicious as well as tonkatsu donburi & chasu pork ramen. However I do not recommend the udon noodle soup...had a weird smell & taste to it
author: Georgia R.

description:
I'd prefer coming here during lunch over dinner. I like the combinations they offer on the lunch menu. and also, you don't really have to wait for a table. 

the first time I ordered the beef udon with califonia roll combo. that was good, but a bit in the greasy side. the second time I ordered the chirashi soba. you can taste the freshness of the tuna and salmon. and I've realized... I'm not too much of a soba person.
author: Ann T.

description: Great service. Small portioning and very very very long wait to gt the food ready. Took 30min just for okonomiyaki. Smh. Never ever again.
author: Oem Fän A.

description:
Craving okonomiyaki so checked out this place since based on the pix and reviews on yelp it seemed like the best option in Japantown.  In addition to japanese pizza this place has donburi's, sushi's, and ramen.  

Ended up trying the seafood okonomiyaki and the beef and egg okonomiyaki, mixed yakisoba and eel donburi.  

Okonomiyaki - prepared very well here, came out nice and hot.  Seafood  had nice big chunks of octopus.  As for the beef and egg, we enjoyed how rich and flavorful the beef was.  Each were prepared with the nice special sauce sauce, mayo, and the thin fish flakes.

Mixed yakisoba was on par.  included pork, octopus, and other types of fish. 

Eel don - taste also on par.  they give you 3 pretty large pieces of eel with plenty of Japanese style rice on the bottom.  

Overall our clear favorites were the okonomiyaki and we would definitely come back whenever we are craving Japanese pizza.  too bad they didn't have takoyaki here...

There's so many food options inside of Jtown from sushi to ramen...but if you want to experience Okonomiyaki this place is worth a try!
author: John P.

description: I come here almost every time I stop by japan town! I love the okonomiyaki and ramen here especially. It's also pretty inexpensive! :D
author: Abby N.

description:
I came here on Valentine's day with my boyfriend because we wanted to try Okonomiyaki and because we didn't feel like walking very far away from Japantown. The restaurant doesn't have much seating and is relatively small so we had to wait a little before we were seated but that's okay because there were a few stores nearby to wander around in. 

The waitress was super super attentive. We ordered two okonomiyaki dishes, I think it was the mixed one and the one with soba noodles in it, along with an order of spicy tuna rolls and the waitress said it would take 15 to 20 minutes for our food to come out. Usually that is a ridiculous amount of time to wait for food, but it's nice that she told us instead of having us wonder what happened. During the time that we were waiting, she proceeded to fill up our tea every 5 minutes and gave us water. It was nice because I'm pretty sure I drank at least $10 worth of tea. 

The spicy tuna rolls were okay, not fantastic but not bad either. 
The okonomiyaki we had were a little salty but pretty good overall. If you've never had it before, the sauce on it kind of tastes similar to the sauce they put on eggs benedict.
author: Tiffany T.

description: I really enjoyed the Udon here, as well as the Kimchi I ordered on the side. It surprisingly tastes better than what I've had in NY. Service was not necessarily the quickest, but absolutely the most attentive and caring.
author: Patrick M.

description:
I had what they call cold soba but is actually cold Udon with gyoza. And oh god how disappointed I was. 

I am in SF for tourism and I heard they have a Japanese town so I went to check it out.

Japanese food is one of my favorites and I was just back from Tokyo so I wanted to have a taste of Japan again.

The gyoza tasted like burn and the udon was uneatable. It made me sad.

How come a Japanese restaurant is handled by Latinos? They were really nice and the service was great but they don't know how to speak Japanese or anything about the culture. Ok you don't need to know as much to cook but at least cook it right!
author: Sharon R.

description:
This place is pretty good and they are open later than most restaurants in Japan town on Sundays. 
One time I got the lunch special with chirashi and it was pretty good, though the rice had a gasoline flavor. The fish seemed averagely fresh.
The ramen was way better--spicy comes with chashu and seafood huge portion but a lot of it was cabbage. 
The service is very friendly and the dishes come out fast so that's nice !
author: Cynthia G.

description: We have been coming here for lunch specials since I don't know when. It's a nice little corner restaurant inside Japantown mall. The service is always great and food hasn't been that great. The lunch special is always a good deal, it usually comes with a main dish (ramen, soba, etc.) and then a side dish (rice, gyoza, sushi, etc.). As of late, the quality of food has not taste the same as before and the price jumped as well.
author: Elaine C.

description: The modernyaki is delicious and makes me wish it wasn't so expensive to go get some Hiroshima style okonomiyaki. Haven't found one so far in the U.S. The Osaka style is really good but there is something about the layers in the Hiroshima style that makes me remember the ones I ate while I was still little in Japan. Mifune Don is the closest I've found so far. Benihana used to do it for a lunch special a long time ago but even then it just didn't seem quite the same. Anyhow, if you want to try a Japanese "pizza" this is a good place to try.
author: tomohisa w.

description:
Good Japanese food for the area! Love the shoyu chasiu ramen here. Sometimes I come here for the lunch special and I always get the shoyu chasiu ramen with a side entree. They give you so much for what you pay for! The bowl with the ramen is huge.

Not a big fan of their udon here... definitely prefer the ramen. Miso ramen is too salty for me so I always opt for the shoyu. The ramen comes with veggies, half of a boiled egg, and chasiu. So delicious!

The only problem is whenever I come here I always get attacked by like 5 fruit flies while I'm eating lunch. Can't imagine this restaurant as a perfect place for a date if you're constantly trying to shoo away flies.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Service was good. Not great, but good and I don't blame them because there was only one server and one chef working. Yes, it was on a Monday night which is probably not a good time to expect great food, but food quality should always be consistent no matter what day it is.

Ordered a regular Cali roll and rainbow roll. Boyfriend ordered katsu curry. The curry tasted nothing like Japanese curry and the sushi tasted nothing like sushi. There was way too much rice and the rice itself lacked the rice vinegar flavor altogether.

Fun fact: "sushi" means rice with vinegar, not raw fish. That is why you can have vegetarian sushi.

Anyway, this place lacked completely in terms of the quality of food. I feel bad for leaving a negative review, but maybe it will help improve the business somehow?
author: Christina Y.

description: The okonomiyaki is good here, and the Koshihikari Echigo Beer is too. The yakisoba is a little greasy though. But I think yakisoba is supposed to be greasy. And the okonomiyaki is listed under table cooking on their menu, but it came to us on a plate.
author: Audrey A.

description:
The lunch combo is great. I had a bowl of niku soba and the chicken and egg donburi. The meal was very filling. There is a good amount of meat in the dishes. 

Service was a little slow but it seemed very busy at the time. The wait could be long if you have a large party since they don't have many big tables.
author: Alexander L.

description:
This place hits the spot. Are you going to come out super impressed with any of the food, service, or atmosphere? Nope. But are you going to have any major complaints? Nope. 

We got the Niku Soba lunch special with Ikura don(this is the best value BTW as the zaru soba and ramen are cheaper standalone) and the Beef Nabe.
