Soba was decent texture, enough so you feel something (the worst soba is when it falls apart in you mouth). Soup was a bit salty and the beef was pretty overcooked, but that's what you should come for: no surprises. This is average in a good way. 

Ikura don was pretty bare bones, wasn't the freshest Ikura ever, but for a non-sushi joint I'm not expecting much. 

Beef nabe came out properly done in a metal pot, they have electric hot plates built into the indoor tables to heat it up. Soup had minimal flavor, but for real Japanese style nabe/shabu that's how it should be. The konjac noodles were good but I wish they had a dipping sauce besides ponzu. Oh well. 

Overall this is pretty standard Japanese fare. I'm probably not coming bake regularly because it's a bit pricey for what it is. But next time I'm hankering for soba Mifune Don will be on the list.
author: Eugene H.

description: The first time I came to San Francisco I made sure to try every type of food in each district. I went to the Japanese town center and tried this restaurants okonomiyaki. It was amazing, the savory flavors really work well to bring out the seafood taste. I have not seen a restaurant in SoCal that sells okonomiyaki so I definitely recommend people to visit and try
author: Kimberly F.

description:
I was so upset at this restaurants waitress and policy I didn't even bother to eat here. PLEASE READ!!

My brother was visiting from out of town last night so my cousin and I decided to take him out to dinner. My brother wanted to get ramen and the cousin and I wanted shabu, we figured japantown would be the best way to satisfy everyone.

The waitress seemed a bit hesitant to seat us, like she was closing soon or something but it was only 7:30.

When we got to Mifune we were excited because IT CLEARLY says right on the menu "all you can eat shabu, minimum 2 orders" we thought, crap this is perfect! We can get shabu and my brother can get his ramen.

The waitress was quick to ruin our good mood. She informed us that everyone in the party must be eating shabu for all you can eat. What...?

I told her that he wanted ramen and we still had the minimum of (2) people to eat.

She was very adamant on us not eating shabu.

We went back and forth for a couple minutes and then I said ok, we don't know him, well put him on a separate check and then slid our table 2inches away from him. It's like we're our own party now.

She smiled and said "No, you can't do that".

I asked her "so, because we brought more business into your restaurant, and have 3 people instead of just 2... We're not allowed to eat shabu?"

"Yes"

"So if my cousin and I came here by ourselves... And didn't bring the extra person we would have gotten the all you can eat special"?

"Yes" she responded 

Ok well I then informed her we would be leaving and that she has a terrible business model and I promised a yelp review to warn others about our plight.

DONT EAT HERE! They don't want your business and they sure as hell don't want you to bring your family from out of town.
author: Aaron A.

description:
You must get the Beef and Egg Okonomiyaki--pretty good for it not being cooked in front of you in Hiroshima. If you don't know, Okonomiyaki is like a Japanese pancake. A picture next to the table said that it would be cooked in front of you, but it wasn't in my case. I didn't care though since I was in a hurry. For a complete Okonomiyaki experience though, it must be cooked in your face on a flat stove used as a countertop and it's slid to you so you eat it on that same stovetop.

Service was good and I like how they let us in a little before 11:00AM when it opened.
This place has been here forever so I'm happy I finally got to try it.
author: Marlon T.

description: Ordered a chicken katsu curry to go, quite a large portion, good enough to fill me up and more.
author: Henry W.

description:
Yuck! what happened??This place used to have awesome ramen 6 years ago.  i used to come here with my friends occasionally just to have a bowl at lunch in the summers.  

Sansai Udon
- tasted like sugar and seasoning instead of real broth.  my teeth felt way nasty afterwards.  the noodles were not fresh and i had a sour aftertaste which was not appealing

Seafood Ramen
-  tasted like some chinese herbal soup, it was TERRIBLE, maybe they poured too much of that canned bamboo shoots water into the broth.  the broth was certainly not as hearty and the noodles were not as chewy as they once were.  

Cali Rolls
- pretty decent.  except for the old and oxidized stringy avocado, it was alright

Tekka don 
- probably the best part of the meal, the sashimi was properly thawed and the rice had minced green onion on it.

Service was non-existent.  at least they did not treat us poorly. 

a generous 2 stars for this horrible place
author: Tina A.

description:
Last days of spring break and my son suggested trying something new in Jtown. 
His idea of something new is a restaurant we had not tried. I tried to explain that there's a reason for it...but decided to let go of the contol with hopes of being surprised. 
Promptly and pleasantly greeted. Waitress efficient,  friendly and welcoming.
The okonomiyaki was small, oily, nothing like the plastic one in the window. Curry katsu was dry, thin, blistered open like a flat calamari ring. I've never seen this before. Oil on crust tasted old. I tried to eat the salad instead but the poor dressing allowed 2 bites. I dug for clean salad leaves underneath and dipped it in the curry. I tried to find something to est. A small gush of water in my mouth from the small cluster of leaves. Not drained well....and when.
I had stomach trouble... 2 times... I'm  convjnced it was the salad because we sampled each other's orders, except the salad.

I had wished that the food would match the pretty plastic samples at the window. 
Last time here for us and our dishes cost more than the other better prepared restaurants in the mall.
Floors dirty. How much csn it cost  to have this small  cleaned?
author: jane f.

description: My friends and I ate at this Japanese restaurant and we were beyond impressed. I got the hot and spicy ramen and it was so good, the noodles were perfect and the broth was spicy and flavorful: I definitely recommend it! However, I do suggest that they get more employees, because one women had to run the whole restaurant, I believe; but she did a great job. I definitely recommend this if you're in the area!
author: Saz M.

description: Pretty tasty ramen and curry katsu.  Would definitely recommend these dishes. The cold soba wasn't something we were pleased with and the fried scallops were too breaded. As for service, it was pretty slow but pleasant. It was Saturday night and they only had one server...that's probably not the servers fault. Solid restaurant worth visiting for the curry and ramen!
author: G M.

description: Spicy Ramen was really great I was electrified by the taste and even though there was only a few of us we still managed to finish the whole thing and one more because it was so amazing. The lady that helped us was awesome and she made sure we were doing okay. Overall I would visit this restaurant again and advise others to go here as well.
author: Chris Y.

description: I came to try the okonomiyaki while I was walking through the Japan Center, since I don't frequently find that as a menu option in restaurants back home. The okonomiyaki came to the table with hefty toppings of bonito flakes, kewpie mayo, and the mysterious brown sauce and green flakes. The pancake itself was thick, filling, and crumbled very pleasantly between my chopsticks. They give complimentary green tea which is a nice touch, but it was bland and eventually I just wanted water.
author: Soonwook H.

description: Unagi over rice looked and tasted good. Sukiyaki with udon looked good. My tempera was gummy and not crispy but ok.
author: Kami J.

description:
This could become my go-to Okonomiyake place.

IF! They go easy on that hoisen sauce and mayo on the okonomiyake.

Ambience:
+Hole in the wall defined.
+Radio station playing in the background with lots of commercials, could really do without

Service:
+To the point, no frills or extra chatter here
+Pick what you want and go with it

Food
+Seaweed salad- standard fare
+Veggie Okonomiyaki- my husband liked it
+Seafood Okonomiyaki- its kind of a hodgepodge of seafood, with no clarity on what exactly goes into each bite; too much mayo and hoisen sauce though

Looking forward to trying the sister restaurant

-Hungry Hungry Pongy
author: Sangita A.

description:
I came in during an off-hour - around 3.30. This is a very small, casual restaurant. I had vegetable ramen (not on the menu) with added chicken. The food came out quickly. It hit the spot on a drizzly day after working up an appetite shopping at Ichiban Kan, which is located on the same floor. 

Service was incredibly friendly and impressively attentive. The hostess/waitress did not make me feel stupid at all for my embarrassingly inadequate knowledge of Japanese cuisine. Her English was not great, but she was able to answer all of my questions, and even help puzzle out the right dish for me at that moment. 

Also sensitive to dietary/lifestyle restrictions. I don't care for pork or red meat. After answering my questions, she was quick to point out that the ramen is cooked in a pork/miso broth. It's little things like this that make even the most casual dining experience enjoyable for me. It was obvious that both she and the cook take pride in their work. She made sure my cup of green tea remained full, he had his eye on my water glass the entire time. I felt thoroughly taken care of in this small spot.
author: Stacie S.

description:
I came here to accompany my hungry hubs (had just eaten my heart out at dimsum a couple hours earlier with my parents) and hadn't planned on anything but tea.

Since it was late for lunch, 4 of us were promptly seated & poured hot tea - bonus, were still in time for the lunch special. Their lunch specials are huge and can easily be split amongst 2 people. 

The four of us tried the Nikku Soba and Ramen specials with chirashi and nikku don sides. Everything was served relatively quickly. The Nikku Don was perfectly flavored and salted, the broth was light and refreshing. I had a second 'taste' and wasn't even hungry - it was that good! My hubs loved his ramen which I tried, but found it too heavy for my liking at the moment. Everything else was perfect and we left wanting to come back the next day! 

Will definitely be back.
author: Jade D.

description: Everythink is great here we've tried the Ramen, Teriyaki and breaded chicken its all perfect each time. Super friendly we go for an early lunch we have never had to wait more than 1 minute to get seated.
author: Rubi G.

description: I was not really pleased with this place. I don't know if the hype was too much and I was let down or if I just got a bad day but...yuck! I got the unagi Don and it was horrible. The unagi was gelatinous and luke warm, the rice was mushy was watery, the gyoza was gross, and although the tea was nice and warm it was over steeped. My husband got the katsu curry don which was a step up from mine but suffice it to say, I don't think we will go there again. I did give two starts for the wait staff, she was very nice.
author: Deanndra C.

description: Waitress was pleasant. Food took a long time to come out. I ordered the tempura shrimp udon and it was not good. The noodles smelled like a very dirty and fishy beach and tasted about the same. The shrimp was ok but somewhat bland. Wouldn't go again.
author: Jamie A.

description: I give this place one star only because of good noodles from the past. Now they close the kitchen before closing the restaurant. They close at 8 and say they close the kitchen at 7:30. How do they stay in business?
author: Rodney L.

description:
Most of the restaurants in Japantown serve mainly ramen and other types of noodles such as udon and soba. I wanted to go to a place where they had okonomiyaki since I've only had them at Kitchen Kura & its pretty hard to beat their pancakes. 

My family and I tried out this place on a Sunday afternoon. There was no wait so we decided to sit at one of their tables outside the restaurant since the inside looked a little claustrophobic. 

I got the beef okonomiyaki while my uncle ordered ramen as well as udon. I'm not sure how they did their meat for the ramen but it had a smoky flavor that he absolutely loved since it was so different from what he was used to. I tried it and I agreed it was delicious. 

The udon was good too and the broth was intensely flavored. The okonomiyaki was definitely not disappointing. I still prefer Kitchen Kura's but this was almost just as good! Very big serving and everything tastes fresh. Definitely will come back.
author: Cathy N.

description:
I like their sushi rolls at Mifune Don.  We decided to have a late lunch here.  I always order Agedashi Tofu as an appetizer at any Japanese restaurant I go to.  I find that their Agedashi Tofu has an aftertaste....I guess it is because it is garnished with raw minced ginger on top, instead of thinly sliced scallions & bonito flakes.  The raw ginger gives it a pungent, raw taste.  It is very traditional & authentic.  The chicken skewers are tender & tasty.  My husband I love the Spicy Tuna from the presentation to the overall taste & texture.  The Spicy Tuna Roll was also very good.  We love the way Mifune Don makes the Dragon Roll....not so greasy from the fried seafood...very simple, elegant & tasty.

The server was very friendly and the service was quick & efficient.
author: Cynthia F.

description:
This is my first time trying shabu shabu ever so it was pretty exciting for me! I thought it was pretty good but I still think it's very similar to hotpot and I think I like the Chinese hotpot more because the soup base has more flavor. I didn't taste very much difference in the meat or veggies between shabu shabu and regular hotpots. 

The shabu shabu was $20 and it was a lot of food already. You can get the $25 all you can eat option, but I honestly think the $20 option is sufficient. 

I like the Japanese theme decor at this place. You get more privacy with the dividers between every couple of tables. 


I would totally come back to try other items at this place! Everything tasted super good with great portions!
author: Amiee H.

description:
I stopped here for a quick lunch.  We were starving and desperate to eat, so we came here since it looked good with all the sample items featured.

It can get a bit busy which means service may be slower.  No problem with that since it's understandable.  There are some interesting items and the lunch specials are pretty decent.  The problem is, however, the food isn't the tastiest - at least what we ordered for the time of length we waited.  

I ordered the ramen and gyoza lunch which was the best out of everyone else's food. Not bad ... 

The chicken donburi and the hiyashichuka (cold noodles) definitely could not be finished.  

If it's your first time eating here and you aren't familiar with what they do best, it might be wise to ask.  I wish I had known what they are best at before making my choices.
author: Mary B.

description:
OKONOMIYAKI GA DAISUKI!

4 stars for the Okonomiyaki!
- Delicious. Just like how Okonomiyaki is supposed to taste. Big portion! Just a LITTLE too soft. Otherwise, totemo oishikatta! 

2.5 stars for the service.
- SLOW, SLOW, SLOW service. There was only one server working on the evening I went in. The lady was polite, but omg, it just took forever. 

3 stars for the price.
- about $10 for the Okonomiyaki. About right.. nothing to complain about but nothing to brag about either.
author: Mari S.

description:
While I'm not sure you can still call it a food court when the majority of the mall is comprised of restaurants, the food at Mifune Don is as one would expect of Asian food courts - good, solid food, but nothing spectacular. There are two Mifunes, with this being the smaller (and possibly cheaper) of the two, serving up some good lunch specials - start with a noodle dish and add a rice dish for a total of $10.95, or add another small side to all this for $1.30 more.

Forgetting that I don't eat as much as I used to, I ordered a niku soba and curry rice combo, and was slightly surprised (and troubled) at how ample the serving sizes were, as the two dishes could have easily made for two meals. The curry was simple, but tasty, while the niku soba was also good, albeit a bit oily, with noodles that became soggy a bit too quickly (which is perhaps just the way buckwheat noodles are). Overall, not something that you should make your way out for, but a solid choice if you're in the area and hungry.
author: Johnny W.

description: I'd accidentally taken friends to a Japanese x Italian restaurant with a really similar name. But I was trying to find this place because I'd read about the okonomiyaki. I found my way here the other day and had a good lunch of chicken okonomiyaki (not on the menu). It's a cozy space, with a few tables equipped to cook food right in front of you. The artwork is pleasant, and the music is great. The "Friends" theme song played. You know I'll be back.
author: Dan B.

description: Really glad we tried this place out.  I was going to give 4.5, but that's not an option and also like to help boost the rating of this restaurant.  We decided to pick a restaurant close to our hotel because we were tired and cold.  Found this restaurant on yelp, but skeptical because of its reviews.  I ordered the sweet savory beef shabu shabu and my sister ordered Chicken and egg Donburi.  Both were great.  We don't understand why the ratings were this low.  Service was great too.  Fast and friendly.  Came back two more times to try out other dishes and all of them are great!
author: Lin Z.

description: This place was an average Japanese restaurant but it had some good okonomiyaki, which sometimes is hard to come by. I got a bowl of ramen which could of used some more meat for the amount I paid but it was good all around and had quick service.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Being one of the less crowded spots around japan town, Mifune Don has surprisingly good food quality, value and service. 
While their ramen is nothing extraordinary compared to some places around, it is quite simply--in a literal sense--good. Broth, noodle, meat, they got the basic elements down all to a satisfactory level. Same goes for their don. 
What truly prompts the five stars is their service. I've regular-ed the place for a good two month now, and every single visit the waiters there just seem happy and welcoming. Consistently getting comfortable dining experience and walking away with a better mood is simply the best thing I would expect from a restaurant. So far so good.
author: Yang C.

description: One of our favorite restaurant at Japantown. The place is really small, but the food are good.  I like the ramen & udon soup. The servers are attentive. The price are reasonable. 4****
author: Larry A.

description:
This is a decent find in SF's Japantown. I got the katsu don which was packed with pork and rice. My friend got a bunch of different things on the menu including some rolls and edamame.

The plum sake sounded good but I decided to get crepes instead. Service was good and the interior of this place is pretty nice. I'll be back if I'm in the area.
author: Amy J.

description: This is our go-to place when we go to Japantown. It's the best okonomiyai in the city. Employees are very friendly and there's almost never a wait.
author: E V.

description: This is my sister-in-law's go-to Japanese restaurant in Japantown, so since we were in the area, we tried it out. We had a group of 10, so we had to split into 2 booths. I had never been before, and I went with the Sukiyaki nabe and the Gunkan spicy tuna. My nabe was a little salty, but extremely filling. Tuna tasted very fresh, but wasn't really spicy. Service was excellent though. Although our waitress was very matter of fact, she was extremely patient in explaining the dishes and dealing with our 2 toddlers. We also ordered a train of food for the kids, and they were nice enough to give us 2 train trays so that the kids wouldn't get jealous of one another. Very cute. Decent food for a decent price.
author: Veronica C.

description:
I wouldn't say this place is horrible nor awesome! But it's decent enough for you to go in again and try other things.

I've tried their lunch special for nearly $13.00. It had chashu ramen and a side of gyoza. I feel that their soup base can be better but again it's decent enough for you to go again and eat it. I really liked their gyoza because it tasted fresh like they wrapped it when you order it.

Service is great, the waitress is really nice. She's their all by herself and able to manage with great service.

I'd come back here again.
author: Annie H.

description: Extremely not excellent. Bland soup, stingey on the meat, just slightly better than store bought ramen noodles. Horrible room temperature control. UGH.
author: Snuffles B.

description:
MUFUNE DON is known for it's DON (rice plates), SOBA & UDON (noodles). It is not sushi focused though it does have some items on the menu.  

This place has the perfect TEMPURA VEGGIE SOBA...Absolutely HUGE portions at an incredible price ($9.80). The tempura is perfect, never greasy nor limpy. (The piece of tempura onion is heaven.)

Service is a little off at times due to the fact that the place is always busy and the waitstaff are constantly running around. They probably are wiped out! (Someone on YELP made a rude comment that no Japanese go here. That is so incorrect! I have been coming to MUFUNE for over 30 years and they have a diverse & loyal customer base !!!)

One can order and get out fast if necessary though it is important to tell the server. (MUFUNE is great for dining fast during the San Francisco International Film Festival) 

There are many booths (for 2 & some for 4) where one can feel that they are eating in private.
author: Addadada A.

description:
I've stopped here for a quick bite a few times after a session at the Kabuki spa. This is definitely not the best ramen around. The chasui pork was a weird spammy texture and the fish cake tasted like it had been sitting around for a while. The ramen broth also tasted "off"--very salty but otherwise flavorless.

This place seems to have reduced the quality of its food and service, and is resting on the laurels of good reviews past.

I'm going to give it a miss from here on out.
author: Marina C.

description:
The first thing that hit me when I walked into the restaurant is the overwhelming smell of dishwasher soap. The smell really hits you like a heavy weigh boxer's right arm; however, after a while, you'll get used to it.

I ordered the chicken katsu curry and I didn't really like it. The curry has this weird sweet taste to it, which is really different from any sweet curry. It was a bit creamy yet a bit watery at the same time. The chicken katsu was fried nicely and tasted great. It was crispy on the outside and still moist on the inside. I didn't like the taste of the curry in the end and couldn't eat it.
author: Steven B.

description: Average bowl of udon. Tempura's on the oily side. No wait on the weekend though, so that's a plus! Really, nothing to write home about. We really just came here because we were hungry and Ramen Underground wasn't open yet.
author: Kathy L.

description: If you're not coming here for the okonomiyaki, you're missing out. Definitely the best okonomiyaki in San Franicsco! The waitstaff are friendly, the prices are reasonably, and unlike its sister shop on the other side of Japantown, Mifune Don is quiet and peaceful.
author: Kevin L.

description:
It's been a long time since I last ate here, but here it still stands, which says something, I think. This is probably the best place for noodles in this restaurant mall portion of Japantown. They have a killer lunch special of your choice of udon or soba and a side dish for $11. The side selection includes nigiri, tekka don, unagi donburi, curry, and more. The curry here is pretty good and not too mild or runny, I'd say. The potato croquettes were so, so good. The inside was nice and warm while the outside was beautifully flaky with panko and the oil they used was fresh and not overused. I'd come back for the okonomiyaki.

The service is slow. You'll be qeued up at the door, get seated quickly, but your order won't be taken for a while. The food will come out in a reasonable amount of time, but don't be afraid to raise your hand for the check. The layout is maze-like with large personal booths.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
When you order the hot & spicy ramen, you'd expect the ramen to be hot or spicy...or both.  It wasn't either.  Their ramen is advertised as handmade noodles, but I didn't find them any better than any other ramen restaurant.  They also forgot to put the shrimp in my ramen.  It probably didn't help that we sat there for a good half an hour plus before our food came out.  

We also ordered the potato pancakes appetizer...it came out after we finished our ramen.  It was delicious, but we were already full at that point.

I wouldn't return for the ramen anymore, however, I did see the table next to me order Okonomiyaki and if I'm in the area, I might stop by to try that.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Tuna sashimi was frozen, filled with tendon, had a weird texture, and one of the crappiest I've ever had in my mouth.   

Chasu ramen lacked flavor.  

Seafood nabe was ok.

The best was the tempura appetizer.
author: JBean C.

description:
One of the few places in SF that offers Okonomiyaki.  All their 4 seat-tables have a built-in heat source in the middle of the table for Okonomiyaki ($8.20) and hot pot dishes like nira pork moyashi ($8.00).  Sadly, okonomiyaki is cooked in the kitchen and brought out as a finished product on an iron skillet.  Heat source is there only to keep the skillet warm while you eat.  Seafood Okonomiyaki was pretty good, although I wasn't a big fan of the sauce they used.  I like the sauce to be a bit sweeter, but that is matter of preference.  Their Okonomiyaki selection is pretty good with Modern-Yaki (includes yakisoba noodles) as one of the options.

RAMEN:  I was bit confused by their ramen.  Their soup and toppings is more like a champon (cream colored broth with lots of seafood and hakusai vegetables), but their noodle (men) was regular ramen style (not thick and straight like regular champon).  It wasn't terrible, but this confusing blend wasn't a good match.  Overall, it was o.k., but not great.   

Other than Okonomiyaki, I was not impressed with rest of their food.  Their oyako-don was average to poor.  Their lunch special of $9.80 for a choice of noodle and another item (see picture) is a pretty good deal.  I would give this place 2 Stars, but due to their Okonomiyaki availability, I give it 3.
author: トモ T.

description:
This is my go-to place in Japantown.  I don't even know how many times I've eaten here.  Whether if its before a movie at the Kabuki or just out shopping, 99% of the time I come here to eat.  And I don't even know how I haven't written a review of this place yet!

The food is pretty good, especially for the price you're paying.  It's cheap but tasty.  I am particularly fond of their udon especially.

So why 3 stars?  Well the service blows, lets be honest.  Don't come here if you're in a super rush.  The wait staff is slow and good luck ever getting that water you asked for.  But despite this more often than not, it's pretty packed, sometimes with a pretty long line waiting to be seated.  So be warned, if you come and it's busy you'll be hot!  When it's full it's like a sauna in there.
author: Jen K.

description: There is very very bad service！I will never come here again！There have a fat and glasses girl has very bad service、
author: Ivan H.

description: Finally! a decent place for okonomiyaki! I've been to too many bad okonomiyaki places in SF. Mifune Don was the only place that even resembles an authentic okonomiyaki from Tokyo. I took a peak in the back and a Latin American was the chef. Boy, can he cook. What a great chef!
author: Jeff H.

description:
I was in the nearby area so my family and I decided to go to Jtown and grab lunch. We also wanted to shop so stopped by here since there were both restaurants and stores. We initially wanted sushi, but it was the peak lunch hour and tons of people post holiday and out on school break. So we accidentally stopped by here thinking they had both soup and sushi.  

Then I got tricked by the reviews!

UGGHHHH! I shoulda kept yelping to find more places. What was I thinking?! We were in Jtown, there probably was a good sushi place a couple feet away that I missed =(

First- this place is way too small. The tables are not roomy what so ever and you can barely walk from your table to the bathroom without bumping into someone or having to do a little shuffle dance in the walkway with another customer or waiter.

Second- The service was extremely slow. It took at least 15 minutes til they took our order. I had to actually raise my hand to get someone's attention. Perhaps, they were understaffed or the crowd was just overwhelming? I guess, but I don't feel that's an excuse. A good restaurant will be prepared and know how to balance this all out! 

Third- I ordered the Tori Toji. Noodles with chicken and egg. I was anticipating this since it was cold out, and who wouldn't want warm soup on a day like that?! Honestly, it was just BLAH. It didn't thrill me what so ever. I might as well of had a cup of noodles or made a pack of ramen at home. My overall rating on this place, EH, wouldn't think twice about coming back here...
author: Remy-Anne V.

description:
So Yelpers I lost my virginity at Mifune Don.
My okonomiyaki virginity that is.
Last night I had my first one -- it is a sort of pancakey omelette type thing that contains cabbage and other stuff, in my case seafood. It was topped by what I think were bonito flakes and a decorative design done in mayonnaise. It was all a bit too fishy, squishy  and mayonnaisey for me though.
Anyway the service was very lovely, and the waiter was very nice and prompt and kept my green tea filled up at all times. Dinner was $11 including tax and tip.
I will probably go back to Mifune Don.
But I think I have enjoyed my last okonomiyaki.
author: Lisa T.

description: We went to Japantown for the first time in January and were really hungry when we arrived. Ended up last minute to just go in here. It's a small place, but it's comfortable.  The server was very friendly. The three of us each ordered the niku udon, to have something to hold us over on our walk to Chinatown. We didn't think it would really hold is over. I ended up drinking five cups of the green tea. It was soooo good! The niku udon was really good and I didn't expect it to fill me up the way it did. It wasn't a disgusted full, it was satisfaction. Not only that, I wasn't even hungry for another five hours, which is an eternity when it comes to me being hungry. All three of us had the same effect. I can't wait to go back.
author: Anitra B.

description:
Service is good. First thing they give you is a cup of hot tea and the menu. The environment is very nice and it's a great place to talk. There are also stands between each booth so there's privacy! 

The food is fairly cheap. There is a lunch hour menu where you can pick a type of noodles + 8 piece california roll or other side orders = $10.95

I think this is a great place over all.
author: Kelly H.

description:
I just want to WORSHIP whoever thought of mixing avocado, rice, pork, and sriracha sauce together. It's DELICIOUS! When I first got this, it came in this fatty bowl and my first thought was 'hm, this is interesting.' I've never been the type to try crazy food mixes, let alone any food mixes. Like ketchup and eggs (although I heard that was good??). Not to say that everything was mushed together - that would be a sight - but each part was in its separate section on top of the rice (please refer to picture). 

The meal came with miso soup. Pretty darn good miso soup too since it had more stuff in it than just leaves. It had veggies and such. Well worth it! But I traded my boyfriend for his salad since his salad looked pretty yummy too (bad idea). Anyway, I can't emphasize enough how much I liked this idea for the rice bowl. HOWEVER, as unique as it may have been to me, I'm sure it's quite popular around Japanese restaurants. Those who read this and have seen that combo for centuries now, please be understanding :) I have yet to try this at other restaurants - eee I can't wait!

Bf got the curry chicken. He said he's tasted better. But then again it's curry - it's all the same to me!

Service was okay. It wasn't superb but it also wasn't bad. The pricing was average as well. If I can't find the same dish elsewhere, I'm for sure coming back!
author: Cindy S.

description: Dirty plates weren't clean and the food was cold ... I don't know if they use frozen food to cook with. Not worth coming here. Try other places in japantown!
author: Anna D.

description:
Woo I love their Sansai Udon!! You should try it if you like vegetable udon!
I had dinner with my dad after a long flight. It was SOoo good!
author: C L.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend, determined to get okonomiyaki. 

We were not disappointed!

We ordered:
- kimchi ramen
-beef curry
- beef okonomiyaki

I can't remember if we ordered takoyaki (or if this place has it), but if we did, I'm sure it was good.

Now, the pickled sides were NOT GOOD. I liked them more over at the Mifune over at the other side of Japantown (not sure if they are related). Tasted really really odd and not really vinegary... more like briney. I don't like that kind of taste, since it's not refreshing.

I don't know what the ramen tasted like, but my boyfriend said that it wasn't anything really special, but it was good. 

My beef curry was delicious. I think it's as good as Over The Bridge, but I wish I had more beef and some tomatoes. I have no complaints about the beef curry.

Now, the star of the show was the okonomiyaki. This was actually my first time eating this dish, and it did not disappoint! I was so sad that I had my beef curry, because the first bite made me regret eating anything else!

All I gained from this experience is that I should get straight to the point and order the okonomiyaki instead of spoiling my appetite with beef curry. 

Now, the service was so-so. Waitress is a tad inattentive, but she's nice. Service was also a little slow for a restaurant that wasn't busy, but perhaps we were too hungry to be patient. I'll let that one slide.
author: Hayne P.

description: I really liked the selection of food!  Anything with bonito flakes always makes me smile.  I had the tempura, tako balls, and ramen soup.  My server was extremely sweet.  Hope to find a chance to visit again if I ever travel back to CA.
author: Hana A.

description: Delicious and fresh. The nigiri sake was melt in your mouth delish. And the combination ramen was so yummy. Definitely recommend this place. No real crab for the Cali roll which is always disappointing but otherwise, it's delish!
author: Jeannette L.

description: The food was a turn on but the service was a turn off. I went with my boyfriend and his brother and when we came in and got seated the waitress gave us the menus and walked away. Besides that, she seemed to pay attention to all the customers...but our table. They weren't even busy! There were only 6 people in the whole place and they were already eating! My boyfriend also had to call the waitress over multiple times to ask for refills on our water. Our food on the other hand was very yummy...but my mood went sour when we didn't tip. We already exited the store and one girl came out running saying, "You have to tip, most our customers tip 15%-30%!" I felt like they didnt deserve a tip for the service we got. A tip that high should be for a person who works hard and is attentive to the customer...but I gave them their tip...even though they 100% didn't deserve it.
author: Lorraine W.

description:
This place serves SALTY and Americanized version of Japanese cuisine, so it's not the appropriate restaurant to seek authentic Japanese food. 

Went in for a lunch with party of 4.  Tried various items on the menu from lunch specials, rolls, cold noodle, and hot noodles... The soup base were SALTY and had no taste. The cold soba noodle was warm! and not cool and refreshing.  The restaurant inside was hot and humid.
author: Sam P.

description: I came in super hopeful for the okonomiyaki because ive been craving it 4 a while and havent found a place. I was utterly disappointed when i tasted the modanyaki, maybe i'll come back 2 try the others. Maybe it will be better.
author: Jenny N.

description:
I've brought a number of people here before and have shown them the awesomeness of okonomiyaki. A couple of weeks ago I brought a different friend expecting to show her the way like so many others and yet... it just didn't happen. The second to the last time I was here was the Cherry Blossom festival so I don't know if this was just an off day for them or if the food has truly declined. I'll give them the benefit of the doubt though and opt for the former. 

First of all, the okonomiyaki didn't taste delicious like it normally does. It wasn't bad... but it wasn't good either. The texture was a bit off too. 

The sushi is a definite pass. The tamago was medicore, the spicy tuna roll and california roll were only slightly better, but considering all the other sushi places in Japantown it isn't worth it to buy any here. 

My friend's katsudon with a fried egg was good.
author: G C.

description:
After being disappointed with a sushi joint in Japantown, I was still craving some udon, so we ended up having a second dinner.  =X.  We ended up at Mifune Don restaurant and oh my goodness.  The disappointment of this dinner!  

I had an udon and the husband had a ramen.  It's pretty much mall food.  For a restaurant that's in Japantown, I expected so much more!  

I definitely would not go there unless for some reason I was in desperate need of food and I happened to be stuck in Japantown.
author: Susan C.

description:
Came here for lunch with the moms.

Place was recommended by a chef friend and he said they have the best okonomiyaki in the city - right up there with the places in Japan.  
Tried it and I thought it was alright, only because I just like Okonomiyaki, and not in love with it, it was just cool. Not a Okonomiyaki aficionado

On the flip side, they have other good and cheap dishes... like the mini dons, ramen, etc., which I will need to come back to try.  

I like this place more than the other Mifune because it's smaller, more intimate and cozy.  Service is more attentive as they are not overwhelmed like the other place.  

Side note: There were only three other people in the restaurant and I thought it was bizarre I ran into a college friend here I haven't seen in at least 6 years.  What a small city SF is.
author: Debbie N.

description: Great,simple food and service. You won't find fancy sushi rolls and upscale ambience, but if you want good, reasonably priced sushi you're in the right place. As a side note, we didn't try the udon or table dining but people around us seemed to enjoy.
author: Chelsea H.

description: Mifune Don is super cute and super delicious. The kitsune udon was awesome and I loved the sweetened deep-fried tofu skin. SO BOMB! My boyfriend and I tried the modanyaki okonomiyaki (pork, seafood, and veggie pancake) and this was tasty as well. It was like this egg and noodle omelette with various meats. There was dried, shredded squid as topping. It was such an interesting mix of ingredients. The service was attentive and not too overbearing. I think the pricing is pretty reasonable for the amount and quality of food you're getting.
author: Judy H.

description: Worst service ever, waited at least 25 minutes before they took our order or brought us water. Food was incredibly subpar, probably a 2/5. Don't get the soba or udon, it's not authentic whatsoever and the flavor is bland.
author: Victoria G.

description:
I'm sitting across from my buddy and we are both commenting on his experience.  Here's the north seat version. 
The Katsu Curry's skin was crisp and melting nicely under the curry. Portions are large (both cutlet and rice). So much so that am appetizer can remain silent. But us two gluttons decided to prep our buds with the Kushi Katsu (which is a meal in itself). My main hesitation rests with the service. The waitress took 15 minutes to recognize that we were sorted and ready to order. 
All in all, lunch was highly functional. Not spectacular but serviceable. Yes, I would return.
author: Abe I.

description:
I've been to Mifune before and in the past it was OK, but today's meal was kind of a disappointment. 

I was drawn to their lunch special menu and the rice in green tea dish caught my eye. It just looked and sounded so yummy! Also, I was craving soba and I've had it here before and it was pretty good, so that pretty much sealed the deal.

I ordered the zaru cha soba (green tea), but the waitress said they ran out!! I also asked her about the green tea rice dish and she said the only one they had available was the plum one... :T
SO I ended up with the regular zaru soba and the plum green tea rice.

That's when things went downhill.

1) I guess the waitress misunderstood me and she had given me the zaru soba meal, which included tempura. That wouldn't have been an issue, except the meal is more expensive than just the soba by itself -_-
2) My plum green tea rice was forgotten. My friends and I had to remind our waitress.
3) The actual green tea rice dish was bad. I guess that's what I get for trying something new? It was literally rice in green tea. With some nori sprinklings and rice cracker bits. With 2 plums on top.

I'm going to blame miscommunication and myself for being swept up in the idea of green tea AND rice for the less than stellar experience.
I'll probably go back to try some other dishes because I'm hoping that today was just an "off" day and things will improve.
author: Kei H.

description:
Slurp slurp!  Oodles & oodles of noodles!  I love noodles! My buddy & I had no idea where to go for dinner the other night, and continued driving on El Camino til we hit San Bruno & decided on going to J-Town.  I thought that sounded like a good plan since it was freezing & a hot bowl of udon & some sushi sounded appetizing.  

He got the cold soba noodles & I got a bowl of beef udon.  We shared an order of California roll.  The California roll didn't have much flavor to it, but had lots of pop due to the tobiko.  I liked the broth of my udon even though it was a little salty.  Plenty of noodles cooked perfectly and thin slices of beef with some fat.  Service was okay, but then again there was only one waitress for the couple of other tables and a fairly big sized (for this small restaurant) birthday dinner party.  Food was reasonably priced too.  Maybe I'd return if I was feeling like some udon & was already in J-Town; this was one of the few restaurants without a wait too at 8 on a Friday night.  2.5 ish but I'll round up...oh Yelp I wish you had half stars!
author: Cat C.

description: One of the best Okonomiyaki places in the City. We have been coming for years and it has kept the quality up. Always great service and good food. Five stars to counteract the low ballers :)
author: Ben R.

description:
Great place for a snack!

I ordered the okonomiyaki and the cold potato soba -

The okonomiyaki was fantastic! It did take a while to cook, but it was definitely worth the wait! They serve it to you on this little griddle in the middle of the table, which keeps it warm while you eat. And it's pretty tasty too!

The cold potato soba, on the other hand, wasn't so great. It was really bland, and the soba sauce tasted like water. The potato was really mushy and too sticky, which gave a weird texture. Combined with the bland taste, I just couldn't find it appetizing.

My friend ordered sushi, and he felt like it was okay, but not anything special. We've definitely had better, but this place is worth a look, especially if you're craving okonomiyaki.
author: Michael T.

description:
I'm surprised this place only has 3.5 stars! Based on the reviews, I think this is one of those establishments where you have to order the right thing. So far, I've really enjoyed both the service and the food. I've been coming here for years and it's usually my go-to whenever I have a craving for udon. 

Ok, so the udon here is really simple. Udon noodles, soup, meat, and fish cake. However, I personally enjoy a more basic udon over "fancy" udon with all the bells and whistles. I love how simplistic the udon is and it's really rather tasty! My favorite is the Niku Udon (beef). They used to have an amazing lunch special where you could pair any udon with a side of croquette or oyako-don for only 11 bucks! Both of which are very good! The croquettes are pretty much a no fail, you can't go wrong with deep fried mashed potatoes. The oyako-don, which is chicken, eggs, onions, and a special sauce over rice, is also super yummy! However, I was really sad to see that this lunch special pairing is now gone :( They still have a lunch special but it's a dollar more and you can't pair your udon with either of these. However, you can still order croquettes and oyako-don, it's on their menu, but it's not a part of the lunch special anymore. These days, I usually just pair my udon with a side of curry or a california roll. The curry here is actually quite good, so I would recommend that as well.
author: Christine B.

description: Nothing amazing (nor even truly authentic Japanese) about this place at all. It's the typical average and declining Japantown Peace Plaza kind of noodle restaurant. It truly saddens me, because I care about the future of Japantown and because I love Japanese food and culture. But restaurants in this historic mall are going downhill, with maybe one exception
author: Raymond F.

description: Yesterday I went to Mifune and had shabu shabu for my friend's birthday. The most annoying thing was when I got the bill and there was already a auto tip of 15% on there. It was just 2 of us! What the hell Mifune? I actually liked you guys for your non shabu stuff and I have never been charged an autotip before. I definitely will not be returning again. You lost me as a customer permanently.
author: Linh V.

description:
[M]ona: 3.5 Stars
[W]ayne: 4.5 Stars
Average: 4 Stars

+ Big portions
+ Decent prices
+ Lunch Special

- [M] Bad California Rolls :( 

[W] This is a nice place to have a quiet lunch. It's a little hole in the wall in the Japanese mall. The meal that I always get is the lunch special where you can choose 2 items from their set menu.

I ordered the Ramen and the Oyako Donburi while my GF had the Udon and Curry Bowl. Also when you go, don't forget about the California rolls! They come in large portions and are just simply delicious. Sometimes its so good that I have to have a second order of it. If you're a gyoza lover, I have to say those aren't too shabby neither. I normally don't eat gyoza myself but Mifune's gyozas will definitely help you change your mind.

[W] The owner that works there is really nice and efficient. There's nothing to complain about this place other than.......I can't eat anymore because everything is so good!

Another thing about this place is their tea. I haven't had a better tea than this place. It's always fresh and doesn't taste watered down like if you were to go to a typical Asian restaurant where they just keep adding hot water to the pot.
author: Mona C.

description:
The beef curry is still one of the best I've had.  They use sliced fatty beef rather than lean beef chunks.

I was super disappointed in their gyoza though.  I haven't eaten here in 4+ years and I remember the gyoza used to be fresh and delish.  However, when we ordered it, it tasted old and stale--as if it'd been sitting in the back of the freezer for a while.  I also noticed they serve it for cheap with their lunch combos and that might have been what compromised the quality of their gyozas.

Oh well, service is still great and the curry is what I really come here for.  Will be back soon!
author: Ivy Z.

description:
There is something about katsu donburi that is just so comforting! After a long work week, I met up with good friends and decided to check off "eating in Japantown" off my SF to-do list, as I was sorta jipped out of it the last time I visited. I wanted to eat in Japantown, probably just for the novelty of it, bc as I'm told, it's not the best place to find Japanese cuisine. REALLY? I found that hard to believe. But okay, I'll take it from the locals. 

We came to Mifune since it was still open by 9:30pm and it wasn't going to break the bank. Service was only okay, the hostess showed us to our table which was missing a chair. We also weren't given any napkins/chopsticks initially and had to ask for them after our appetizers came out. I guess they were ready to close but that still shouldn't stop them from providing us the necessary services that would allow us to eat! I also never got a refill on my tea and was pretty thirsty, but my miso soup helped i guess. 

I certainly enjoyed my katsu donburi, and I think at least one other in my party enjoyed their katsu curry. The other two both had ramen, but not sure what their take on their dishes were. I would say Mifune is average at best but good for when you're craving some Japanese flavors and don't want to spend too much.
author: Jenny C.

description:
This is your typical Japanese restaurant in the Bay. 

Nothing all that spectacular about it. 

The place is really small, so don't be surprised if you have to wait up to 30 minutes on a busy night. 

The food wasn't bad. The tempura was crisp. The sushi ok. The salmon was seasoned just right and not too dry. The green tea, HOT! 

The only downside to this place is if you go on a busy night, the staff will do EVERYTHING in their power to get you and your party the hell out of their restaurant. 

Also, be sure to use the restroom BEFORE you come here. 

Mifune Don does not have its own restroom, so that means you will have to use the mall restroom just outside the restaurant... And if your a lady-you won't be happy. lol

Also, do not fall for the Mifune Don outdoor seating... Their outdoor seating consists of a pair of picnic tables located outside the restaurant in the mall... :(
author: Black K.

description:
So I went over to Mifune Don a little over this weekend and ordered Okonomiyaki... after watching obsessively how they prepare the okonomiyaki (osaka style) this and Genki make it Kansai style because there are NO places that make it in front of you so be warned. 

What to expect / what did I get:

- Mixed okonomiyaki w/ egg and yakisoba ( I think it had the pork also)
- glass of Asahi

Now for everybody that knows... the only way to enjoy this treat is with a beer. You can be alone eating this as a snack and be happy. You can also enjoy it right after having a long hard search of what to eat at the end of the day. I prefer to get this tasty meal with a beer. Now, okonomiyaki as seen on youtube:

 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q3S73BmUFUk&NR=1&feature=endscreen

This is how osaka prepares as to where kansai type or more localized does the already mixed type. The batter is supposedly made with a special taro / sticky root paste to give the batter its texture. Normally teppan usually prepare it in front of you so you also get to talk to him/her while your food is being prepared. From what alot of them do they usually do alot with shellfish, oysters, shrimps and squid. Normally its always topped with that japanese style bacon they add a bit of batter then they flip it. After a while they prepare an egg and soba to put on top.then top it with okonomiyaki sauce and kewpie mayo, nori flake and agedama. 

So... I kinda wanted mine prepared similar to the one that I seen on youtube.. but theirs looks alot bigger than the one that I have. it makes mine look like a normal pancake or loosely similar to paejun from a korean restaurant minus all the added stuff like sauces, egg and soba. Tbh, I would have made a great teppan for this type of stuff. 

Order time took no less than 20 mins but I was there for over an hour by myself doing other.Waitress was fast and poured me tea about 3 times :O The place is nice but a bit small. its not bad really and its in the Kintetsu part of the mall if you go to Japantown (the same side that they have the bargain store/market). The waitress was nice and at least better than the one that   sat me  over in Genki Ramen. Now as for the dish itself.... it did taste a bit better than the one that I had over in Genki since it had the yakisoba and the egg topped with it this time. It was a mix of kansai / osaka but more visually pleasing. To be honest I would come back here again if I am not so decisive about making dinner decisions. Then again... I always am D: 

Good to eat bit by bit with a chug of your beer!!  

Its too bad that they don't stay out longer than the posted time otherwise it would be a great late night spot to have a beer and snack. I recommend this to anybody that is a paejun or okonomiyaki eater or haven't tried it with a topped egg or yakisoba. having it with yakisoba and egg is a MUST-HAVE another thing that I would have is had kimchi with it... its as spicy as it gets when you add korean condiments to japanese dishes. :3

Have a great eat guys and good hunting!!
author: Xeirhen V.

description:
The one thing I learned from coming here is to trust yelp. if the place has 3 or below this place probably isn't good. 
The second thing I learned is if you see that half the people at an asian restaurant are white... the place probably sucks. 

Lessons that I will never fully learn. but I came here this past weekend to get some good japanese thinking that in order to survive in japan town the food must be authentic and must be delicious. To my dismay, it was neither the soba unagi was mediocre at best.. I think i would compare it to the level of.... tung kee noodle

Not one of the people in my group thought this was above average... MAYBE a 3 at best... dragon roll was "the worst he's ever tried"
author: James H.

description: The restaurant boasts of hand-made noodles, but you know what - hand-made noodles don't mean anything if the rest of the ingredients end up giving the noodles a weird flavor. I ordered the nabeyaki-udon which is a favorite of mine to order to test out a noodle restaurant. Broth was overly strong and the ingredients cooked too long in the nabe which made the udon noodles BROWN and mushy. The tempura shrimp (actually panko coated) was cooked in old oil, or was frozen and flash fried - I couldn't tell except that it wasn't fresh. The kamaboko was sliced too thinly for such a hearty dish - you could almost see through it, and because of the strong broth, took on the flavor of the broth and so the essence of the kamaboko was lost. All in all, 2-stars.
author: Dirk J.

description: There's no other okonomiyaki place in SF that I know of apart from this one; I came across the name of this place in my fav food blog www.lemonsymphony.com when looking for a good japanese pizza place in this area. Located strategically in the famous japantown although this place looks like a hole in the wall and may be a little difficult to be located at first, the food is superb. The okonomiyakis are really good and authentic; would've given them 5 stars if they used a little less cabbage on the toppings though; too much cabbage makes the pizzas a little soggy at times.
author: Kay C.

description: Price is OK, food is sub-par, I rather go to Takara for soba or bentos.  Also, Mifune on the 1st floor is better.
author: Ryan Y.

description: Our go to place when we are in Japan town...so convenient because it's inside the mall (Japan Center).  The price of their food is very affordable and the udon that I usually order is good. I like their spicy tuna too!!  They have their specials like any other places in this mall..The service is awesome.
author: Jing F.

description: We ordered two ebi nigiri along with other food. Food was okay until my first bite of ebi nigiri tasted a little sour. So I asked one of the server if the shrimp is suppose to be sour. The server told me ebi is sour as if I dont know how it is suppose to taste. I just thought that its their specialty and finished the first ebi nigiri. As I was eating my second pair, I realized that the first one has gone bad. Yeah. They served me rotten food. Dont eat here. I could clearly tell that they were reusing food. all our nigiri rice were not staying together nor attached properly with broken salmon cuts. It was a terrible christmas experience.
author: Jason C.

description: The service was soooooo slow. I even debated leaving the restaurant because I was starving and this place was taking forever. The food was not good when it arrived. I got the lunch combo with ramen and unagi. Fiancee got the okonomiyaki. Ramen was bland, but the unagi was tasty. Okonomiyaki was ehhhh....definitely not worth the wait.
author: A L.

description:
Nabeyaki udon for $11 with tax/tip = Happiness. Went here before heading to the Fillmore on a Monday night. It was unsurprisingly not crowded (double negative what?) and offered the usual. Good n decent tasting Japanese comfort food.

Slooowww service each and every time I go here. But still, I like. I always regret not getting the potato croquettes. Dangit, must order more often. They are delish here.
author: Sarah W.

description:
This place was a definitely a waste of my time and money. My friend and I were hungry so we settled for this place since we were in that side of the mall already. We ordered to go, and both of us were unsatisfied with our dishes. She ordered some sushi and they tasted plain and were overpriced. I ordered some egg with rice / fried rice dish and it tasted like something someone who don't even know how to cook made. 

Definitely NEVER going to this place again.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Chicken Katsu at Mifune Don actually is not bad. Mildness of curry sauce is just right.
Quick serve.
author: Hiroshi U.

description:
Had dinner here on our last day in SF. First of all very good service! We had a $25 All you can eat beef shabu shabu, worth the money with unlimited beef and veggie. The shabu shabu pan (well, more like a basket with paper line) is so neat on electric stove top. Good lean quality beef with soyu flavored soup to dip the beef and veggie, much better compare to plain water than used to be my favorite shabu shabu place that I usually went in LA Little Tokyo with comparable price with additional price for every extra beef or veggie.
Overall very good food and nice service!!
author: Vick A.

description:
I came to Japantown for the first time yesterday and we decided to have lunch at this little restaurant. There are two Mifune restaurants in Japantown, and the atmosphere between the two is very different. The one I went to was much smaller and quaint.

I ordered the $10.95 lunch special. You get to choose among a selection of entrees and I got the Tori Udon (chicken) and the California roll. We were served green tea, which was piping hot! Never did we have to ask for refills on tea. The food was pretty good. I've never had a bowl of udon that I didn't like, so I wasn't disappointed. :)

It's a perfect place for lunch and it filled me up! I appreciated how our waitress split the bill for our table, even though it got a little confusing... but she did it. However, if you're looking for strictly sushi, this isn't the place for you (unless you want sashimi). But if you're hungry for actual entree dishes, then I'd recommend this place.
author: Theresa T.

description:
MiFune Don was so cute! Little place for lots of food. The waitress was so nice to us! Boyfriend and I ordered some food together. We ordered the udon, nigiri sushi, seaweed salad and gyoza. 

Seaweed Salad - You can't go wrong with it! Great starter for lunch.

Udon - Udon noodles were so yummy! The chicken had that "chicken smell" to it, but I'm really particular about how my meat smells.

Nigiri Sushi - $6 for 5 pieces! Not that great of fish, but I wasn't complaining. The unagi was pretty good too.

Gyoza -  Your basic yummy appetizer, and very tasty at that.

Sake - $6 for one glass, chilled

Sapporo Beer - $5

Bill totalled to about $35. Not bad at all. I really wanted to try the okonomiyaki as I have heard it is very tasty, but I had no space in my stomach! I would definitely come back here again as the service was impeccable and the food was delish!
author: Tisha G.

description:
I went there yesterday, I decided to try the lunch special. I had the kitsune udon and a side. Sadly the udon was quite salty, I think it might depend on who cooks it. It was an older gentleman who made it...or maybe I'll just stick to okonomiyaki. 
Service was A+++ though!!
author: Olivia O.

description:
The Teriyaki Chicken ramen is the best. Very filling, HUGE bowls. I really liked the atmosphere and the feel of the restaurant. My girlfriend and I were seated promptly, and about 4-5 minutes later we were asked if we were ready to order. I can't get over how large the portions for the Ramen were.

I guess since I don't order soup very often, it was a bit of a shock to me. Very flavorful, very yummy. I'm getting hungry just thinking about it right now. They kinda lag a bit with the check though... But other than that, really good place to eat.
author: Jay A.

description: Good food, service and prices.  Love the Beef Curry Noodles.
author: Adelio F.

description:
Been here twice and I always leave as a satisfied customer. The service is on-point and friendly and the food is pretty good. I had ramen my first time and then an okonomiyaki. The ramen was plentiful - I had to force myself to eat every last spoonful. As for the okonomiyaki, it was my first time trying one so I can't vouch for how good it tasted. 

Overall, a nice place to drop by and grab a bowl of noodles whenever I crave for some.
author: Emily M.

description:
Had me some delicious donburi here! I got the Tanin donburi, which is beef and egg. Yum yum! Can't beat Japanese comfort food. I freaking love donburi. The boyfriend had okonomiyaki, which was also pretty good. A little to saucy for me, but that's how okonomiyaki normally is.

This is a pretty small place, so don't show up here with more than 4 people. Best for couples, I think.

The service was very timid, but good. Girl, you in America now! Don't be afraid to ask us if we want the check! ;)

I'll be back!
author: Rachel H.

description:
As somebody who used to live in Osaka, I'm always on the hunt for good okonomiyaki. I've been terribly disappointed by the few places I've been able to find in the Bay Area, with the exception of Izumi-Ya in SF Japantown; but they happened to be closed when I was in the city yesterday. So at the recommendation of a bunch of Yelpers, I tried Mifune Don. To be honest, I hadn't expected to like the food as much as I did, since I'd read Mifune Don specialized in Hiroshima-style okonomiyaki. But I ordered the mix yaki, and it was terrific - outside of Japan, it's the best I've had with the exception of Izumi-Ya and Okonomiyaki Chibo in Honolulu (which is amazing, if you ever have the opportunity).

The only reason this is a four-star review is that the service was truly atrocious. There was only one server for maybe 9 tables, and it was lunch time, so I was inclined to give her a break. But I had to ask for EVERYTHING - a menu, chopsticks, a napkin, the check - and usually more than once. I figured things would get better once the place cleared out, but they didn't, so I'm thinking it wasn't just a case of somebody overwhelmed by the lunch rush as much as it was somebody who just doesn't know how to wait on table. I'd thought about even giving them fewer than 4 stars based on the service, but the food is too good; I'm definitely going back to try the modern yaki. 

Izumi-Ya will remain my go-to place in J-town - I actually used to teach English in Izumi City, and I have a hunch the folks who run Izumi-Ya come from the same town, which is why I like their food so much. But Mifune-Don is a close contender. My only quibble with the mix yaki was that the pork was a bit tough and lacked flavor; usually when okonomiyaki's made with pork, it's pork belly or bacon, and I specifically chose the mix yaki as opposed to seafood-only because I thought the buta-niku would add some flava. Not so. 

One other thing to know: there are at least 3 places in the Japantown complex named Mifune, including this place, a bigger place in the Kintetsu building and a cafe on Post St. This place is on the second floor of the Miyako building, between the Peace Plaza and the Hotel Kabuki. Itadakimasu!
author: Peter D.

description:
I came here with a friend. We usually eat at the Mifune Restaurant (also in Japantown), but we decided to come to Mifune Don instead. The restaurant is very small and pretty quiet. There weren't many people inside, and we did not have to wait at all to get a seat. The waitress serving us was very kind and friendly. She refilled our tea and everything.

I ordered a lunch special kitsune udon with unagi. When the food came out, the first thing I noticed was the portion. The portion of udon was smaller than at the Mifune Restaurant, but also seemed more appropriate for a lunch outing. The next thing I noticed was the taste. I felt like the taste of the broth was considerably more bland than at the restaurant. I like broth with more taste. It wasn't horrible, but I had to add quiet a lot of salt and chili powder to get the kick that I like. 

Overall, I thought this place was decent. I would come here again if the Mifune Restaurant is too crowded.
author: Marjorie M.

description:
Ok, went during lunch time and the place had a slight crowd. I got the Ramen and Oyako Don. My daughter got the Ramen, California Rolls and Rainbow roll. The Ramen was very tasty with a great broth. The Oyako Don was very flavorful and I would definitely go back for it. The California Roll and Rainbow roll needs work. I would only suggest you go there for Ramen and find your sushi else where. 

I would give it 3.5 stars if I could. During the lunch hour they only had 1 waitress on staff which wasn't enough to handle the crowd that was there. They cook kept coming out the back to talk to his girlfriend. Not a good idea when you have people waiting.
author: Ayana K.

description:
Tempura Donburi was just okay. A nice-sized portion but kind of greasy. There is no  brown rice option. 

I'd give the food 3 stars except for the cleanliness factor...

The booth we sat in smell bad-musty is the best I could hope for but I think it was something else-and OMG, the bathroom was FILTHY. I'm talking gas station on a back road kinda bad. That always makes me wonder about the kitchen's cleanliness.
author: Marie L.

description:
Had the Chicken Ball Ramen, was super yummy!!  

Was craving some comfort food since i'm getting over a cold.  This totally hit the spot!!  I will definitely be back if i'm craving some noodle soup.
author: Alexandria P.

description: One word: okonomiyaki. The first time I ever had it was here, and I was really amused by the whole smorgasbord of ingredients and the mini spatula with the dish. Fast forward a couple of months to a quick trip to Japan and more okonomiyaki eaten, and I still think very fondly of my first one at this place. Best one I've had was in Hiroshima, JP but seeing as how I can't go there all that often, I'm glad this place is around to satisfy future cravings. The other dishes like udon are fine, but nothing spectacular.
author: Allie Y.

description:
You have a Mifune and you also have a Mifune Don. Got it? Good! 
The latter is solid, reliable, and tasty since the smaller Mifune is actually better than the big one! Considering how many years we have lived upstairs from this place when we are in SF I can't believe I have not reviewed it until now! 

MD has always been dependable for their $5 take-outs and also for quick, clean, and refreshing dining in! Their $10.50 lunch specials are awesome. You can get hot or cold noodles along another entrée that will fill you up and send you on your way. I really like their soba and udon noodles, along with their piping hot ramen. The sashimi is fresh, as is their tempura. Mifune Don does not claim to be authentic gourmet Japanese cuisine, supreme caliber sushi, or perfect hand made noodles. For that you have Takara, Ino Sushi, and Maki close by. I mean, watchagonnathink from a place that has plastic chairs outside?  Stop here for an easy lunch that will not drain your wallet! You can even fill up on a way decent cook-it-yourself hot pot dinner and some sake for under $20!

I do have to give major props for the server at MD. She fluently speaks Japanese, Chinese, and English and seems to work 7 days a week! She has always been super pleasant, if not shy, and doesn't "lose it" even with some of the rudest customers! 

Mifune Don is also a place to bookmark when you need to grab something to eat and every thing else is closed in J-Town. They are one of the few restaurants that have been open on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Years!
author: Richard T.

description: Tried the chashu ramen, so can't comment on anything else. This is one of the worst ramen I am taken in the Bay Area. Soup is tasteless and chashu is so dry. Never ever stepping in here for a ramen again. Compare to those good ramen such as Kotetsu and Santuoka in San Jose area, this is horrible!
author: Nigel L.

description:
This wasn't my original choice for dinner this evening, but I decided to give it a try when I saw the big picture menu saying they're serving clam ramen. I never saw that before and was curious because I love clams. In fact, I've never eaten here but have gone many times to the sister restaurants Mifune and Osakaya in the next building.

When the noodles came, I noted that they include dome pieces of shrimp and calamari which initially was exciting. Unfortunately, when I got to the clams, they weren't fresh. In fact, they tasted somewhat like raw oysters like those you get at a Chinese dried good stores. I understand that may be an expensive delicacy, but it's something that I never liked the taste of since I was a child. Don't mistake me, I like some dried seafoods like scallops and baby shrimps, just not dried oysters.

At least the miso soup base and noodles were fine. Also the waitress was nice. If I come again, I'll just try the donburi (rice bowls).
author: H K.

description:
HAIR IN THE FOOD!!! 
so my BF and his friend ordered the $5 special from here. it was weird but good and very filling with hella rice, chicken and egg, a bit of greens. but when my BF was mostly done i saw a hair in his food. i guess he wasnt bothered cuz he kept eatting. thankfully i brought a PBJ sandwich and carrots cuz im on a diet. 
2 stars for speed and decent prices.
author: Katie F.

description:
I've lived in Osaka, Japan all of 2008 and upon returning I've lamented over the realization that nowhere in America can seem to come close to the tastes of Japan's "City of Food".  That is save for Mifune Don, my Bay Area haven away from Japan.  The owner is from Osaka as well, and she's brought with her the tastes I've come to miss.

The Okonomiyaki here is the most authentic tasting I've experienced outside of Japan. (Osaka-style, not "Monja" style)  The same goes for the Yakisoba, which makes sense as the two seem to be menu items in the same restaurants in Japan, such as the popular "Fugetsu" chain.  The restaurant staff have been taught the "taste first" traditions of Osaka, so I would recommend against "delicate" dishes.

If you're truly concerned for authenticity, Japantown's Mifune Don should be your first stop.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
Keeping this one short... 

I ordered the lunch special.  Oyako Donburi and Niku Soba Soup.  It was okay.  I've been going to Mifune across the way and I seem to like their Soba more.. softer maybe?  And the broth didn't taste the same.  Oyako Donburi tasted the same tho.  I'll probably stick to the original Mifune because I wanted to add corn to my soup but they didn't have any.  Sad face.  All in all it was cool.
author: Alice E.

description:
Shhhh!

Mifune Don is in the quiet part of the J-Center, Miyako Mall, where they have the little orange bridge that turns inexplicably into the stairs to the second floor. Like most people, I come to this part of the mall only to replenish my supply of Sapporo Ichiban ramen noodles and Pocky boxes at Ichiban Kan. But I decided to try something out of my routine for lunch here, and I have to say it was a bit of a ho-hum.

They offer these $9.80 Lunch Specials where you pick an item from group A and an item from group B. Group A, I understood, since there were only three items, so I chose their beef udon bowl. Group B was a bit confusing because I couldn't make logical sense of the variety of items and whether they were all being presented as options. The people in the booth next to me had the same frustration. Menu usability issues.

I went for a simple sashimi over rice, which was the better part of the lunch since it was straightforward. The udon bowl struck me as rather paltry in ingredients with the salty broth overwhelming everything else. Even with the miso soup and minuscule serving of salad, I also thought $10 was a bit high for what I got. In hindsight, I guess I should have tried the okonomiyaki, apparently the open-omelette, mayo-covered house specialty. Oh well. Service was attentive...even as the bulbous European tourists trundled in with their plastic bags of Ichiban Kan crapware.

FOOD - 3 stars...decent enough but rather overpriced even for lunch
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...reminds me a bit of those cubby-hole Ginza eateries and a lot quieter than its sister restaurant in the Kintetsu Mall
SERVICE - 4 stars...typically attentive as the staff at most J-Town establishments are
TOTAL - 3 stars...Mifune Don, what's that omelette you have on? Could it be okonomiyaki from days gone by? And did I hear ya say, Don was a-meetin' you here today to take you to his teahouse in the sky-eye?
author: Ed U.

description: Unlimited Shabu Shabu is amazing and totally worth the money! Only downside about the place is it is small and fills up fast during lunch and dinner so you may have to wait a while.
author: Cassaundra J.

description: This was our "go to" place in SF Japantown for the past year or so. I visited today after a 4 month hiatus and "things have changed" (and not for the better). The prices have gone up (that's understandable) and the quantity and quality has gone down (as previous posters noted). Not sure if I will be back or not.
author: James W.

description: Pretty good food here.  Wasn't too impressed with their Yakiniku, but everything else I've had here has been good.  I particularly like their sushi, salmon ochazuke, and their ramen.
author: Rory K.

description:
Used to come here all the time when I was a kid.

I would usually get ramen, but lately I've been getting the unagi don or the katsu don. Both are good.

The waitresses were shy at first, but after a couple times they warm up to you.

If you're in the city looking for a good don buri, visit Mifunes
author: Karma B.

description:
We had lunch here while visiting the Daiso / Nijiya stores. All in all, the niku udon and the wakame soba were not *bad* but they were kind of what you'd expect at a fast food restaurant in a Japanese mall's food court. Edible but not delectable. 

Still, the prices weren't outrageous and it hit the spot when we wanted some Japanese food, so we vacillated between giving it two and three stars. We settled on two to counter yelpinflation.
author: Karen N.

description:
Okay. WOW.  Am I really missing something here? This place really gets three and a half stars?  Two or ONE should be more like it!  

1. My boyfriend, friend, and I decided to eat here for lunch.  When the waiter took our order, he "accidentally" forgot to write down my boyfriends order.
2.  Refills was seldom, all we had was water and a hot cup of tea.
3.  All three of us waited for my boyfriends meal to come out... for about 15 minutes.  Obviously they did not check up on us to even see why none of us were touching our food.  
4.  Didn't even bother to take his meal off the tab.
5.  gyoza seemed like it was left on the skillet for too long because the bottom half was missing and was probably still stuck on the pan. 
6.  pickled sides tasted like it was fermented in toilet water.


This place sucks ass!
author: Lea M.

description:
Wow. I plan on paying Mifune a visit sometime soon again and decided to hop onto yelp to see how well (or at least I thought it should be) rated. I am surprised that it's not even 4 stars! =( So, I feel somewhat obligated to write a review. 

I've been coming to Mifune with my family for YEARS now and I love it here. Granted you usually have to wait, and service is not the quickest, nor the best, I still come back over and over again for their food. I always come only for the lunch special because it's a great value ( I apologize I can't give the exact number since I haven't gone for over half a year due to the distance). With the lunch special you basically get 2 items of choice. I usually go for the cold soba and tekka rice bowl, or beef udon with tekka rice. My sister on the other hand like the udon and sushi plate (nigiris - authentic sushi). Their portions are really decent for the price you pay and the flavor is great. I love the presentation of the cold soba and their soba dipping sauce just doesn't taste the same as the ones that you buy in grocery stores. The udon broth on its own deserves 4 stars in my opinion. It's not too salty but sooooo flavorful. If I don't get the udon, I make sure someone else at the table is so I can steal a few spoon full of soup from them. =) 

This is not your commercialized Japanese food restraunt. I mean, we're in Japantown. You get more authentic Japanese food, not overly salty soups, overly decorated sushis etc.  Don't get me wrong, I love commercialized Japansese food as well with all the fancy rolls and stuff, but you just have to appreciate this place for what it is and the flavors of the food for how it is made, simple yet delicious. 

Personally, I really enjoy coming to Mifune and feel like their restaurant is worth at least 4 stars. I'm making a special trip out to the city (not that its THAT far... but I always need an excuse to go) again sometime soon, so Mifune, here I come!
author: Louisa T.

description: This was a terrible place to eat at. I dislike being so blunt but I went here earlier today and I have never been here but I saw the reviews on here and thought Ill try it looks good! I ordered the chicken karage off the appetizer menu and I got a curry bowl the croquette curry bowl to be exact. Ive never had a curry bowl at a japanese restaurant  before so my firsy question to the waitress was if it is spicy? She said not not at all.
