So I went ahead and ordered expecting not spicy which I thought ok this should be interesting. I got the curry bowl and it was so spicy I was sweating throughout my meal and I am not a fan of spicy food but I ordered it so stuck it out. I found eating it very unpleasant and the curry was a little goopy too. In regards to the chicken karage. I have had chicken karage before several times and felt like I was eating imitation chicken it was very stringy and the batter it was fried in did not taste good. Im sure other people love this place but after being lied to by staff over a simple question that can make the difference to an individual who does not know the dish in question and has a sensitive stomach this is a big deal. In addition to this I was asked if I needed a glass of ice water while I was fanning myself from how spicy the curry bowl was. I did not finish either food plates and do not plan on coming back. I had a really bad case of awful indegestion. However despite all of this if you plan on coming here do your research beforehand please.
author: Diana B.

description:
This restaurant is tucked away near the hotel and is far from the rest of the eateries in Jtown. He was telling me how great the Okonomiyaki was until I blurted out 'wth is okonomiyaki?' We ended up coming here for okonomiyaki. When looking at the pictures, I thought it was an omelet with sauce on top. I had no idea what I was getting my stomach into lol

I ain't complaining though, this was my first time having Okonomiyaki. I never knew this place existed til my friend introduced me to it during the Nihonmachi weekend. 

I had the seafood okonomiyaki which was served in a hot iron skillet and was topped with japanese mayo, teriyaki sauce and flakey tofu skins. Whata pretty presentation! And, it smelled delicious! This entree came with a pretty looking dish and a silver spatula. I didn't know I was supposed to use the spatula to eat with until I read Nobu's entry below xD 

I used chopsticks to feed myself. My bill came out to about $20 since I ordered tuna sashimi as well. The bill was actually $16 + tip = 20. My stomach was really satisfied and the staff were refilled my tea constantly which made me really happy. 

Overall, great place to go to for lunch and dinner, but not with a huge group. A large group for them would be like 4 people. There are a few booths and two medium sized tables. Also, this is a hole in the wall type joint. Great food doesn't have to be served in the biggest food joints.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
I been here twice in the past few months and this review is going to be about both visits. 

The first visit:
Customer service: great
Food: I got the mifune special. I loved the tempura it came with but the cold noodles has NO flavor at all. The noodles came with sauce but no matter how much I dipped the noodles in it, or how much I poured over my noodles, it was still tasteless. I wouldn't recommend it. 
Overall: okay

Second visit: 
Customer service: Bad. When we first walked in we were ignored and stood at the door for a good 1-2min before anyone even said a word to us. When looking for a tea refill, we places our empty cups near the edge of the table and it wasn't until we stopped a waiter did we have it refilled. We tried stopping one multiple times before but they always rished right passed us. When leaving, the waiter just stared at us and the amount of tip we left. I admit, we left below 10% tip (Not my fault, my friends were all too broke/cheap to pay their fair share of the tip. I paid my part) however we shouldn't be looked at weird because of that. If you want a better tip, should have gave us better service and I would have been willing to pay more than my share of the tip.
Food: Since I ordered something different this time, I was sastified with my food. Me and my friend spilted the order of seafood ramen and California rolls. There was nothing special about the rolls but the ramen was good.  
Overall: Good

The bathroom is also VERY small but they have nice smelling soap LOL
author: Jenny N.

description:
I really like the waitress. She is very down-to-earth, and simply wonderful. 

The lunch special deal is awesome, okonomiyaki is decent (but I really can't finish it by myself), the sushi roll is always tightly rolled, simply well-done. Ramen is probably not made as professional as Suzu or Tanpopo, but it is good for it's price and definitely a plus for the combo deal that comes with california roll. 

This place can be quite packed during the regular meal time, especially on weekends. I tend to visit this place when it's not the peak-dinning time to enjoy the food.
author: Moneta L.

description:
Great spot for lunch. Service is friendly, the lunch special is cheap and plentiful, and the Oyako Don is amazing. 

To people complaining about the sushi: It's not a sushi bar!
author: Mike O.

description:
3.5 stars -

The last time we came here, my gf and I had a favorable opinion of the food and we were looking forward to coming back again. We had ordered a beef and egg okonomiyaki and a seafood okonomiyaki. They came out looking like the ones they serve in Japan. We've also had okonomiyaki at Kitchen Kura and Halu, but the ones here were slightly larger and they tasted a little better. The ingredients and dough are distributed evenly so the texture is just right for a delicious okonomiyaki.

We came for dinner again today. My gf ordered the mixed okonomiyaki (squid, pork, shrimp, veggies) and the ebi tempura roll and I ordered the tannin don (beef and egg). The roll tasted a little off as soon as we put it in our mouths. It may have had something to do with the fact that the rice was warm. We like our sushi made with cooler or at least room temperature rice. Plus, it tasted bland. Soy sauce did not help the flavor either. I wished we had not ordered this -- it was not worth the $6.80 for 6 bland pieces. The miso soup that came with the donburi was meh. I took two sips and that was it. The mixed okonomiyaki was not as good as the beef and egg or seafood ones we had last time. Maybe, it was a mistake to have chosen something different. My gf felt like there was way too much pork compared to everything else. 

Unlike a few other reviewers, we had no problems with the service either time --the other time we had an older lady. This time, it was a younger waitress and she was also polite and observant. My gf was a little bummed that not all the cooks in the kitchen were Japanese, thus rendering the food not  as "authentic," but we will still definitely come back for the okonomiyaki.
author: robin b.

description:
I have absolutely no complaints about this place. No suggestions, no helpful hints, nothing. It's great the way it is. I've been here a few times now, and it's on my "I want something filling, hot and comforting in my stomach" list. We go here for the  Okonomiyaki. It's great...and oddly entertaining. Whatever they put on the top of it ends up curling up while the whole dish sits on the heat plate. 

The service is good: nice waitress, drinks refilled, we were attended to at appropriate moments. 

Atmosphere: hole in the wall cute place...not too much seating, so good for couples, singles, or small groups. 

Husband and I had a few other dishes there as well, all good quality and filling.
author: Katia T.

description:
Are you fricking kidding me that anyone would rate this place higher than two stars.  I am so livid over my experience today.  My boyfriend and I went in for lunch.  Service was awful.  Food was fare, but not great.  Again service was awful.  How can you have bad service in a restaurant that small.  
1. Everyone that came in before us got tea and water immediatlely.  We had to ask twice. 
2. Refills, forget it.  
3. When my BF asked if the waitress was this, he is also thai she was nasty and ignored him.  
4. they practically threw our food at us, the trays hit the table so hard you could hear the thug everywhere.  
5. They were RUDE, very RUDE.
Okay I could go on, and I would give them NO STARS if I could, DO NOT DINE here.
author: Troy C.

description:
The smaller eatery of the two Mifunes at the Japan Center
Very good lunch specials:
Choice of several types of udon noodles (e.g., chicken, beef, seaweed) for $10.95
With added gyoza, California roll, or unagi for $12.25.
Tempura donburi was very good
Complimentary green tea; friendly food service
8 tables/booths
author: Rosquete B.

description: The food is okay, but not worth the wait or price.
author: Stephen M.

description: Nice little place amongst the JTown Plaza Shopping Center. Underground parking, and this an Indoor Only location. Good Rice and Noodle Bowl Dishes, although peak time therefore service was challenge at times to meet our needs. Located amongst other Japanese Restaurants and Shops but definitely attracted to their rice bowl dishes shown in the front windows. Also, enjoyed the ambiance reminding me of traditional Japan.
author: Jackie W.

description:
I am only reviewing the Zaru Zabu lunch special (Japanese cold noodles). Whether it is a cold or hot day, it is always refreshing and filling eating a bowl of cold noodles accompanied by one of the side dishes (I usually get the juicy and tasty Gyoza). It is a simple and delicious meal. I am always satisfied after my meal. The atmosphere is relaxed and peaceful, the tea is good, the music is great, and the service is excellent. I have no complaints. I have no idea about the other items on the menu but the Zaru Zabu lunch special with your choice of side dish is to diee for. If you want to order this be there before 5 cause that is when the special ends. 

You can also find coupons online for a free order of California roll with a purchase of 20 and over per table
author: Katherine L.

description:
Oh so yummy!

Living in Berkeley, it is really hard to find really good Japanese food. I came with a friend to eat before volunteering at the Cherry Blossom Festival and it definitely hit the spot when it came to my craving for Japanese food. 

I ordered the Mifune Special (Cold Udon and Soba with Tempura). The dipping sauce for the noodle was so good. Not too salty,but definitely flavorful. My friend ordered the Katsu Curry and it was HUGE! It smelled so good!

Only problem with the place is the price. Kind of expensive, but once in a while is okay.
author: Derrick H.

description: I asked for something not even on the menu, clam miso ramen, and the server got my special request immediately, no problem, no strange looks.  Excellent ramen.  The real thing.  Got lucky with an empty parking space right outside the front door, which is rare, lucky, and just made lunch quick, short and sweet.  Four and a half star service too.
author: Joe S.

description:
what an experience! granted it was New Year's Day and half of J-Town was closed down, but we finally set on Mifune-Don as the place to eat dinner. The restaurant was PACKED, and I suppose the kitchen backed up. We ordered and was immediately greeted with green tea and water. A few minutes later a complimentary "salad" which came with my order (unagi donburi) was given to my partner. About 10 minutes later my order arrived at our table. I politely waited as I assumed my partner's order was close behind. 

NOT SO 

I didn't time it, or look at my watch, but I'll assume about half an hour later (by now the restaurant was nearly empty and the "closed" sign on the door, her meal arrived. Mine was now cold and congealed. Naturally I complimented the waitress that my partner's meal had finally arrived at least on the same day, but did not admonish her further. I assumed it was the kitchen's fault. 

The lead waitress came to apologize. near the end of our meal and a kitchen person came and also apologized. Here, I told him that I thought it was prudent to hold back the one immediately available dish until (approximately) both orders were ready so to not make the customers uncomfortable. English (or Japanese) was not his first language and I think the logic was lost on him. 

My partner was a waitress in an upscale restaurant in Marin for 20 years and she assured me that for a professional staff (wait and prep) there is cooperation and even communication to the customers (especially to larger parties) what they should expect as to serving timing. 

I do not hold any grievance against any of the staff since I am certain this is a one-off experience. I left the standard tip, and wouldn't want to see anyone fired (jobs being so rare these days) but some training is in order. 

We enjoyed the taste of the food.
author: Robert W.

description:
I would stop here for dinner after my hair appointment at JCBC. Their prices are very reasonable and their food suits my palate more than On the Bridge. 

Huge selection on the menu. Definitely more of a "fast-food" Japanese than a real Japanese restaurant per se. Their menu ranges from Ramen to Bento boxes and sushi. Their dinner set is very cheap. $14 for a bowl of noodle soup, tuna sashimi, salad, and California Rolls. It goes up to about $20, but you will get chicken katsu and tempura. Definitely very affordable and a lot of food.

Service was always prompt, but not the friendliest.
author: July N.

description:
3.5 stars

Came here to satisfy a Japanese food craving before a show at the Fillmore. It was actually the first time I ate in place in this Japanese mall. I didn't know what to get, and ended up setting on ramen.

I really like noodles. I really really really like noodles. And the ramen here was only OK, maybe just borderline good. However, the price was definitely right (although the service was pretty slow, i'm pretty forgiving about that though). I wanna try the okonomiyaki here if ever come back.
author: Andrew M.

description: Quick, cheap place to eat in J-town.  It's average food, better than take out that won't break the bank.  Fast to seat, fast to order, and fast to get out.
author: MTBer I.

description: Great food and even better customer service. Inexpensive and well worth the value compared to it's neighbors. Highly recommend!
author: Kristy M.

description: Food was pretty good but service was pretty not good,boo for that! It was a great deal big bowl of beef sobs and sushi rice with sashimi all for about $11. I asked for water 3 times until I got some. I asked for no ginger or Wahabis on my sashimi and got a huge pile of ginger on top,yuck! Because the food was good I might go back.
author: Karen T.

description: Cozy, fast service and solid food. Decent lunch special deals with noodles and another side dish. I ordered the chicken soba soup with a side of chicken curry over rice. Almost enough for two meals and really hit the spot on a cold day.
author: Clinton L.

description: Ordered spicy beef steak ramen, so so good.
author: Jerry G.

description: I've had the Japanese mountain vegetable soba and was pretty impressed with the flavors compared with a lot of soba in Jtown. The wait staff are very attentive. I have to say, their curry is very bland.
author: Brittany B.

description:
I ordered 2 Diet Cokes, the Beef Nabe, and an extra bowl of rice on this visit. The atmosphere is not too quiet. The service was very fast and the waitress monitored the boiling/cooking of my Nabe hot pot for me. I was seated immediately and my order had been taken right away. (I probably should mention that I am a regular here XD).

Side note: Waitress somehow reminds me of Japanese actress Miki Mizuno from the hit 90's Japanese cop drama Odoru Daisousassen (Bayside Shakedown).

This was my first time having Nabe which gave me a chance to teach myself the finer points of rationing meat. Got my check 5 minutes after I was done eating and my total came to $16.30.
author: Nathaniel O.

description: Five stars for the okonmiyaki! I went here based on the Yelp reviews and they were not wrong. I haven't been to Japan so I can't say anything about authenticity, but this is the best okonomiyaki that I've ever had. So flavorful and the seafood is cooked perfectly. And they don't overload it with sauce. It's a tiny place and they tell you when you order that it's going to be 10-15 minutes, and that's fine by me. The servers are super attentive and the food is worth the wait. I've noticed others eating ramen and sushi so that must be popular too. I can't bring myself to order anything besides the seafood okonomiyaki though.
author: Amy W.

description: Cute exterior. The okonomiyaki was good; also had tamago yaki and an udon lunch special with oyako-don. Everything was decent.
author: Rina L.

description:
My friends and I came here to eat, after trying to get into Dosa (40 minute wait), Fresca (1.5 hour wait), and SPQR ("we started taking reservations and have several big parties coming in (so don't even bother)").  I'm surprised at how early restaurants in Japantown and Japantown Center close, but Mifune Don let us in after their official closing time of 9 p.m.  I had never tried okonomiyaki, so I was pretty excited.

I ordered the pork and egg okonomiyaki, which is deceptively named, because it also contains squid (the menu tells you in the description).  I wondered if it would taste like a Korean seafood pancake, but it didn't.  It was presented in a cast iron skillet, and kept warm on a built-in table-top burner.  I thought the pancake was perfectly cooked, crispy on the outside, and soft and moist on the inside.  It was topped with okonomiyaki sauce, mayonnaise, and bonito flakes, which added a nice savory flavor.  One of these is probably enough to feed two people, if you're also drinking and order a side dish.

One of my friends ordered the mix yakisoba, which was good, because it was not greasy, not too salty, and had chewy noodles (the most important factor for me).  My other friend ordered the curry cutlet, which was basically, deep fried mashed potatoes and yellow curry sauce over rice.  It was flavorful, but I probably wouldn't order it myself, because it is kind of heavy.

I would come here again for a casual meal.
author: Diana C.

description:
When dealing with places that still exist, best okonomiyaki ever!  My friend up in San Francisco took me to this place and like I said, best okonomiyaki ever now!  Really.  I thank my friend for taking me here, though I feel bad for leaving him out when I spoke to our waitress in Japanese.  Ha ha ha!

I forgot.  For those that don't know, okonomiyaki is a grilled dish of various toppings in some batter. (The literal translation is along the lines of grilled favorites.) So, yeah, we had the modern okonomiyaki which if I remember correctly is more or less like the Hiroshima type, as in the type with noodles.

Yeah, the place is so~ good.  You will have trouble finding the place.  Other than that, there really isn't much else to say.

+:  It's a nice small gem in the lovely city of San Francisco, as it has solid marks all-around.

-:  The place is easy to miss.
author: Don U.

description:
Hubby and I had some time to kill before we had to be over at my cousin's house so we decided to drop by Japantown and grab some lunch. Originally we were going to go Mifune, but there was a wait! Usually I don't mind waiting, but I'm pregnant right now and the baby wanted to eat ASAP.

So we headed back to Mifune Don, which we passed by while we were walking to Mifune. Mifune Don is a much smaller restaurant and not busy at all. The server sat as at a booth quickly and gave us water. Hubby and I ordered the $10.95 lunch special, which consists of an entree and a side. I opted for the soba (what is it with me and soba) with curry and rice. Hubby ordered udon with donburi. We received our order quickly. The soba and curry were delicious! I ate both in one sitting! Hubby loved his udon, but took his donburi to go. 

I will be definitely coming here next time I'm in town!
author: Jillanne D.

description:
This place is aiiighhhtttt! Came here on a Saturday Afternoon. Not too crowded but not empty either. 

I order a sapparo and a lunch special with a tekka-don side. See I don't even remember what I had it 'cause it was kinda mundane. The price was good, but the quality was so so. Overall service, ambiance, service was so so.
author: Joon Y.

description:
Came here for lunch today.  Good food, and fast service.

Since I wasn't that hungry I had the wakame salad and california rolls.  The wakame was pretty good, but nothing special.  Usually I don't order this at restaurants because Ranch 99 has it for about $7 for a large portion, but I had a craving today.  The California rolls were good and very fresh.  

My dining companion had the lunch special for $10.95 (ramen and california roll).  He ate the whole thing and said the ramen was the best he ever tasted.  

I would come back here.  Fast, friendly and easy on the wallet!
author: Nita K.

description:
Meh.

I ordered the kitsune soba and when it came I smelled the MSG vapors, which I did not know was possible. It's really plain (came with two pieces of tofu and a couple tiny slivers of fish cake) and unremarkable. I guess it's decent and filling if you are hungry enough (which I was) but really not worth my $10.

I say again: meh.
author: Tiffany C.

description: So lately Ive been eating a lot of Japanese food. I came across this place with my gf and wanted to eat some light dinner. I ordered the soba with raw tuna and she just ordered the tuna with rice. The food was pretty good. The fish was a bit slimy and didn't have the consistency of sashimi like it was suppose to be. The service was a bit slow but the place and "making your own soup" was unique!
author: Allister D.

description:
After a long day of shopping, my boyfriend and I were looking for something low-key for dinner. He wanted to go to a place in Japantown, so we decided to give this place a try. The Yelp reviews are spot on--the noodles at this place are its specialty! The menu is not too expansive, but it definitely focuses on its noodle items over appetizers, rolls, and nigiri. I would come back to place again in Japantown if I'm looking for a quick fix of Japanese food at a decent price (total was roughly $36 not including tip).

Zaru Soba: 
My boyfriend had the zaru soba (cold soba noodles topped with seaweed flakes that you dip in a cold sauce), which was $6.80--a great price for a dinner item! I typically prefer hot udon noodles over cold soba, but these soba noodles were delicious (in terms of texture). Although bland-tasting without the sauce provided, the noodles were very bouncy and chewy. 

Deluxe Nabe:
Even though I love nabeyaki udon (chicken, tempura shrimp, egg, mushrooms, veggies, and udon in a broth), I opted to step it up and go for a deluxe nabe (same as nabeyaki udon but also includes scallops). It was $14.80--seemingly pricey, but you get an ENORMOUS metal pot of food (bigger than my face!). Something special this place has that my boyfriend pointed out was the type of seaweed this place uses in their hot noodle dishes--the seaweed is not your typical flavorless seaweed. It's got a hint of sweetness that resonates in your mouth as you eat the noodles and sip the hot broth. It's a wonderful touch that he and I don't taste often when we go to Japanese restaurants.

Nigiri:
My boyfriend originally was not in the mood for sushi, but since the price was right, he also ordered some nigiri for us to munch on. He ordered a salmon nigiri, hamachi nigiri, and ikura. The salmon and hamachi nigiri were $3.80 and the ikura was $4.80. I wouldn't say they're the best quality nigiri, but they were average. I didn't eat the ikura, but I'd rank the hamachi nigiri as better tasting than their salmon nigiri. I'm sure this can vary depending on the fish shipped in that day, but I'll bet the salmon typically shipped here won't be very fatty and thus not as succulent as it could be.

Atmosphere & Service:
This is probably the main reason I would only rank this place 3.5 stars instead of 4. We arrived at this place around 7:30 pm, and not surprisingly, this place was packed. Nevertheless, we got a booth immediately. The table and seats looked like they hadn't been wiped (some leftover splashes here and there on the table, some oily marks and crumbs on the seat), but I'm glad the waiter did not take offense when I asked for extra napkins to wipe the booth down a bit. (I've been to other fancier/pricey restaurants where the hostess/waiter would give me the stink eye because I want to their uncleaned tables & seats.) He simply handed me a bulk of napkins and apologized for the mess. Our waiter and other waiters were very prompt with refilling drinks and serving, so I was very pleased to never have to ask for a refill or wait a long period of time for food (the food arrived within 5 minutes or less).
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Walking into this hidden gem is like walking into a Japanese speakeasy. But instead of booze and debauchery there's serenity and a transcendental food experience. Very spectacular food. I always pass by this place probably gazillion times whenever I am at Japantown, it's right next to Seoul Garden Korean restaurant. 

My eyes were appealed by the window display with full of plastic food models, haha. Made me wonder if it's real. LOL. 
I ordered bunch of kinds of sushi. I say it taste alright, but you can't go wrong with their soup!! 

The only thing I hate about this place was the waiter. I was constantly eating my food enjoyably, she keeps staring at me while I'm at it which made it feel awkward. Have some respect when people are eating their food, please. 

Overall, it's pretty affordable and delish.
author: Jan P.

description: Service is slow and terrible.  Hostess does not know how to seat peaple..don't spread them out if the restaurant is nearly empty.  Its bad enough the server stand around, now they have to run around an empty restaurant just to service the customer.  You have to flag the server down because they just freaking stand around...what does it take to get a tea refill.
author: MickYee M.

description:
I'm a big fan of ramen, udon and homey Japanese places.  I just can't give this place more than 3-stars:
- chicken karage: juicy and tender, but not all that crispy on the outside
- Nabayaki udon: decent with all the usual ingridents. Nothing spectaular
- pancake (can't remember the name):  don't usually see this dish at other places, +1 star for just serving this
- unagi don:  just average
- dragon roll: just average
- service: not horrible and maybe a notch above your mom & pop Japanese restaurant. 

Note - they don't have high chairs, only booster seats.
author: Hsiao C.

description:
On a recent Monday, a series of pesky mishaps wound up placing me in the culinary world's equivalent of purgatory - aka "The Linner Zone". That nether time around 4:00 that is too late for lunch, too early for dinner, yet unfortunately (and correspondingly) accompanied by a ravenous appetite. So - there you have it. The Linner Zone.

I've walked by Mifune Don countless times while ambling around Japantown and thought "That looks cute". But for one reason or another, never stopped. That changed on this day since it was open at the odd hour offering a welcoming respite for two ravenous refugees from Linner Zone. Yes! 

With growling stomachs and plummeting blood sugars, my bf and I zipped inside and tucked into one of the few cozy booths. Within 5 minutes we were grubbing down on oh-so-satisfying, unfussy, Japanese comfort foods like wakame udon (with slices of fishcake, seaweed, silky noodles and flavorful broth), excellent potato croquettes (some of the best I've had in SF), generously portioned grilled salmon, veggie & shrimp tempura (non-oily and perfectly breaded) rounded out with rice, miso soup, pickled vegetables and green tea. Aaah. Happy bellies. Plus happy wallets. Linner time sometimes silver linings into Happy Hour pricing. 

We grabbed some sweet red bean treats from a nearby grocery and strolled safely out of Linner right into The Comfort Zone. I recommend following this plan closely should you ever  find yourself in similar dining peril.
author: wendella a.

description:
oknomiyaki is surprisingly hard to find in america, maybe the seafoody kewpie mayoey fish flakeyness it too much for ameircan palettes?

well i guess when i describe it that way it sounds pretty gross BUT IT ISN'T IT IS IN FACT AWESOME

i wonder if i were to open a place that let u cook ur own like most of the ones in japan if i would be successful? hmmmmm

ANYWAYs

mifune don is pretty decent/ok/youcan'tgetokonomiyakeanwhereelsesodealwithit. 

That being said, if you've never tried the dish go do it.

and pass on the mix-modern-yaki, it's not as good as the regular okonomiyaki and costs more to boot.

and who the hell thought of the expression "to boot"
author: Misha T.

description: First off, I'd like to comment on our arrival. My girlfriend wanted okanomiyaki so we decided on this place. We waited in the doorway and the waitress didn't seem to notice us until we asked if there was a place to write down our names, to which she replied, "You can." Like ???? So we just stayed instead of shopping around while waiting for a table. When we got seated, I had to raise my hand for a good 2 minutes before anybody came over, and when she did, she didn't take my order, instead she said someone else would take it. Which was fine. So we waited further, and finally a waitress came to take our order. After a solid 45 minutes, the food arrived at last. I can't lie though, the okanomiyaki was shmackin. When we finished eating and paid for the meal, the waitress never came back with our change, so I had to ask for it. Dissatisfied with my experience, I chose to leave a measly tip of 56 cents. Only seconds after leaving the restaurant, the waitress had called us back with an attitude to say, "Is this all you think I deserve? The tip asks for 15% normally but I'll only ask for 10%" as if she was being nice or something. Begrudgingly, I handed her two dollars and left feeling bitter. Okanomiyaki 8/10 Service 1/10
author: Jerry W.

description:
Came here on Friday for dinner - I was craving some Japanese food and wanted to try out a new place. I'm not sure if this is the sister Restaurant to Mifune on the other side of the building - they do kinda share the same name. Anyway, we were seated pretty quickly - its a small Restaurant, but its clean. They only had one waitress running the place, with two cooks I believe. But we were able to get our food in a timely manner. 

The menu wasn't that impressive - they don't have many sushi rolls or sushi at all. But I wouldn't get sushi here anyway. I think their speciality is noodles cooking in a iron pot at your table! The tables are all equipped to be able to cook noodles. But we ordered the katsu curry rice and the tempura with soba. It was okay - the curry was a little salty - and I've had better before. The soba with tempura was pretty good...but again, its just pretty standard stuff. Looks like the okonomiyaki is the thing to get here - I'll have to try it next time.
author: Betty S.

description: Judy, Josie and I have probably tried every restaurant in Japantown.  This one obviously had good donburis.
author: Suz L.

description: Horrid customer service. Basically sat down and ignored for 15 minutes. No "hello welcome", No tea, no water...
author: Geordie E.

description: Zaru soba was so good last time, we got a couple orders to go this time.  Food is excellent and service is awesome. Our water and tea never went dry.
author: John H.

description: Came her for lunch on a Friday.  Quick and friendly service, cheap lunch specials...  We came here for the Udon/Soba and it hit the spot.  I'll definitely come here for noodles again!
author: Peter K.

description:
This place is a solid 3.5 stars. I am not in the Japantown neighborhood much and since the Japanese supermarket ran out of their pre-packaged sushi pack yum-yums, my boyfriend and I decided to come here.

Our waitress was attentive and the service was quick. We ordered a California Roll, a Katsu-soba, and beef & egg donburi. The California Roll had sweet egg as one of the ingredients, so that was a nice change from the imitation crab and mayo mix served at most places. My meal came with a tiny nibble of a fermented vegetable salad and miso soup. The salad is nothing to write home about but the miso soup tasted very authentic. My beef and egg donburi was tasty, but the sauce was a bit overpowering. However, it was still solid. Also, the donburi portions are hefty and the meals are decently priced. 

Next time, I hope to come back and try their soba noodles and okonomiyaki.
author: Crystal C.

description:
I think the food here is not super special, but all in all the taste is pretty good for most of the dishes. I like to order okonomiyaki and soba here among other things.

If you are looking for something less americanized in the Japantown area, Mifune Don is definitely a terrific choice!
author: Samantha T.

description:
This place rocked. I had their grilled salmon filet and tempura combination. The restaurant was clean and well kept. Service was nice and friendly. I was pretty impressed on how fresh the food was. 

Definitely coming back here again!
author: Mika D.

description: Oh, geeez. I think they really should get rid of shabu shabu from their menu. Please refer my comment only about shabu shabu. If you want to have shabu shabu, go to other places. If you want to try this place, have some other dishes. What made us so disappointed was thick beef cut and meat came out frozen. I understand they tried to keep them fresh, but can they at least defrost meat completely before serving? Also, they didn't have grounded daikon/radish for soy dipping sauce.  Wrong meats wrong sauce....They're missing whole points of shabu shabu.
author: Zoe K.

description:
On our last day of our vacation in SanFran, we hit up the Japan mall right beside our hotel (Hotel Kabuki) and browsed around. 

Not sure of what to eat, we walked at least 2x by this restaurant and ended up trying it out (they had a stream of people coming in and out). We were not disappointed.  We were seated right away and we settled on the lunch specials ($10.95/ea) which consisted of a main soup item with a side. I ordered the bean curd with skinny noodle and side curry and my hubby ordered the udon and for his side, some kind of fish with teriyaki sauce?. This place is kid friendly and they were nice to my 3yr old daughter. She enjoyed my side dish which was the  currey with rice! 

Anyways, it was a great experience.  We also got good service - received water refills often and also their complimentary hot tea refills. 

Will definitely come back here the next time we come visiting!
author: Marnie A.

description:
Mifune Don Restaurant is easy to miss, crowded as it is into the mall in Japantown.  But this place serves a quick, cheap, and unpretentious lunch of better than average quality.

I had the miso soup and seaweed salad to start (hard to screw up) and the soba noodles.  The soba noodles were traditional, fresh and perfectly cooked with a little al dente bite to them.

The gf had the okonomyaki which she liked enough to bring home the leftovers.  (Come to think of it, she always brings home leftovers.)  But she liked this even better than the specialty okonomyaki place we went too in Honolulu a few months ago.

We spied on a lot of our fellow diners and coveted the tempura for most of our meal.  If we go back, that will definitely be on our list.

Overall, Mufune Don is nothing more than a casual diner, good when you're stuck in Japantown and trying to figure out where to eat.  I don't think we'd make a special trip to go there.  But what this place does, it does extremely well.  For a fast and cheap Japanese lunch, Mufune Don is a winner.
author: Steve B.

description:
OKONOMI-YAKI-MAN here!
It's in a 8" diameter hot iron skillet eat with a silver spatula!
The Spatula is NICE!
I like it.
That is authentic eating Okonomi-Yaki with a silver spatula.
beef, pork, shrimp, sea food mix.
8 to 12 bucks.

Okonomi-Yaki was very popular when I was a kid in my home town.
I remember there were Okonomi-Yaki-Ya (Ya= a store) almost every corner.
My parents didn't took me there, they were poor and they didn't like the idea eating out at restaurants. 

All of the corner type Okonomi-Yaki-Ya in my home town had One Big Hot plate table.
The table Big enough for 6 to 8 people .... it's like the hot plate table at Beni-Hana. 
So when I was at Benihana 1st time, 27 years ago, I said to myself, " It's a Fxxxin' Okonomi-Yaki-Ya, but why they don't make Okonomi-yaki. WhatThe FXXX?" 
I didn't get it.
Why No Okonomi-Yaki?
I really wanted to ask Mr. Rocky Aoki about it but he is dead now.

So I remember clearly my 1st time Okonomi-Yaki shop experience was.
My friends took me there.
I had a Modan-Yaki.
It was Hirishima-style.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YZ0fIuDlecE

Hiroshima style is Yaki-soba between 2 thin, crepe like thin pan cake, just mixed wheat flour and water. on a hot plate table. 
Usually Oba-chan lady right front of you making it.
Oba-Chan= Older woman. You don't say this right front of women.
And we all ate with a silver spatula.
I had such a hard time eating with the silver spatula.
But I thought I'll get looked from my friends showing I was 1st timer if I asked for chopsticks so I trained myself to use the FXXXin' spatula.
It was not that easy.
But it was fun also, to cut the Okonomi-Yaki with the spathula and scoop it and eat it. 
I didn't think eating with spathula was such a good idea because on the hot plate and hot Okonomi-Yaki with a steel spathula?
Everything was HOT.

All my friends were experienced.
Their parents took them and taught them how to use a pathula when they were very small.
FXXX.
I hated my parents that my spatula training days so badly.
Childhood experience is very important in any case. 

But, Thank God that they were too busy eating it and I could eat it FAST enough so they didn't notice I was struggled.

But when i began to used to spathula, what a joy using it.

It took me about 14 visits to finally be able to scoop the last piece of Okonomi-yaki without using the other hand to hold.  I was about 14.

Well, the Best Okonomi-Yaki I had in SF was that the Benihana in Japantown about 12 years ago. I don't know they still do Okonomi-yaki. Hope they do.

I liked Izumi-Ya's Okonomi-yaki but I haven't been there for 3 years.
Sapporo-ya wasn't too bad.
So as Genki-Ramen.
The worst Okonomi-Yaki I've ever had was that at Hime on Lombard St.
Hime was pathetic.

http://www.yelp.com/biz/hime-san-francisco#hrid:JuU-5VI0Kl5PG4v6LAkgyg

Omu-Soba, Yaki-soba inside of thin omelet, I don't know who invented the shit but the shit is pretty good.
author: Nobu K.

description: Came by for lunch and had some, as the stars indicate, a-ok ramen. $8.50 for a bowl of chasu ramen with attentive service (never needed to ask for more water or tea!) and fast, yummy food.
author: Madeline N.

description: I had their okonomiyaki and  It was delicious!!! I also had their cut roll with uni on it. I didn't like the sushi much. The rice was way too sticky to be legit sushi. Thankfully uni was on it because I wouldn't have finished it otherwise. I have yet to try their ramen, which I hope to do once I'm up in the bay area again. The restaurant is small but there's outdoor seating available if you want to enjoy the day.
author: Anna K.

description: Our experience was okay. We entered on the eastside and wanted to eat before we went through the mall. Wish we had waited until we got further in; the choices seemed better than what we decided on. We ordered a couple bowls of ramen that weren't outstanding. The kimchee ramen didn't look quite right and didn't taste particularly kimchee-y. We asked twice for water refills before we got them. So it was just okay. We'll choose another place to eat next time we go.
author: Taryn And Stefani A.

description: What can I say other than how amazingly delicious and fresh the sushi is!!! We ordered some maguro sashimi and some spicy tuna rolls. It was by far one of the best sushi place we've eaten at. I'd have to keep it on my top 5. Granted the food was delish, it took forever to get our orders and food. I also didn't like how there was a limited choice on beverages. If I could give it a 3.5, I would. But a revisit is likely.
author: Shana O.

description:
OKONOMIYAKI is the name of my game.

It's a Japanese dish that you either love or don't love. I first had this dish in Kyoto and immediately fell in love with it. Well, it turns out that  most Japanese restaurants here in the U.S. don't serve it.

To my knowledge there are only a couple of places in SF that serve Okonomiyaki. Izaka-ya and Mifune. I have to say... I love the way that Mifune prepares their version of it. Izaka-ya is good too. But Mifune isn't as crowded and you cannot beat their prices. Not super cheap, but a good deal for Japanese food. Plus their wait staff is very nice. 

In my book a five star rating is hard to come by but when you find a place that not only serves a "hard to find" dish (exactly the way I like it),  at a reasonable price - well... you get five stars!
author: Stephanie I.

description:
Passable but not great informal all-around Japanese restaurant.  No sushi chef so the sushi is crude - they use a mold for the rice!  Service was inattentive and the place could use some sprucing up.  Udon noodles in the soup were very good.  Other things were simple, and carelessly prepared and plated.  Despite the hype it's in the middle to lower half of all the restaurants in Japantown, and a tad more expensive than its peers.

They must put crack in the rice, because the Michelin people decided to rate this one, of all the town's great Asian joints, one of the very few French-approved non-French restaurants in town.  Utterly inexplicable.  Guest they were out to lunch in more ways then one.
author: Gil S.

description:
Not bad! There aren't too many Japanese restaurants that offer okonomiyaki, and if you like your okonomiyaki more meaty than stachy, this is the place to go (but if you like it the other way around, get it at Izumiya). Their ramen's broth was perfect too. It's so hard to find a bowl of ramen that isn't too salty or too bland. Pretty cheap here too. They offer $5 donburi to go!

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: Tasty, but saw mice running around in the restaurant at my last visit. A shame, because the noodles are so good.
author: Alyssa M.

description: This place has a really great $25 all you can eat shabu shabu deal! They give you ribeye cuts and delicious rice that you can keep eating to your heart's content. It's great when you're famished because they bring out the stuff very quickly. However, the waiters are not every attentive after bringing out the first set of meat and veggies so the service is slow after that.
author: Libing W.

description:
Tried the: 

* tsuke soba w/ tempura (where you dip the noodles, and not where it's floating in a bowl of soup)
* tanin don ("stranger" beef/egg udon) 
* combination yakisoba w/ egg

and they were all perfectly al dente! I usually assume I will dislike tempura (esp the fluff and oil), but I actually ate theirs b/c the shrimp was super good. They might have forgotten the tempura sauce, but that's okay, less sodium the better.

I'm told they make their noodles downstairs daily; it really makes a difference! I don't think I'll go elsewhere for noodles in jtown now. I'm content here. The waitress was super nice, considering we basically got there after they "closed"!! I think there was only 1 chef that day, but I was impressed when 11 or more orders went in, and they all pretty much arrived one after the other. SKILLS. 

We came, ate, and left content. Will definitely return!
author: Nanemone T.

description: Came here with my cousin and his girlfriend after what seemed like an impossibly long day. I have to say, the food is the only thing that saved my rating of this place, because that was a fantastic sukiyaki nabe order. But the service was horrible. I know being a waitress for a restaurant isn't easy, and I know it's a lot o handle, but there were only 3 other people in the restaurant, who were already eating and you still managed to twittle your thumbs and forget about us. I guess you really just don't mind getting paid by the hour... We called for her 3 times as she walked by us and she still managed to not see. I'm sorry but that was pretty terrible...
author: Michael N.

description: A casual space with the best udon I've had since I first learned to love it, many years ago, at a very unimposing Asian restaurant in Vancouver, Washington. Lana thought her Imari sushi was very good as well. Decent tea, OK service, reasonable prices. You'll find it in the lower level of the shopping center.
author: Lana G.

description: Excellent surprise. Looks like a small restaurant. My wife is native japanese and was missing her hometown so took her there. Worker in restaurant not Japanese but food was excellent. They make their Udon pasta from scratch and my wife was surprised how good it was. Whatever the nationality of the chef he must have studied in Japan. The okonomiyaki was really really good and the waitress we had was genuinely caring and polite. This resulted in an excellent dining experience. We only had one udon and one okonomiyaki but we are definitely fans and will return to try new stuff.
author: Kim N.

description:
I'm not entirely sure why Mifune Don only got 3 stars. They are a very good very reliable Japanese restaurant. Friendly staff and always busy (a good sign). 

They have a $20 shabu-shabu deal which is awesome. Their Sukiyake nabe is delicious; but my favorite dish has to be their gyoza appetizer. Yum! Note that this is NOT a sushi/sashimi restaurant, though you can order it they specialize in cooked japanese dishes.
author: Claire J.

description: The food wasn't good, the booth smelled like cat pee, and there were bugs. The star is for the waiter because he was nice
author: Robert E.

description: So i like at Mifune. But Mifune was full and crowded. So i went across to Mifune Don. Its cute; a little restaurant. The waitress is nice. But the only thing that was bad is; each time i go there the california roll is very dry. Like the rice and roe (the small orange fish eggs). Which made it bad. But it okay.
author: M L.

description: Reasonable option in the overly hyped japantown. Relatively inexpensive for a ramen but nothing really to rave about.
author: Adam X.

description: This is the place to go for Japanese pancakes: Okonomiyaki.  Get any variety and any combo.
author: Matt S.

description:
Went here for lunch and between 2 people the tab was $21. We had an order of cold soba noodles, a tempura assortment, a bowl of ramen (so excellent!) and a small bowl of chicken and scrambled eggs over rice. The service was not bad considering there was just one waitress, 4 other occupied tables with one being a very large party of 8. The place is small, very narrow and on the long-ish side. Ambiance is just like any other casual Japanese eatery.

Okay, I'm now editing this to add that I've now also tried the niku (beef) udon, gyoza (kind of salty) and the California roll (pretty good). Service seemed a little faster this time around.
author: cyndi L.

description: This is the smaller more casual sister restaurant of Mifune that I prefer because it is calmer and easier to get in and out. Really good udon noodles. Fat and Chewy. My friend had the ramen which was also good. Service was quick and I had a big glass of sake for $7. I'll be back!
author: Priscilla C.

description:
My favourite place for soba. For years I've been going here with great pleasure. 

I felt always welcome, with a nice and caring service, especially when I was pregnant, sickish, fat, and ravenous. I count on the finger of one hand the places who were nice to me when I looked like a whale with a floral dress. Even better, I came back with the baby and guess what? We were welcome too. 

Whenever I have a little time and feel for some comforting and delicious noodles : Mifune Don, here we are!
author: Del D.

description: Delicious authentic Japanese noodles.  By far, one of the best Japanese noodles in town. Lousy poor quality sushi. They use frozen artificial colored tuna instead of fresh ones.  Customer service??? No service! Not even a "thank you" when they hand you the check. So don't expect anything else.  Pricey for just a noodle place. Ordered 2 combo noodle set. $30....expensive!  Unfortunately, for the taste, we'll still be back. Lol
author: Josh G.

description: Brought my Brooklyn friends here for some shabu shabu. Came on a Monday afternoon so there was no wait and the service was fine. Lots of beautiful red slices on beef. We got two orders for three people and we were stuffed! Came out to about $14 per person. We even drank all the broth like rude Americans.
author: Shmalex D.

description: Pretty standard. we had the salmon tea rice thing and chasiu ramen. Not really standout in a good or bad way
author: Joy X.

description: I was in desperate need of a hot bowl of ramen and Mifune is disappointing. Gyoza was bland too.
author: Vicky R.

description:
I don't eat out much...but I often find myself in Mifune a few times a month with my friends. I always go to this one in the Peace Plaza, which is much smaller and has less tourists. The waitress is always nice and attentive to our needs even though she is busy dealing with other tables. Its nice to know that my cup of tea never reaches the bottom! 

Order the mix Okonomiyahki, its so good! And if you're super hungry, the lunch special is more than enough to feed one person. In fact it could feed a small army of asian girls...in my experience.
author: Lyna N.

description:
try their lunch special. for $10.50, you get a bowl of noodles and another bowl of a rice dish. i got the beef udon and the unagi rice bowl. boyfriend got ramen and beef bowl. i thought the portions were good. the udon was excellent. i'm not a huge fan of udon, but something about this place told me to get it. and i was so happy with my choice. there's a good amount of meat, which i didn't expect. the broth was very tasty. the unagi bowl was so good! there was plenty of unagi. it was cooked well, and wasn't drowned in sauce. my boyfriend's ramen was really good. he loves ramen, but he likes the one that costs 10 cents and it cooks in 5 mins. haha. his beef bowl was also very good. he couldn't even finish it!

i guess i can understand why people don't like this place. fortunately, service was good when we got here. where we were seated, i had full view of the kitchen, particularly the cleaning area. it wasn't exactly clean, but i don't know what the standards are for that. i'd go back whenever i'm back in san francisco.
author: Rachelle B.

description:
We've been looking for a good okonomiyaki place in SF for a while.  I still don't think one exists.

I recently tried out Mifune Don.  I've tried it at Izumiya and Sapporo-ya, both in Japantown, and their okonomiyaki is not passable at all.  (The okonomiyaki I make at home is 100 times better, and I'm not even Japanese.)

Mifune Don's is the best of the three, but still not "good" okonomiyaki by my standards.  Sorry, I've been spoiled by Gaja and Tombo down in LA and my partner's been spoiled by authentic okonomiyaki in Osaka AND Hiroshima, Japan.  Even our Japanese friend who came with us to Mifune Don said, "meh."

Sadly, it seems that there are no real good okonomiyaki places in the Bay Area.  You'll either have to make it yourself (it's very easy to make and ingredients can be found at Nijiya or Mitsuwa) or travel to LA or Japan.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
The three stars is for the excellent okonomiyaki Michael had. He loved it and said it was much better than the okonomiyaki at that other Japanese restaurant by Kinokuniya. 

I had some sort of beef don that was just not memorable. The sauce was bland and too sweet and the rice was a little too soft. 

The waitress was nice and very attentive.

All in all, I would go here again just to sample their sake.
author: emi s.

description:
Really good okonomiyaki. I heard about this place from my massage therapist.

Outside of Japan, this is the best I've had. I tried the other spot next to the crepe place, but the popularity of the Kinokuniya building should have tipped me off that they can afford to ride that popularity and slack off on their okonomiyaki.

I don't know if it's just me, but the pancake feel of okonomiyaki can be overwhelming, making you think you're full after a couple of bites. So much flavor! If you feel yourself getting full like this, just have a swig from a nice glass of Coke on ice, and you can continue. I don't know why Coke does that for me.

I've been back a couple of times since I found out about this place last month. Definitely a place off the beaten-path in Japantown, good for impressing that cute non-asian girl.

Knocked a star-off for having a very unfriendly hostess (working Saturday afternoons) who would probably charge you just for giving you a smile, even though the waiter is very friendly. Hey, you're only as strong as your weakest hostess!
author: Dean C.

description:
Tried out Mifune Don today; went before the Friday evening dinner rush. Service was quick; my meal was served to me in about 5-10 minutes after I placed my order. 

The "1/2 portion" of a couple of the donburi (Unagi and Tekka) were of good value; $5.50 for a still-reasonable portion of rice with either broiled eel or raw tuna served over it. Not bad! Unfortunately the 1/2 portions do not come with a salad, but that was okay with me. Miso soup was good and fresh; however, the cabbage that was served with the donburi and miso soup was rather pitiful looking, and it wasn't even pickled. *shrug* But that was a really small part of the set anyway, so....onward--

The ambience bothered me though; I can't complain too much since Japantown in general is really unlike Japan (here I go, being a snob about Japan....). Still, even though the booth seats were nice and cute, I felt they were too close for comfort in terms of overhearing neighbors' disturbing conversations about their sexual lives. I certainly don't need to hear such things while I'm eating eel, thank you.

Other than that, I found the restaurant "A-OK". It didn't make me feel super excited/satisfied, but it also didn't make me feel like I wasted my money. Hell, it's hard to get a good, cheap dinner under $15 these days...so I can't complain on the value.
author: Helene K.

description:
I came here again yesterday with the gf. Since I haven't tried anything but the okonomiyaki, I wanted to try the ramen. Well....

I've had better. And to be honest, the ramen tasted funny, and I had to use the restroom if you know what I mean. My girlfriend had the udon, and had a similar experience. It might have just been that cook that day, but I definitely felt worst coming out, than going in.

I will say that the service is really really really good, and I'll do another update when I visit again. Hopefully it'll be better the next time around.
author: Clinton L.

description:
i went here while i was in san francisco to try the okonomiyaki here, since i'd never had it before.  the okonomiyaki was good but i don't think i'd order it again (four of us were sharing and i let them eat most of it).  i don't think it was the cooking though, but that it wasnt' really my thing.


hmm, i wasn't TOO into this place the first time i went but i like it more now.  their katsu curry is really good :3
author: Katrina V.

description:
I like Mifune Don because it's inexpensive and is true comfort food.  Do not order those crazy combo dishes or sushi.  We always stick to  the usual tempura udon and are always pleased.  Their udon is filling, warm, and tasty.  And the tempura is always fresh (and they don't throw it in the udon, which makes everything soggy by the time you get to it!).  At $7.75/bowl, mifune don is where I turn when I have a craving for udon.

Do not confuse mifune don with "mifune," which is in the other part of the mall.  I think they are owned by the same folks, but Mifune is more crowded and they do, in fact, throw the tempura into the udon, which is really annoying!
author: Quyen T.

description:
My friends and I made a mistake when we went to mifune don, we should have went to mifune as they were bigger (quality wise not so sure). We ask for a table to 9 people which isnt to unreasonable said it will take 20 minutes for a table (took 10 so great) she gave us 2 table that were back to back so we wouldnt talk to each other just the people at our table. 
So we all (the five at my table) all order. 4 of us order some soba or udon dish and 1 person ordered sushi (apparently the smart move). The 4 of us (including me) thought that the soba/udon would taste much better as their sign outside said the noodles and broth was homemade...it did taste homemade, like i got chicken broth added some water blah! My udon dish was #29 (udon with beef and vegies) the beef was cooked yet it tasted raw (if i wanted the raw taste i would have ordered it with beef on the side) my dish including tax and tip came out to $11.73..kinda high for something that taste like i could have done better..i will NEVER come here again.
author: Timothy L.

description:
The first time I came here, everything was great--decently attentive service, great price, really tasty kitsune udon!

Yesterday's experience was not so stellar, more eh. When I arrived at nearly 5pm on a Wednesday there was nobody in the place... not even the server lady. I waited around for five minutes hoping someone would magically appear so I could sit down and eat, then I decided to leave and use the restroom hoping someone would be there when I got back. Luckily that seemed to do the trick; maybe the lady was just in the back or something when I came. I don't know, anyway, not a great start to my early dinner. 

I ordered the zaru cha soba, and it was okay but kind of bland, same with the tea. I left feeling rather unfulfilled. At least it was cheap. Next time I'm definitely getting the kitsune udon again, it was wayyyy better!
author: Kristen H.

description: After a number of years in the city, I've come to the conclusion that very few (if any) Japanese restaurants do both sushi and comfort food well.  This place is firmly in the comfort food category.  The sashimi has an odd color and is additionally flavorless.  But the okonomiyaki and the nabeyaki udon...oh, the udon!
author: Angband A.

description:
Modern(Hiroshima) OKONOMIYAKI that's what I have to say.

It's good and served on a hot plate.

Will have to go back and order Shabu Shabu.
author: Jeffrey V.

description: Great food and satisfying service. Definitely will return for the chashu ramen and okonomiyaki.
author: Ella A.

description:
Fab waitress - someone needs to give her a better job
Got seated immediately, and like another said "there could be a reason"

All I wanted was a sushi nosh, and so I ordered one Calfornia Roll. I know, I know ..  .how BORRRING = however, it should have been FAB and instead it was BAD.

But really great waitress
author: Cinnamon Z.

description: My friend and I weren't very familiar with Japantown when we found this place. It looked cute and had quite a few people inside so we decided to try it. It took the waiter a little why before he acknowledged that we were there. The busboy came by and seated us outside since there wasn't room inside. I would have liked to sit inside because it looked cute but the weather was very nice so sitting outside was just as enjoyable, and also because the other store fronts could be seen from where we were seated. I had katsu with egg and my friend had ramen. I liked the katsu with the egg because the egg was a little wet the way I like it and the meat was tender although there was too much rice. It was good but not great. The ramen was also good. The bill was about $24 between the 2 of us. A little pricey for the portion and quality but what can you expect in a tourist spot.
author: Grace G.

description:
I was getting some headphones on Bush st. with the lady and we were hungry.  Of course, I'm always in the mood for japanese food.  We decided on Mifune just because we'd already been to all the other ones.  As soon as we walked in, we were overwhelmed with not just the scent of japanese food but the noise that a packed restaurant makes.  This is about when it started to go downhill.

One of the hostesses was doing, something receipts and when we said "umm, seating for two?", she put her hand up and just shrugged us off.  I looked around for another hostess who wasn't so busy and saw one getting food, or wait, just playing with the noodles.  After about a 5 minute wait when there were a large number of tables around, a waiter took us to our table.  First thing I noticed was the noise that 10 grade-school kids could make.  And then I noticed how long the table was,  I couldn't just lean over and whisper something to my honey anymore, I had to speak in normal volume :[

Nobody came to give us tea or menus so we sort of waited and just as we were about to leave, a guy came to take our order and realized we never had menus.  He came back promptly but looked pissed that we hadn't gotten the menus before.  We ordered some food and he left.  About half an hour later, our food came.  We had hoped it would make up for the horrible environment.  Many customers had already complained about the kiddy table's noise.

The food wasn't bad but all we really ordered was udon, tempura, and soba.  You have to try awfully hard to mess that up.  The tempura is worth trying though as the "breading" isn't bubbly like most places but crispy.

My recommendation, just don't go here when they're so busy.
author: Bobby Y.

description:
geez, my mom likes coming here.  I don't know why.  she just likes to be able to speak japanese to her waitress.  I like to utilize the in-table shabu shabu maker.  I like to get nabeyaki udon, or veggie tofu udon. 
moms will usually get gyoza and zaru soba i think.  or we will split nabeyaki and okonomiyaki.  Its good to have it cooking in front of your face i guess.
author: yayoi s.

description: There's really nothing special about this restaurant and by the time you're done waiting for your food to arrive, you're not as hungry. The lunch specials are standard price and the menu offers the expected options, so going there makes sense sometimes. I used to do so as a kid with my mom on her lunch break when I went to school with her.
author: Jessica L.

description:
The name of the place is Mifune DON... there is another MiFune in Japantown but THIS location specializes in Donburi - they have the best Donburi in the city NO QUESTIONS ASKED and it is for sure less expensive than most of the Japanese places around town! They also have the one of the best Okonomiyaki dishes in the city as well if your into that. 

My favorite donburi is the Tanin Don, but many of my friends think the Katsu Don and some of the others are great as well. They have a lots of other great food if your not a huge fan of donburi - even a limited selection of sushi, sashimi, ramen, and more. If the menu is not large enough try the Mifune at the other end of the mall. 

I often get the same waitress when I come in and she is great! Quick service, attention to detail, attentive over all. I highly recommend trying this place out!
author: Dewey P.

description: I've tried their udon, rolls, donburi, and donkatsu. Mediocre, nothing special about them. But this place by far has the best OKONOMIYAKI in SF! I've been to many different places for the dish but nothing can compare to it. I prefer beef & egg okonomiyaki over seafood one though. Seafood one tastes too fishy for me. It's also a very good size for the price. It comes out on a hot sizzling plate and the waitress turns on the built-in table stove to keep it warm while you eat. Mifune Don also has delicious potato croquettes. Perfect consistency inside and crispy outside! Order a plate(2 croquette per order) and enjoy them while you wait for okonomiyaki to come out(it takes some time to make this).
author: Jeanie K.

description:
If you are MSG sensitive, stay clear of this restaurant. The food wasn't terrible but the after effects of consuming MSG laden food is seriously not worth it (lathargic, exhausted, nauseus, etc). 

I had the okonomiaki, which was okay, and had bites of my boyfriend's ramen. Maybe I'm particularly more sensitive than the average person, but after consuming about 1/4 of the ramen and 1/2 of the okonomiyaki, I was not feeling well for the next day and a half. Seriously was not fun for me. 

I think if I want to take the dare to venture into eating Ramen again, I'm heading over to Katana-ya in Union Square. Food is so much better and MSG is at least tolorable.
author: Jane K.

description: Ordered a bunch of lunch specials and a Katsudon for 7 people.  Everything was good, but the sauce was under-sauced.  Ramen and Oyakodon were really good.  The service was kinda slow, but maybe it's because we were sitting outside (meaning in the mall but outside the store).
author: Ethan C.

description:
I love going to MifuneDon for their Curry Katsu.  Their curry has so much flavor and the portion is huge.  The food here is completely authentic the prices are reasonable.   Their Oyako Don is huge (Chicken Donburi).  Everytime I come here I absolutely have to have the California Rolls and the Gyoza.  

Definitely have to try their udon and ramen though, this being a noodle house and all.  Try to go during lunch though.  They have lunch combos for like 9.95 for a bowl of noodles and a side of either sushi, gyoza, or whatever else you want.  It can get pretty busy also, considering there is only one waitress, so you must be patient.
author: Cass J.

description:
I work in the area and stopped by for a take out order. My review is mainly based on my shrimp tempura dish and the friendly, efficient service I received. I paid about $15 for the meal and all the food was prepared well and the portion was fine. It was a good meal.

The woman working the floor was moving super fast to put my order together. She was really pleasant and helpful. Granted, my interaction only lasted for about five minutes, but it was a positive five minutes. (I've certainly been turned off in much less time than that.)

I'll certainly be back, and I'll want to eat there next time because the resaurant appears cozy. I also like the second floor, corner location in the mall (close to the Hotel Kabuki). It's easy to get in and out.
author: Mosephus D.

description:
I come to this little spot with my dad and friends usually after shopping at Ichibankan.  Now Mifune Don is the SMALLER restaurant in the "quiet" mall area for those who are familiar with J-Town. 

So a few things...the service is good....it is quiet in this place....the food is good......and its inexpensive.  

The main dish I love here is the Croquette Curry which consists of two Veggie Croquettes (for those who are unfamiliar this is a fried potato dumpling filled with either meat or veggies).  They are placed atop of rice and a generous helping of curry sauce.  It is my dads favorite fast curry spot and mine too.  

Also their yakisoba is good.  Like most places I need to say that if you go into a real Japanese restaurant and order Chicken Teriyaki, it is the equivalent of going into a real Mexican restaurant and having a burrito or nachos and then defining the establishment by those dishes.  I have been reading reviews on japanese restaurants and seeing people give one or two stars based on their experience of CHICKEN TERIYAKI!! Seriously people???  

So the main point is Mifune Don offers good curry rice and yakisoba.  Their zaru soba is average but I could make this at home.  So please try some real Japanese food and get out of the shell k?
author: Crista Y.

description:
Your mouth will be plesantly surprised by the great Ramen here.  Even though the meals run around $10, the "ramen" which is what they called a "house" ramen, consists of finely flavored pork, veggies and an awesome soup base.  That $10 also includes a small side dish, like gyoza (yummy and not overly fried) cali-roll (your standard flair) and unagi over rice. You can also try their sukiyaki and other delightful dishes.

Get there quick because they close at 8pm or earlier. It is in the other side of JapanTown where Ichiban Kan and Union Bank of California is at. 

It's always the same waitress there, but she is nice and prompt in responding.

Highly recommended for the price and value of food if that's your forty.. boo-yah!
author: Wilson L.

description:
ehh, there's better places in the area.  Don't come here for sushi as there is no sushi chef on hand.  Service was attentive and the hot plates embedded in the table tops for shabu shabu were cool, but if you're not there for novelty dinner table cooking, don't come.  

The ramen was ok, but its hard to mess up ramen. The gyoza was ok, the cold noodle dish my friend got, was not.
author: Jen I.

description:
Went here with a friend and the husband, in our quest to find the best okonomiyaki in the Bay Area. I followed the Yelp reviews and ordered the pork okonomiyaki and the modern okonomiyaki. We also ordered the gyoza and the breaded chicken sticks.

The gyoza and the chicken sticks were ok. Nothing to write home about. The modern okonomiyaki had the ramen noodles, which made the dish interesting, but difficult to eat. The pork okonomiyaki was ok, with thin slices of pork. I was surprised to see that all the okonomiyakis contained squid, which was great, cause I love squid! But if you're not into squid, I guess you can ask for yours without it. 

One thing I did notice, was that I was suuuper stuffed afterwards! Everything we ordered was just enough food to fill the 3 of us, and with a slice of okonomiyaki left over. The server was very attentive, always filling our cups with tea and our glasses with water. 

If I am in the area, I'll come here for a quick bite, but I must continue on with my quest to find the best okonomiyaki in the Bay Area.
author: Jan Z.

description:
Here's the thing, I've been here a few times, and the waitress/boss is very intimidating. Every time I've come here, I felt unwelcome by her. I try to order take out as much as possible to avoid her awkward stares. Also, last time when I stayed to eat, I was served after this white couple that came later than me. (Reverse racism?) 

The only reason I come here is because of the food, which is why I even bother giving them 3 stars. They have $5 lunch specials, but they're not that good. You should try their okonomiyaki because they offer the "cheapest" (average price $8) and biggest selection around.
author: Alex Y.

description:
This is a great place for okonomiyaki, soba, and donburi. I've been here at least three times and the food has always been good and inexpensive.

The service isn't the best, and yes, you'll be kept waiting, depending on whether you get the older woman or one of the younger kids serving you. But whereas I was with a group of friends on one visit and we were loud and chatty (and probably annoyed the waitress), my husband and I tried being extremely polite and quiet on a return visit. We were treated much better--the waitress even cracked a smile.
author: Stacy L.

description: Lunch menu looks interesting, but come out not interesting. Soup is hot which is good, bur the fish cake look so pale, effect the presentation of the dish. My friend felt the sushi rice is too sticky and have some uncooked rice.
author: KBs C.

description:
well, one of my japanese friends told me their Katsu curry ( deep fried pork top with japanese curry over rice ) is the one and only.

And i think he's right. The pork was crispy on the out side and tender on the inside. The cuury's absolutely Oishi!!!!. It comes with house salad and saulty cabbage. For just less than 10 bucks!!!!

They all so have the awsome Okonomiyaki.
Thick sweet wierdly dilicious japanese pizza look-alike food. 
AHHH!!!! can't wait to go back there a gainnnnn!!!!

Banzaiiiii!!!!!
author: tim t.

description: Food was very good.  The miso ramen was hearty and tasty and came with a slice of pork, a couple of prawns, and a really thin, limp kamaboko.  The broth was very flavorful without much grease.  The noodles had a good texture - not too soft nor hard.  The tekka don was only ok.  The sushi rice was a tad bit warm but with good seasoning.  The tuna was meh...about as acceptable as sushi grade can be.  Guess many yelpers have had issues with service.  Although the tiny restaurant was filled, I had prompt service.  Very good lunch special, too, for the price and amount of food.
author: Bella G.

description:
My date and I had a pretty awful dinner here.  Fortunately, we were just happy to be hanging out together, so it didn't ruin our night, but looking back it was a terrible dining experience. 
First of all, the servers were sullen and inattentive.  We had to wait for a long time to be seated even though it wasn't particularly busy, then another long wait to place a drink order, then . . . well you get the idea.  Then, after all that waiting, our server ended up bringing me the wrong dish!
But wait, it continues . . . 
Aside from not getting what i ordered, the food i received (i didn't send it back b/c i was too hungry at that point) was decent, but only just.  She seemed like she was enjoying hers - until she found a little black curly hair swimming in her udon soup!  She's not squeamish at all, but finding a pube in your soup is enough to put anyone off their udon, and she was over it at that point.  
We were already starting to talk about how this was not-the-best-dinner-ever, when she spotted a mouse running around underneath the table next to ours!  Right out in the open, with no fear of getting caught because the staff obviously did not give a damn about cleanliness.  That was that, we paid and left, thoroughly disgusted by the fact that we had just consumed food that was likely horribly contaminated by mouse droppings and definitely contaminated by pubic hair.
So, to sum everything up, go to this restaurant if you enjoy eating in vermin-infested mall restaurants where the staff hate you and serves you soup with pubes in it.
Nasty.  What's the number for the public health inspector again?
author: K F.

description: I had a great meal here... zaru soba and curry.  It was tons of food, actually too much food!  I love me some zaru soba, especially considering that even in my toddlerhood, I was eating platefulls of this stuff.  The curry was good, but devoid of any vegetables or meat.  It would have been so much better if there was one or two pieces of potato or a smidge or chicken or two.  It is a teeny little place and it's no frills.  It's cooked by one dude in the kitchen, and the one server is the one lady. It's probably a husband and wife duo.  But that's what I love, small family businesses run with love and hard work.  I would suggest maybe making the giant portions a teensy bit smaller and making it cost just a bit less.  That would make it an even better lunch!
author: Jenn H. H.

description: Edamame and seaweed salad appetizers are good but not anything special.  I was disappointed with the udon I ordered; the noodles tasted like they had been in the broth for too long and weren't as firm as udon noodles should be.  Service was slow and not very attentive; I always had to call for more water.
author: T T.

description: I was really impressed with the overall meal I had here. The food was quality, the service was good, and it certainly beat the wait at some of the trendier places in Japantown.
author: Andrew H.

description:
came for the mix okonomiyaki, which was thick -- meaty and heavy on the mayo, fried crispy on top and bottom, overall flavorful, and covered nicely with bonito flake
also had the katsu curry, sauce a little bit package-like
service attentive
wouldn't get any sushi from here
author: Rob C.

description: Just got back from their seafood okonomiyaki, and was very pleased.  So far the only one i've had in San Francisco was from Namu, which is also very good.  Place was very accomodating to a large group of us, and very affordable.  Would definitely come back here again.
author: Phil J.

description: quite the handsome large udon variety under $ten..few specialty shabu-shabu udon metal pots over $ten...heavy portioned donduri...rice plenty and soup tasty...tekka don..rice, seaweed and tuna sashimi bowl..wide and filling..soysauce wasabi saucing delicous....mifune perfect for casual udon or donburi bowls....extra large portions for fair pricing....
author: Hen A.

description:
This place is 'sufficient'... what does that mean? The food is definitely good enough - There is nothing  that distinguishes itself from the other establishments in the mall but its got the added bonus of being one of the cheaper places (and of course, not having an income these days - that really attracts me to it).

Its got a cozy environment and the beef curry that I got was good, not spectacular. Somehow, there is something about the processed taste of Japanese curry that really appeals to me... Am I the only one?

The portions were of a decent size and that's about it. It may have got a higher rating but I couldn't say that the service was great, it took them a long time to come round for our orders and for the bill to get collected.

Even with that in mind, I would go back there again though there is plenty to choose from in Japantown
author: Krishnan S.

description: They have a great lunch special which includes an udon soup and choice of appetizer. I got the california roll. It was all pretty tasty and very filling.  The space is small, so dinner time gets very busy.
author: Ka C.

description: i come here almost exclusively when I'm in Japantown, I like the lunch special, although the bowl seems to have gotten a bit smaller, Still though it's a good deal so I cant complain. Ive been meaning to try the okonomiyaki... but I always end up getting the Ramen and Nikku-don.
author: Bruce W.

description: Kitsune Soba with Tekka Don. Perfection.
author: John M.

description: I used to eat here regularly.  Came for the cold soba & cold udon - tasted great on a warm summer day.  But I stopped when i noticed a roach on my table one day.  I know that could happen anywhere but it was enough to keep me away.  Still haven't found any other place with cold soba and cold udon that tastes as delicious.  :(
author: Peggy N.

description: Really solid meal. Nicely done tempura, well-cooked rice and tasty miso soup.
author: Brian H.

description: The okonomiyaki and udon are solid, authentic tasting Japanese dishes. The reason I only have this place as 3 stars is I expected us to be able to cook the okonomiyaki at the table, but instead they bring it out pretty much done and it's just heated up at the table.
author: Aesah L.

description: I've been eating here since I was in highschool. The kitsune udon and oyako don are yum yum yummy! The udon is perfectly chewy and the kitsune makes the broth pleasantly sweet. As for the oyako don, there is a great balance of egg, chicken and onions. Sometimes donburi can be disappointing because there's more rice than anything else but at mifune, that's never the case!
author: Minie J.

description:
