I went here with my friend and we each ordered an appetizer and a main course. We went for dinner and ordered, gyoza, yakitori, okonomiyaki, and soba. The waitress was friendly and was attentive to what we needed. They were flexible in that they fit to my dislike of seafood. The gyoza was nothing really special, it was browned nicely and had good flavor, but there are some Japanese frozen brands that taste the same. The yakitori also was a little dry, and didn't have much sauce. 

However, the reason we gave them four stars is from the service and the main course. The okonomiyaki was thick and full of vegetables, egg, and beef. It was kept warm on the tabletop grill. It formed a delicious crust on the bottom of it. There was just the right amount of sauce and helped it from not drying out. It was a good meal that kept me satisfied for the night, even through Wicked, given we ate around 5-6 and Wicked ended at 11:30.
My friend said that the soba was good, she ate all the noodle, and drank most of the soup base. Even though soba is pretty hard to mess up it was good to know they had the basic stuff!

We have been going there for a long time and will continue to go for their standard Japanese food you find in America. The prices are good and the portions are satisfying.
author: Sumi M.

description: I like this place a lot more than Mifune Bistro. The lunch specials are different from the Mifune in the restaurant mall but it's still quite good. I had the tori udon and croquettes for like $10.95. I found that it was okay. I thought the service was very good which results in this 4-star rating. The portions are a bit small but yes, I'm a fan of this place. I'll come here again if I'm craving croquettes.
author: Cara C.

description: I had the sake roll and miso udon and thought it was okay. It was nothing outstanding but it was not horrible.
author: Riza I.

description: Awesome lunch special: I had the ramen (flavorful without being too salty - the pork was amazing) and the tekka (tuna) -don. It was like having two lunches, at once! I thought the tuna was solid (quality wise, not texture-wise...), which was a pleasant surprise for a restaurant that has so many options other than sushi.
author: Christie C.

description: I'm rounding up to four stars here. I'd say the food is 3.5 stars, but God, they give you so much of it!  Noodles, tempura, California rolls, salad and soup...all for $14.50! I think this is one of the more popular places in Japan Town, as there's always a line.  Hey, where can you get a drink, dinner, and still have leftovers, all for $21.00 each?
author: Kathleen P.

description: The reason you don't like this place is because you are ordering wrong. Modern Okonomiyaki - get it.  This is the ultimate Japanese comfort food. Don't be fooled by the combo plates - this is what my people call, "Fool-the-White-guy food." You don't really want to order the combo and you know damn well you choked under pressure. Japantown isn't known for its sushi because the Japanese don't eat that much sushi. You need to order nabeyaki udon, sukiyaki and, the mother of all deliciousness, the okonomiyaki. YES!!!
author: Dana O.

description: Had the udon with tofu and it was excellent. It was the best thing to have after getting off the plane. This was a small place, but cozy and not too pricey.
author: Emme K.

description: Had a great lunch here this week.  I went specifically to try their Okonomiyaki and it did not disappoint.  I had the don special which mixed pork and seafood and it was very well done (homemade is always better, but one of the best restaurant versions I've had).  My kids had soba and udon which were both excellent also.  I'll be back in when I'm in Japantown!
author: Peter G.

description: After walking past Mifune so much, I finally tried it.  For an appetizer, the sushi plate has a wonderful combination of fish and of course the soy sauce, ginger, and biting wasaby you would expect.  The green tea rice and salmon is excellent and something I have never had before; firm not soggy rice, wonderful green tea flavor that is not overpowering, and fresh salmon.  The service is very friendly and attentive.  It is a bargin.  So, for cheep Japanese cuisine that yet very good in a clean casual atmosphere, Mifune cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: By FAR the best okonomiyaki I've found in SF.  I have no idea how their other food is, since the only reason I ever go here is to have okonomiyaki.  Minus one star because you can't make it on the hot plate thingy yourself.  (Do any places in the bay area let you do that?)
author: Riya K.

description: One thing, if you are a patience kinda person you can actually come and eat here.  Yesterday I waited 1/2 hour for our food to come out.  They are understaff and the chef was pissed off cuz he can't handle all the ordered food.  It was kinda funny and yet annoying cuz I was hungry and I lost my appetite after waited for so long.  About the food, it's pretty good.
author: Albert W.

description: vegetarian croquettes are excellent!  and the okonomiyaki was also good - great, tiny place!
author: Nothin G.

description: im pretty sure this is the Mifune that is downstairs in the plaza????  im not sure about the rest of the food  but the Shabu...... SUCKS!!!  terrible terrible... maybe it doesnt help that a Japanese resturant is run by thai people?? im sure the other food is fine, but the SHABU  DO NOT EAT IT!!
author: Damien F.

description: The service here is very bad.  Another customer had to tell the stone faced hostess that my husband and I would like to be seated.  They were very unattentive.  The best part was the free beer we didnt get charged for because they were so out of it.  i asked for a box and it never came so i had to ask again.  dont go here if you're a vegetarian, our tofu dish came soaked in fish broth with fish on top.  worst part was the service.  and it was very hot in the building.
author: K R.

description: There's nothing better than when you stroll into the 1st restaurant you see and you get exactly what you want on the cheap!  The bf and I needed a snack to tide us over -- we wanted real food, but not too much, not too expensive, and it had to be supremely tasty.  BAM!  Mifune's $10 lunch special let you pick 2 plates.  How awesome was it that one combo packed the exact 2 cravings we had -- Kitsune (sweet beancurd) udon + Japanese curry w/ red pickles!!  I've had a lot of udon in my life, and the broth in this bowl hit the spot.  Nom nom nom...  (3.5 stars)
author: Andrea L.

description: Good deal on the lunch specials, you get a big bowl of soup, and a big bowl of donburi. Nice small place.
author: Jason C.

description:
Mif-ooeey.  From what my companions told me, this used to be a more hospitable and yummy place.  They no longer validate for parking in the Japantown parking garage.
And the staff was weird from the get-go.  We could see an empty booth down the hall but the hostess took her time directing us to seating. She was going back & forth to collect bills, and left a couple platters unattended - one w/a credit card, and another with cash.  We all looked at each other like, "who needs a new pair of shoes?"
Things didn't fare much better as we got led, about 10min later, to a table that hadn't been cleaned yet. 
I'll spare you the play-by-play efforts to get drinks, order, and our food served, and straight to the food that was merely ai-ight.  My beef udon, had some funny curly slices of overdone beef - it was not a lean/fresh chunk that these thin-slices were sawed from.  The broth was overly salted, too. We all finished our bowls, we were HELLA hungry, but none of us made any exclamations of delight.   
Guess the sun is setting on this establishment.
author: CINDY K.

description: Wife and I shared an okonomiyaki, homemade ramen and a tempura udon. Everything was ok (homemade ramen is always a must whenever available) but we left with an MSG aftertaste that endured for a good couple of hours.
author: P L.

description: The service is awful.  The attitude is simply an "I'm doing you a favor" attitude.  The tempura lacks flavor, the noodle soup lacks flavor, the sushi is the worst I've ever had.  Supermarket sushi is better!  It was as if the fish had been sitting out drying for a few hours.  My friends ordered various dishes and not one of us was satisfied.  I hate to say the best thing about the meal was the soda I ordered out of disgust.
author: Chester A.

description: I'm concerned about this place. Not sure where to start. Let's start with their lack of lemons. They don't have lemons for ther ice water. No big deal, but whatever. What really bothers me about this place I guess is the people I'm with. I just can't understand why they would choose this place for sushi when clearly their sushi is sub par and limited. So much for my sushi night.
author: Bobby K.

description:
This is Japanese fast food.
Nothing special.  
The ramen was disappointing.
The bento was acceptable.
author: Jerry L.

description: I've always wanted to try this place since it was next to the supermarket in the Japantown plaza. I went in, unsure what to expect since the menu on the outside resembled a very similar menu I've seen at another Japanese restaurant. I ordered the sansai (wild mountain vegetables) and kitsune (fried sweet bean curd) with my udon, which came to about $9 total. Not bad, but I wasn't amazed. My udon was nice and springy and the broth was really sweet with the bean curd. Worth trying? I'm not sure. Maybe I'd try the "All You Can Eat" raw beef thingy if I actually ate red meat.
author: Elsie L.

description: I absolutely love this place. I came here and ordered an okonomiyaki and my boyfriend ordered the croquette curry. Both were delicious, but I definitely love the curry a lot more. It was so delicious I nearly licked the plate clean. The okonomiyaki wasn't a let down either, but i'm a sauce person and love love love sauces. In any case, of course I will be back. Was disappointed though that it was closed on Tuesday.
author: Christina B.

description:
yeah!!!!! a place with okonomiyaki - and lots of different kinds (about 6) - we had seafood and vegetable for about 8buxxx...great value

we also had the $9.80 lunch combo with ramen which was a little underwhelming to me and the tekka don which was allllrriiiiigghhhttt

the broth in the ramen needed a lot of what we call 'the damn pepper' - you know, the S&B togarashi chili pepper to give it any real semblance of taste. but the noodles were good and the squid was tender.

tekka don was super fresh and the perfect size to be filled, but not stuffed.

aces!
author: Joanna R.

description: Yummmmm, okonomiyaki! I really shouldn't have,  it was hot and I was planning on having some cold soba and beer, but that okonomiyaki was calling to me.  It was really quite delicious. But you'd better be hungry, it's quite big for one person. The price was also quite good for lunch in Japantown.
author: Whitney R.

description: I love this place! I come here almost every time I come to Japantown. My group of friends & I always choose the outside booth because it's cooler and not as stuffy as inside. The waitress is very nice, she always asks us  if we would rather go inside because it's so cold outside. She's a very considerate person. I go for lunch all the time, oh! If you can come before 5PM, be SURE to go for their lunch special! It's $9.60 for a bowl of udon and a rice bowl or sushi. It's the best deal there! I love the service and she's very kind and always offers more tea even when we're about to leave. I think it's a better atmosphere because it's in the Miyako Mall and is more quiet and less commotion. &hey when you're done you can go shop for some cute trinkets @ Ichiban Kan(:
author: Jenny L.

description: 4 stars for food and 3 for service.  Food here is always delish and you can mix up a few dishes for their lunch combo.   But someone I don't understand how the server tries to run off after each person places an order.... I do want to order an appetizer or something.
author: Allison T.

description: What made me want to try this place: the plastic food models in the window (something you see in many restaurants in Japan) and the small cozy Japanese-like look of the place.  It was cozy.  I liked that they had a pile of newspapers and magazines for their customers...very ramen-yasan-like, very nostalgic for me.  I tried the Tentoji Don, which came in a humongous bowl, a side of pickled vegetables, and a bowl of omiso soup.  I liked that everything came together, and not separately.  I'd like to try this place again and try something else before I make a concrete judgement.  A revised review to come!
author: Mellie P.

description: They have lots and lots of noodles here . I got the pan-fried soba noodles with sashimi . It was alright except the noodles were sorta dry . I didn't like the pieces of onion skin sprinkled on top . I also got the seafood pancake which was okay but again , it had pieces of onion skin sprinkled on top so I had to remove all of it grrr .... lol . Service was pretty good .. food was just alright . I recommend elsewhere .. there's a lot of better places out there .. especially in SF .
author: Eileen L.

description: Great place to eat with a couple friends. I got the Mifune Special and shared okonomiyaki and it was perfect! The modernyaki is also very interesting and tasty kind of okonomiyaki I had never tried. This place goes on my list of restaurant returners!
author: Kelsey L.

description: When I take my daughter to Japan Town in San Francisco this is where we eat.  The place is tiny maybe 5 booths and 2 tables. Everytime we've been there we've had really good fresh food.  The servers are nice and well mannered. I would reccommend this restaurant.
author: Leanne J.

description: I think I actually like this restaurant better than the Mifune...because this place offers more rice dishes :)  They also have lunch special and it's pretty good as well!
author: JenJen W.

description: i came here recently for lunch, and got the lunch special.  i had the udon and a california roll.  the broth was bland and lukewarm,  the california roll fell apart when i picked it up, the rice on the california roll was flavorless, and the service was slow - it wasn't busy at all, and it took me forever to get some water.  i'm not impressed at all.
author: Norman N.

description:
There is so much great japanese food in SF that I think that it is hard for me to give a japanese restaurant 5 stars unless it can match the ambience, presentation, freshness and service of one of the uber-japanese joints like ozumo, etc.  While this place can't match up to the likes of its way-more-expensive counterparts downtown, in some ways I can enjoy a place like this just as much.  It's all about expectations, right?  Don't think upscale japanese restaurant you might find in one of the nice tokyo hotels - think hole-in-the-wall sarari-man restaurant close to a train station in anywhere, japan.  If you go in looking for a restaurant that looks/feels/tastes like the kind of restaurant MOST japanese probably enjoy, then you will not be disappointed - very good food at very reasonable prices (we stuffed ourselves with two okonomiyakis, a chicken don, and two miso soups for $30, including a 20% tip for the friendly service).  

And I know this point has been made by other yelpers many times over, but I think that it is worth mentioning again - very few places serve okonomiyaki in SF and mifune don makes a very tasty version of this hearty dish.
author: Chris S.

description: Love it! I've been looking for a place to get tendon since I got back from Tokyo. This place delivers. Okonomiyaki was fantastic as well!!
author: Natas N.

description: For a quick lunch or dinner, this is a good choice if you're in J-town.  The best dishes are the soba or udon.  I enjoy coming here because the price is reasonable, especially the lunch set.  It includes a bowl of udon or soba with a side dish, such as a Unagi Don or Tekka Don.
author: Sebastian B.

description: Mifune Don was ok, I expected more from reading the hype from yelp. I guess can't believe everything I read. The Okinamiyaki was ok, I'm still searching for better. The people there were great, prompt service and nice atmosphere. For the price they charge, I expected better tasting food. I would go back to Don Mifune a few more times, but I think that's about it.
author: Joe Y.

description:
The lunch special offers alot.    Choice of 3 kinds of noodle soup including a HUGE bowl of ramen. REALLY GOOD RAMEN and some rice or tempura varieties.  

Its a bit crowded but I just fell in love with their ramen soup base.
author: cindy L.

description: one of the two best restaurants in japantown. waitresses are friendly and don't keep asking you if you need anything else so many times, which is refreshing. and the place looks great! it has a very welcoming feeling to it and it's decorated nicely. i love katsu curry and the way they wake it is absolutely delicious. they give you great portions, a lot of meat and great flavors. the small salad they give you is seasoned with some delious peanut/sesame sauce, but the main reason why i eat here is because of the wonderful deep fried squid they make. you gotta pay an extra dollar or two to make it this way because it's not on the menu, but  who cares. next time you're here, try it. you've love it as much as i do.
author: Diego T.

description: tempura udon kicked ass. quick service, cheap, and close to all the action in Japantown.
author: Tara H.

description: This is not the regular Mifune in the main area of the Jtown mall, this place is n the other mall across the main plaza. the udon here is pretty decent, and the service is okay. There was one poor waitress working a packed saturday lunch period, and she looked stressed out. The best reason to go here is their daily lunch special that runs from the morning to 5 Pm. for about 11 bucks, you get your choice of udon, ramen or soba, and you can get a side dish of oyako donburi, tekka, gyoza, cali roll, among some others. It is a very good price for the amount of good. Is there better Japanese food out there? Hell yeah. But for the amount of decent food you get with their 11 dollar lunch special, this place deserves a good rating. A lot of people get the soba for the lunch special, and it is good. Next time, i want to try their okonomiyaki, as they were advertising that they won some culinary award for it.
author: Jerry C.

description: This is not a review but a question for anybody who has eaten here.  I grew up in Japan and CRAVE Japanese food, especially okonomiyaki.  The problem is I am allergic to MSG with major symptoms.  Does anybody know if it is possible to get the OKO made with no MSG?
author: Tara S.

description: Small place, enormous taste. I love this place. I was in San Francisco for 3 days and I went here 2 times. The soup is unmatchable, and delicious. A smaller option to the larger and less tasty (in my opinion) Mifune. Fresh ingredients and soup to rave about. If you are a fan of udon soup in San Francisco go here.
author: John B.

description: A cozier version of Mufune with an expanded menu? Yes! I stumbled upon the mini outlet of the Kintetsu classic by chance yesterday before catching a show at the Kabuki. Expecting the same delicious, but by now predictable noodly fare, I opened my menu to the thrill of new items, or at least new to Mifune. Potato croquettes, curries, okonomiyaki, and a wallop of table-grilled choices stared out at me. Where to start? I was in a yakisoba or curry mood, but the beef curry won out. What tasty goop with onion slivers and beef shaving came ladled atop my mound of rice! A small dish of lightly pickled greens in one bite, a shovel of beefy curry rice the next; some cold, wet salad to round it all out. My companion got the tempura soba plate (tenzaru,) which proved that Mini Me has the same great quality staples you'd come to expect. It's a gem.
author: Jessica D.

description: yelpers!! you let me down!! the modern okonomiyaki at mifune was a total waste of time, parking, and commute! we got something 1MIL times better at daly city, MAJIKKU RAMEN!!!!!!! there was barely any ramen noodles in the okonomiyaki. the service was also bad, bad, bad. one of the servers was walking around, making himself busy, but no refills, no hospitality, no nothin. pass!
author: natassia s.

description: Ok I really liked this spot! The first time I tried sushi was at the mifune don and it was really gooood! I took my gf here yesterday and the food was sooo goood I wanted to order another meal! but me and my Gf end up ordering 2 meals and 3 more orders of cali rolls..... The waiter was nice and even showed me how to use chopsticks. I left a 20% tip (the first time I came). A funny experience I had here is the first time Me and my gf came here the same exact waiter could not speak English that well, So we didnt expect her to say "are you finished with this dude" aha Me and my gf chuckled because it was a shocker. Overall is was a good experience.
author: Brandon s.

description: Avoid Like the plague. Terrible service. My friend got cold udon noodles and the waitress had put some fish sauce next to his plate. She comes and checks with us 10 minutes later and he hasn't touched the fish sauce. She grabs the bowl of fish sauce, shoves it in his face and said "Why you no like fish sauce? Try with your noodles", and continued to pour over his udon. We left, didn't pay for it. Terrible waste of time.
author: Alycia M.

description: i don't understand why this place doesn't have a higher rating. their shabu-shabu is awesome and very affordable. the server/hostess/cashier is very nice and accomodating. plus, they validate parking. 4 solid stars!!!
author: J S.

description: I had okonomiyaki here yesterday and it was made in heaven.  Fabulous.  Their sushi is nothing special.  But that okonomiyaki... I have had it 2-3 times at Mifune Don over the past 5 years and it is always stellar.
author: Chris D.

description: This is, in my opinion, the better of the two Mifune's in Japantown.  The only place I know of that has kickass okonomiyaki and yakisoba, as well as regular cold soba noodles.  Oh yeah, their hot soba noodles rock too.  I have almost ate everything on their menu, and have never been disappointed.  The waitress is so nice and always hooks me up when/if she can, especially when it's not busy!  You gotta come here when it's not packed and when it's slow so you get the best service.
author: Jim N.

description: The restaurant was not crowded, and now I know why.  The food is serviceable, if your hungry and can't wait for one of the other fabulous places in Japantown.  We had a noodle dish and a meat entree...it was so memorable I don't know what the dishes exactly were.  OK service and OK food.
author: The F.

description: I love this place! I come here every Saturday and never get tired of it. I really like their niku udon which is udon with beef. I think that they should use a little less salt for their dishes, but otherwise everyone should come and eat at Mifune Don.
author: Marina C.

description:
ok granted that i probably annoyed the waitress because i changed my order (i know bad, but i couldn't help but get nabeyaki udon) i was planning to get the lunch special (ramen and korokke, oh how i love korokke)
but i was feeling a bit cold... and wanted nabeyaki udon... sue me. x.x
i was supposed to meet my friend and we were planning to go to sapporo ya but she ended up not being able to make it so i went to mifune don instead.
service was fairly nice, until more people started coming in that some had to be seated outside... when i was nearly done (i give them credit for not giving me my bill while i was still eating the food portion) but i wanted to drink the rest of the soup =[  it was slightly salty tho but i also kind of burned my tongue because i didn't realize how hot it was... =X
but it was pretty good
food was pretty good, but my tempura was kind of soaking in the udon. i know they usually put it in there... but that's what i also burned my tongue on in attempts to try eating it before it would become soggy. 
anywho, it had an egg (yay), some vegetables, and two slices of fish cake, and some meat
for me, i like that type of udon (i've had udon where they have different types of fish in it... and i know that nabeyaki udon supposedly usually seems to have fish, but i like the one without fish better) x.x
yes i'm picky =\ i haven't a clue what authentic is but as long as it tastes good, won't make me sick, is decent and tastes like it's supposed to, i'm, for the most part, good
so, food was good
service was ok... for the most part
price was 11$ including tip. it was fairly decent and i kind of expected to spend around that much for lunch in jtown =X then again, japanese food seems to always be expensive... and i always want japanese food...
i still really want to try okonomiyaki... i would come here again.

[Edit:]
I had their okonomiyaki, twice. and I really enjoyed it ^.^ I went on Wednesday (take out). and the waitress seemed a bit more cheerful that day and that cheerfulness spread to myself, so I was happy too =3
anyhow, it was good xD and good, and really good!! i wish had more x.x.... however, i need to ask for without mayo... (i keep forgetting though) (and not because they put too much or anything, but i don't like the taste of mayo... and there's also the fact that  my mother always told me to never eat the mayo when i was younger...... anyhow, i need to remember to ask for it without) =3
Regardless, their okonomiyaki is extremely delightful (good food = happy me ^.^)
author: Christina W.
